Kamloops, B.C.,
June 4th, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I would be obliged if the Department would grant me authority to purchase the following re-fills for the fire extinguishers at the Kamloops Indian Residential School:

18--2 gal. Foamite Extinguishers @ $1.80........32.40
8--2 gal. Soda Acid Ext. @ $.60...........4.80
10--1 qt. Fire Gun Extinguisher @ $1.45.......14.50

$51.40

This price of $51.40 is f.o.b. Vancouver, B.C. In addition to this there would have to be added the freight. These prices were supplied me by the La France Fire Engine and Foamite, Ltd., Vancouver, B.C.

A representative of this firm visited the school today and went over all this class of equipment there and prepared the above list of refills required.

It is going on to two years since these extinguishers were refilled and I feel that they should be attended to as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

(W.J. Ferguson)
Indian Agent.

WJF/3.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.
Ottawa, June 10, 1936.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 5th ultimo, regarding an expenditure of $2000.00 for repairs required to Kamloops Residential School, at the time of receipt of your letter the Principal, Rev. Father Kennedy was away from the School, and I thought it better to delay proceeding with the estimates on the work until his return. He returned last week, and I have had Mr. V. Durante prepare an estimate on the plaster and pointing of the brick as follows:

**ESTIMATE OF V. DURANTE OF JOB AT KAMLOOPS RES. SCHOOL**

Window and door bumpers in Boys' and Girls' Dormitories and repairing plaster where damaged by knobs

Repairing plaster in Girls' Playroom

Repairing plaster in dishwashing room

Repairing plaster in Dairy kitchen

Repairing plaster in Staff Rooms

Tearing down old broken plaster in boys' shower room and replacing with cement slab

Repairing plaster in Boys' Dormitors

Boys' Play room: Tearing down old plaster 3' 6" in height) all round hall and replacing with one inch mesh netting and three coats of cement, smoothed and marked in tiles $68 sq.ft.$217.00

Repairing plaster in same hall above cement work

Repainting all bricks with new mortar on outside of building about 6 ft. in height, and rebuilding arch in boys' dormitory entrance

$5 for possible extras that might arise

All the above items are quite small with the exception of the $217.00 for the boys' playroom, but I think you will recall that when you were out here last year that

R. Guernsey Orr, Esq.,
Architect,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6449, file 882-5, part 3)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
that the plaster in this room had a number of small and large holes over the walls, with the greatest damage being within 3 feet, 6 inches of the baseboard. Since your visit considerable more damage has been done to these walls. To just plaster up these holes would not help much as the children playing in the room would soon have it in the same damaged condition again.

In view of this I have had Mr. Durante estimate on new cement work for the 3 feet 6 inches all around the hall. I had in mind V-joint for this work, but he claims the cement will be more substantial.

All this repair work in Mr. Durante's estimate is very necessary to rid the school of its dilapidated appearance, especially in the boys' wings, and I would recommend that this estimate be accepted, and as I consider this work of first importance, I would like to be authorized to proceed with the work considering the painting and plumbing at the same time.

I had Mr. Blackburn and Mr. Carr over to the School this morning, and they have promised to let me have their estimates on the painting and plumbing early next week.

The condition of the shingles on the roof of the girls' wing is quite bad as some 10 or 20 square feet of the shingles have lifted and some patch work will have to be done to put it in shape before painting. I will have a carpenter estimate on the work and forward same as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

(W.J. Ferguson)
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Further in reference to your letter of the 5th ultimo, regarding an expenditure of $2000.00 for repairs required to Kamloops Residential School, I beg to advise that I am now in receipt of Mr. R.C. Blackburn's tender covering the painting and decorating as follows:

Boys' Play room; 1 coat enamel on ceiling, posts, etc. 52.00
Kalsomine walls; 3 coats paint on 4 ft. dado 62.00
2 lavatories; 2 coats paint on all toilet, bathroom, partitions, radiators, pipes, etc. 117.00
Varnishing windows and doors 19.00
2nd floor, kalsomining; 2 wash room, painting wash stands and bronzing radiators 19.00
Top floor kalsomining walls and ceilings throughout 88.00
Ground floor front corridors throughout, 2 coats kalsomine 44.00
Varnishing baseboards in same 11.00
Kitchen ceiling, radiators, pipes, etc., 2 coats enamel 39.00
Wash room, kalsomining walls and painting dado 3 coats 23.00
Girls lavatory, painting partitions 2 coats and kalsomining sisters rest room 32.00
Outside doors (forty) stain and varnish 38.00
1 coat linseed oil paint on east wing roof, including all dormer windows, cornice, etc. 215.00
1 coat linseed oil paint on west wing roof, including all dormer windows, cornice, etc. 215.00

$974.00

I personally went thoroughly over the school buildings with Mr. Blackburn and laid out the work for him to tender on. All this work is very necessary to put the appearance of the building in shape, and I would recommend that the tender be accepted and instructions issued for Mr. Blackburn to proceed with the work.

You will note that I have had him tender on the painting of both the boys and girls wings. This is necessary as it would be a matter of a couple of years and both of these roofs would have to be reshingled. In fact, as already mentioned in my letter of June 10th, some of the shingles on the girls wing would have to be

W. Guernsey Orr, Esq.,
Architect,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.
replaced. I have asked Mr. Durante for a tender on this work, but have not received it as yet. As soon as I receive it I will forward it on to you. In the meantime I would like to be instructed to proceed with this shingle work at the same time authority is granted for the painting job.

In connection with the plumbing work, Mr. Carr has tendered as follows:

"We would agree to fix up the present boys wash table by repairing the zinc covering, also to straighten and fix the water pipes and install splash backs up the wall; we would straighten the girls wash tables and renew the lead tops on same and cover the tops with heavy zinc; we would take down the wall rads in the recreation room to allow the plasterer to cement behind them; install all sleeves on main steam pipe from the boiler room to stop the expansion on main from breaking plaster; Repair Monel Metal Sink in Dairy, which sink is 3 ft. by 4 feet and made of heavy material; but the bottom has had unequal expansion and has wrinkled and cracked; Our price is two hundred and ten dollars ($210.00)."

I also went over the work to be done with Mr. Carr and found all these repairs necessary. The splash of water in the girls and boys wash rooms has rotted the table tops and damaged the floors with some damage to the wall.

In regard to the girls toilets, Mr. Carr has tendered as follows:

"We would agree to take the present range of toilets out of the girls wing and install 13 Twyford seat action closets with high tank for the sum of Thirteen Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($1350.00). To install this battery of toilets it would be necessary to cut the present terazzo floor a foot wide and thirty feet long, and replace same; as we have to lay the waste pipe beneath the floor to get the toilets on the present floor level."

If there are no funds available over and above the $2000.00 allotted, I would suggest that this item be laid over for another year. The Principal, Rev. Father Kennedy is in accord with this claiming that they can get along with the present equipment for another year, but due to the fact that this type of toilet has been condemned for use in public buildings as being unsanitary by the health authorities, these repairs should be kept in mind when preparing next year's estimates.

The expenditure as recommended by me up to date amounts to: Durante 377.00 Blackburn 974.00 Carr 210.00

A total of 1,561.00 leaving a balance of $439.00 from the $2000.00; to expend this there are other important repairs at the school to the kitchen roof, kitchen
W.G. Orr. Esq.

July 25, 1936

floor, girls' playroom, etc., However, further reports will follow in this respect.

The repairs to the plaster are under way at the present time, and should be ready for the painting and kalsomining in a week's time.

Yours truly,

(W.J. Ferguson)
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

With reference to my letter of the 25th instant, dealing with repairs to Kamloops Indian Residential School. I beg to advise that in connection with the repairs to the shingles on the roof of the girls' wing, I have the following tender today from Mr. Durante.

"My price for repairs to the East Wing shingle roof (about 59 sq. ft.)—nailing on old shingles and replacing with new shingles where necessary, is fifty dollars. ($50.00)."

This appears quite reasonable to me and if only $50.00 will put this roof in shape before painting, it should be done and I would ask authority for this expenditure.

With regard to the repairs to the kitchen roof, Mr. Durante has tendered as follows—

"I find the roof in very bad shape and would agree to take out most of the flashing and cut the gravel off the roof back about six inches and lay two ply of Irish felt around parapet under flashings; replace flashings, repair some leaks where vent pipe comes through roof. Also I would sweep roof clean of gravel and dirt, wash the same with hose, then apply a heavy coat of high melting point pitch all over roofs and bed new gravel on same. My price for the above work is one hundred and sixty-six dollars ($166.00)."

I have not had time to check up on this work, but as soon as I do and I find the work all necessary, I will write for authority.

Yours truly,

(W.J. Ferguson)
Indian Agent.

K-S-2.

Dear Sirs:-

Mr. Arnell, Dominion Public Works Engineer, after inspecting the boilers at Kamloops Indian Residential School here on the 23rd ultimo, reported that in connection with the new boiler purchased from you last October, he had found some 30 leaks around the tubes of the upper end, and about 20 leaks around the tubes in the fire box. There is also another place that needs caulking. This appears to have been caused by faulty construction.

The boiler has not been in use a year yet, and at that it has only been fired about 30 times of a one day duration at each time.

In view of these circumstances I would ask you to please, as soon as possible, see about repairing this boiler and putting it in proper condition at the expense of your firm.

Yours truly,

(W.J. Ferguson)
Indian Agent

Vancouver Engineering Works, Ltd.,
VANCOUVER, B.C.

COPY FOR MR. GUERNSEY ORR, DEPT. OF INDIAN AFFAIRS.
Dear Sir:

Further in regard to the repairs to Kamloops Indian Residential School, I had here in the office to see me the other day an Engineer from the Tremco Manufacturing Co., who quoted as follows in regard to the painting of the roofs of the boys' and Girls' wings.

"The Blackbourn Decorating Company are prepared for the additional sum of SIXTY DOLLARS ($60.00) to use Tremco Specially Formulated Shingle Paint color Green, to all areas as specified in their original tender, of Two Hundred and Fifteen Dollars ($215.00), also to use Tremco Heavy Duty Paint, to all metal work, cornices, weatherboards trim etc., the Shingle paint to be applied at the rate of 200 sq ft per gallon of paint, the Heavy paint; all surfaces set out, at the rate 450 sq ft per gallon; 1 coat job to all surfaces, except such places where shingle replacement is deemed necessary, this surface shall receive priming coat in addition to standard finish."

Mr. Blackbourn has agreed to the changing of materials if so desired by the Department.

The Engineer, Mr. J.T. Leigh said that you would be familiar with his product's some of the Parliament Buildings had been painted with his. From his talk it appeared to be the right thing for the Schools, but as I am not familiar with this material I cannot recommend that this change be made and leave it with you to decide.

Yours truly,

(W.J. Ferguson)
Indian Agent

KAMLOOPS INDIAN AGENCY REPORT FOR MONTH OF MAY, 1936.

ACTIVITIES:

KAMLOOPS RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL. - More interest is being taken at the school in connection with the grounds. The play grounds for the children have been much improved with basketball court, swings repaired with flowers and some lawn planted along the front of the buildings. This all much improves the appearance of the place.

W. J. Ferguson
Indian Agent.
Kamloops, B.C.,
July 10th, 1936.

KAMLOOPS INDIAN AGENCY REPORT FOR MONTH OF JUNE, 1936.

ACTIVITIES:

KAMLOOPS RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL. - Refills were purchased for the fire extinguishers at the school, and all this equipment was re-charged and brought up to date. The Rev. Principal complained that there was some danger to the children from the pulleys in the laundry. This was pointed out to Mr. Carr, who made the necessary improvements by putting galvanized metal guards around the pulleys, without charge. An allotment of $2,000.00 for repairs in general has been allowed the School by the Department. In this respect estimates are being prepared.

W. J. Ferguson
Indian Agent.
VANCOUVER ENGINEERING WORKS, LTD.,
VANCOUVER, B.C.,

August 11th, 1936.

W.J. Ferguson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Department of Indian Affairs, Canada,
Kamloops, B.C.,

Dear Sir:

We are in receipt of your favour of August 7th in regard to the vertical boiler and regret the trouble you are having in connection with same.

We may say that before making shipment of the boiler it was put under test by our own mechanics and also was examined under test by the Boiler Inspection Department and everything was in first class condition, with no signs of weakness apparent.

We are of the opinion that the condition which you now find is simply due to ordinary contraction and expansion conditions and doubtless if the boiler was in operation for an extended time these leaks, which you mention, would take up.

In view of the test to which the boiler was submitted before shipment, we regret that we cannot see our way clear to agreeing to your request that this boiler be caulked at our expense. We would, however, be prepared to send a boiler maker to Kamloops to do this work without profit, or in other words, at our net cost.

Yours very truly,

VANCOUVER ENGINEERING WORKS, LTD.,

(Signed) E. Redpath,
General Manager.

AC/AMF.

THE SECRETARY,

Dear Sir-

In connection with the Vertical Boiler in the Laundry at Kamloops Indian Residential School, Mr. T.J. Arnall, engineer of the Dominion Public Works, in his inspection report recommends as follows:

"Most of the tubes were leaking on top tube sheet; Seam in firebox leaking; Longitudinal Seam below butt strap leaking. These should be repaired by the Manufacturer without expense to the Department as this is a new boiler and has had every care. Safety valve set to correspond with steam requirements of laundry machinery."

In regard to this I wrote the Vancouver Engineering Works, Vancouver on the 7th instant, asking them to make the necessary repairs at their expense. A copy of this letter was forwarded to you. Since then I have had a reply from them, a copy of which is enclosed herewith.

I am of the opinion that the responsibility for the condition of this boiler rests with the Manufacturers. Please advise me as to just what action I should take in the matter.

Yours truly,

(W.J. Ferguson)
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.
Ottawa, September 1, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th ultimo, enclosing copy of a communication you received from the Vancouver Engineering Works, Limited, regarding the condition of the vertical boiler in the laundry at the Kamloops Indian Residential School. It is noted that the Engineer of the Dominion Public Works Department, following his inspection, recommended considerable repairs to this boiler, as enumerated in your letter.

This boiler has been in use only about a year, and the Department fails to understand why it should be in its present condition. It is noted the Vancouver Engineering Works are of opinion that the present condition of the boiler is due to ordinary contraction and expansion and that this firm will be unable to carry out the necessary repairs at their own expense.

All expenses for the purpose should be kept to the lowest possible point, and, when the work has been completed to the satisfaction of the Principal and yourself, you should obtain an itemized account, in triplicate, stating in detail the work carried out, the number of days or hours employed and the rate charged. This account, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. I would request that you have the repairs made to this boiler at an early date.

Dear Sir:

Attention Mr. Orr,

I am enclosing herewith Vouchers No. 258-36 and 272-36, in favour of V. Durante and Carr & Son respectively, for work in connection with repairs to Kamloops Indian residential School.

In regard to Mr. Carr's account, you will please note that it is $30.00 less than his tender of $210.00. The reason for this was that other urgent work showed up, and I decided that repairs to the Monel Metal sink in the Dairy ($30.00) should wait over for another year, and in place of this, I had the shingles on roof of gables on the girls' wing repaired by V. Durante ($30.00).

In regard to this extra shingling work I beg to say that when Mr. Blackbourn commenced the painting of the roof, it was found that the shingles on these roofs of the gables had become badly weathered and lifted some so bad that they had to be replaced and all the others renailed. Rather than delay the painting of this part of the building with everything all set, along with excellent weather, I had the work done and trust that you will approve of my action. When considering the first shingle repair job the gables were overlooked as the roofs of the gables were not visible from the ground.

In regard to the other item on Voucher 258-36, for cement piers, etc., ($25.00), these piers had to be installed to hold the wall radiators. Previous to the repairs the radiators had been fastened to the baseboard which was imbedded in the old plaster for support. When this plaster and baseboard was replaced with cement there was nothing left but tile and cement to which to fasten them. These new piers have a centre bolt with the head fastened into the cement of the floor.

This makes a total expenditure to date of $1696.00.

On October 17th the Indian Agent wrote to the department stating that Mr. Gale claimed that all the equipment, including dynamo, piping and other fittings should be turned over to him with the tank. The Agent did not agree with this as the tender definitely stated the old pneumatic tank. The Indian Agent was advised on October 31st that the tank only was sold to Mr. Gale.

Dear Sir,

Regarding your inquiry of May 5th the sewage disposal system at the Indian Industrial School at Kamloops, B.C. is comprised briefly as follows:

The system is what is known as Septic Tank Sub-surface Irrigation System, and consists of a reinforced concrete septic tank connected with two disposal beds composed of 4 inch open jointed land tile laid 3'6" below the surface of the ground.

The sewage is carried from the school by means of 4 inch sewer pipes to a main inspection chamber from whence it is transferred by means of an 8 inch sewer pipe to the septic tank.

The septic tank is divided into two compartments:

1. Settling chamber or septic tank which is 15' x 7' x 9'6" deep and is connected by a 5 foot overflow weir with the siphon chamber.

2. The siphon chamber which is 15' x 7' x 6'6" deep and is equipped with automatic siphon discharging four times a day under normal loads.

The discharge pipe from the septic tank to the disposal bed is a 6" sewer pipe 210' in length.

The disposal beds are two in number consisting of 4" land tile laid to conform with the contours of the ground on a grade of .005. The east bed consists of 2000 linear feet of land tile, and the west bed comprises 1500 linear feet. This gives a total disposal bed of 3500 linear feet.

The construction of this plant was carried out by contract under the supervision of the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service, Vancouver, in 1924. Detailed specifications and plans for this system are not available at hand, but if you...
require them they will be procured and forwarded at your request.

KAMLOOPS INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL
SEWAGE DISPOSAL

Sir:

I made an examination of conditions existing at the above school in respect to sewage disposal, during June, 1937.

Following is a report in this connection.

KAMLOOPS INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL

The accompanying plan Appendix "A" shows the location of the school. The school building is situated at the southern extremity of a low ridge projecting from the hills to the north, and is at an elevation of about 25 feet above the bank of the South Thompson river. To the south and west are extensive river flats, most of which are covered with water at flood stage of the Thompson river.

Occupying a considerable area of the School property on the river flats is a small lake used for bathing purposes by the school children. The lake surface varies in elevation four or five feet at medium and high stages of the river, when river and lake are directly connected by a small channel. At such times the lake area increases more than 50%.

PRESENT SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM

Sewage disposal facilities consist of a septic tank of about 4,000 gallons capacity or about 13 gallons per head for the school population of approximately 325. The flow to the septic tank is approximately 12,000 gallons per day.

C.E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water and Power Bureau,
VANCOUVER, B.C.
Effluent from the septic tank is discharged at about 200 feet from the tank and finds its way by an open ditch to a small pond at the foot of the garden.

When the sewage disposal system was first installed in 1924, it included a sub-irrigation system of about 0.35 acres to which was discharged the tank effluent. In 1930, however, the distribution pipes of the sub-irrigation system clogged up, were subsequently re-conditioned and operated successfully for two years when they again clogged and have not since functioned. The last time was due apparently to the fact that solids were passing from the settling chamber to the syphon chamber, as was evidenced by the condition of the pipes recently dug up.

The septic tank is in my opinion too small to accommodate the amount of debris which accumulates in a few months after being cleaned. The reduced capacity as a result of this accumulation causes an increased rate of flow through the tank resulting in decreased septization and the conveyance of solids to the syphon chamber. The function of the settling chamber appears to be nullified by the grade of the inlet pipe which allows a high velocity inflow and keeps the tank contents in an agitated state.

It would appear desirable to have an enlarged settling chamber capacity at least twice the existing capacity, or sufficient to accommodate from 16 to 24 hours sewage.

The major problem, however, appears to be a satisfactory disposal of septic tank effluent and sludge.
The present method of disposal of septic tank effluent, to the pond at the feet of the garden, is very unsanitary as at times a considerable amount of the effluent accumulates and the area becomes a breeding ground for flies. The stench from the area has become very much of a nuisance.

METHODS OF SEWAGE DISPOSAL

In addition to the inspection of the existing plant, I investigated the possibility of alternative methods of disposal of sewage both in a raw condition and after treatment.

Sewage in a raw state, from Kamloops School, may not be disposed of other than by emptying into the North Thompson river. To do this would require the construction of a pipeline about two and one-half miles in length. The pipeline grade, however, would be below the minimum for satisfactory conveyance.

On the attached plan are shown two projected sewer lines from the school to the Thompson river.

Line "A" as above mentioned would be unsatisfactory due to insufficient grade. Line "B" would not be possible for raw sewage, due to location of C.H.R. pumphouse supplying Kamloops Junction, within a short distance of the projected sewer outfall.

For the discharge of treated or processed sewage to the South Thompson river, it would be desirable to have an outfall closer to the school and farther from the pump intakes, as dissemination in the river water would be more complete and the cost would be less.

The disposal of raw sewage by broad irrigation is not a practical possibility due to necessity of pumping to suitable ground and of using other methods.
of disposal in winter.

It is probable that septic tank treatment of sewage at Kamloops School is preferable to any other process as it is as a rule the least expensive to operate, and provides an effluent easily disposed of and susceptible to subsequent treatment if found necessary. The sludge and detritus is reduced to a minimum and both are in a state readily and cheaply handled.

**DISPOSAL OF SEPTIC TANK EFFLUENT**

Effluent from septic tanks is not considered by most authorities to be free from disease producing bacteria, and for that reason subsequent treatment or disposal should be considered necessary at the Kamloops Industrial School, so as to preclude the possibility of endangering the health of the neighborhood.

The most readily available place of disposal would be the South Thompson river, where the low water flow would be sufficient to provide a dilution of about 1 in 62,000 — authorities consider that 1 in 50 to 100 is ample safeguard. However, it would probably be unwise to empty the septic tank effluent directly into the river even if subsequently chlorinated or filtered owing to the proximity of the City of Kamloops and other users, at least until other reasonable expedients have been exhausted.

The system of disposal by sub-irrigation is the method most suitable for adoption at the school. It is likely to prove the cheapest to install and operate, and least likely to create a nuisance. The area suitable for the purpose is limited to about one to one and one-half acres close to the septic tank.
but at a desirable distance from the river.

**SUGGESTED SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM**

I would suggest that the existing sewage disposal system be re-constructed with minor alterations to function as was originally intended. The septic tank capacity should be increased to take care of present requirements, sub-irrigation beds provided for disposal of the effluent and facilities for removing accumulation of sludge and detritus installed. Such a reconstructed system with the improvements and facilities mentioned, is estimated to cost complete $6015.00 and is as shown on attached plan Appendix "B".

**SUB-IRRIGATION DISPOSAL BEDS**

Beds suitable for disposal of septic tank effluent by sub-irrigation may be constructed at an estimated cost of $3745.00. Such an installation should consist of two units aggregating about one acre in area and so connected with the septic tank as to permit of alternate applications of the effluent to the beds at intervals of about six hours.

Tile in the existing disposal beds is laid at a depth of 4½ feet. It is proposed that the new tile be laid at a depth of about 3 feet, which is expected will be sufficient depth for frost protection. It will be less expensive to install new tile than to dig up the old tile, clean it, and refill the trench, as a shift from the ground used for the former beds is required.

**SEPTIC TANK ALTERATIONS AND ADDITIONS**

Proposals for the enlargement of the septic tank capacity, alterations to present tank, provision for sludge removal, alternating syphons, etc., are estimated to cost $2270.00.
Enlargement of capacity would be obtained by providing an additional settling chamber of approximately the same content as the present one, with connection to the syphon chamber and provision for proportionate distribution of sewage to the two settling chambers. The present syphon chamber would be re-equipped with alternating syphons discharging to sub-irrigation beds.

Provision for removal of sludge would consist of installation of hopper bottoms in settling tanks with 8-inch outlets and discharge pipes. The pipe outlet to be so located as to provide for discharge of sludge into a confined area in the garden to permit drying and subsequent removal.

The carrying out of the above alterations and enlargements should be undertaken during mid-summer school holidays, July or August, as the cost of the work would be at a minimum at that time and any interruption to the operation of the sewage disposal plant would not affect the school.

Regarding the employment of funds, presently available, these could best be used in increasing the septic tank capacity and alterations to existing tank, estimated to cost $2270., to be followed by the installation, at a later date, of the disposal beds.

MAINTENANCE OF SYSTEM

Much of the difficulty in connection with the satisfactory operation of the sewage disposal system has probably been due to lack of familiarity of the school staff with the operation of such systems. It would be desirable that written instructions regard-
ing the functioning of the equipment and its maintenance be accessible to the school authorities and that the school staff charged with such duties be informed of what is required to maintain the system in good order and at a minimum of expense.

The system should function from 2 to 3 years without the necessity of cleaning the settling tank, and it should not be necessary to clean the disposal beds oftener than once in ten years. While it should be possible to clean the beds at a very reasonable cost, probably not exceeding $150.00, sometimes it is necessary to have the tile completely dug up, if the septic tank effluent carries much sludge, as the soil becomes clogged. Under such conditions the cost of cleaning is very much higher.

W.G. Warren
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer

I am now in receipt, from Mr. Webb, of a report prepared by Mr. Warren a copy of which accompanies this memorandum.

It appears that the situation in respect to sewage disposal from this institution is somewhat complicated, due to the Kamloops Residential School being situated on the north side of the South Thompson River, a mile or so above the city of Kamloops whose water supply is taken from the South Thompson River a short distance down stream.

The possibility of discharging the effluent, after treatment in septic tanks, directly into the South Thompson River was given consideration by Mr. Webb and in view of the volume of flow in this river it would seem that such would be a safe method of disposal. However, as the city of Kamloops takes their water supply from a point about half a mile down

stream from where the effluent from the school would have to be discharged, it was finally decided that it would be unwise to take any chances, however remote, of contaminating the city water supply. MEMORANDUM ON THE SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM OF THE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL AT KAMLOOPS, B.C.

Examined - Oct. 26th, 1937.

Principal of School, - Father Kennedy.

The Indian Residential School is situated about three miles from the city of Kamloops on the north bank of the South Thompson River and was visited on the above date in order to determine what influence the school's sewage disposal system might possibly have in polluting the South Thompson River which is used as a source of water supply by Kamloops and the Canadian National Railways at Kamloops Junction, the intakes being located on opposite sides of the river two miles below the school. The water from each supply is delivered for consumption in the raw state.

From the months of September to June inclusive the resident population at the school is 314 while during the summer months it drops to 15. The method of disposing of the domestic sewage from this source may be described as follows. A gravity source of water supply of ample quantity permits the use of numerous flush type toilets in the school which all drain through 4-inch sewer pipes to a main inspection chamber from whence the sewage is conveyed through an 8-inch pipe to a covered reinforced concrete septic tank of two chambers with given dimensions of 15 ft. by 7 ft. by 9½ ft. deep for the settling chamber and 15 ft. by 7 ft. by 6½ ft. deep for the dosing or siphon chamber. The liquid effluent from the tank discharges through a 6-inch pipe to a disposal field, 210 feet distant, consisting of 3,500 linear feet of open jointed 4-inch field tile laid at a depth of 3ft.-6in. in gravelly soil. The ends of the branches are provided with vents.

An examination of the system disclosed that the sub-
surface irrigation part was not functioning at all, having been clogged up for some time. The effluent from the tank had a very strong odor from the putrescible organic matter in it and was being discharged into an open ditch, finally collecting in a shallow hollow about 1,000 feet from the bank of the river and at an elevation of about 20 feet above it. The soil at this point appears to be heavy clay so that the liquid does not run away freely. (see Photo No. 3.)

The contour of the ground is such that a rim exists between this hollow and the bank of the river preventing any of the sewage from flowing directly into the river. However, the presence of a small slough to the west of the school, (Photo No. 2), which is known to rise and fall with the level of the Thompson River suggests that there may be a possible connection with the river providing an indirect means for this sewage to reach and pollute it, endangering the quality of the water at the municipal intake.

From a calculation of the capacity of the present system it is apparent that the tank and the disposal field are inadequate for the amount of sewage to be handled with the consequent results from overloading. From 40 to 60 gallons of sewage per capita per day are usually allowed for in designing a tank. Assuming a flow of 40 gallons per capita and an average detention period of 24 hours the settling tank should hold 14,420 gallons which includes a 15% allowance for sludge. This requirement is in contrast to the maximum capacity of the present tank of 6,250 gallons. For a subsurface irrigation system, from 20 to 60 linear feet of field tile per capita is required, the length depending upon the character of the soil. Dear Sir:

He recommended the erection of an additional barn. No immediate action was taken on this letter owing to the fact that the Department had no funds for the purpose.

"I would like to know how my recommendation for another barn at Kamloops Residential School was received by the School Branch. Normally the stable accommodation at the school is too small to provide a milk supply for a school population of 300. At the present time the school is experiencing great difficulty due to the presence of infectious abortion in the herd of cows. Dear Mr. Ferguson:

On the occasion of the visit to the School of Major McKay, Indian Commissioner, we brought up the question of the need of an auditorium in connection with the School. At that time both you and Major Mackay asked me to send you a detailed report of the whole question and you both promised your whole-hearted cooperation. Owing to circumstances over which I had no control I have been unable to take up this matter till the present time. I am sure you will understand that my delay in writing to you regarding the question of an auditorium is not due to any lack of interest concerning this need at the School.

Among the many reasons which might be given to prove the necessity of an auditorium at this School I shall refer to only one. I feel that one of the reasons why the Indians do not make greater progress in spite of all the sacrifices that are made for their welfare and in spite of all that the Department is doing for them is the fact that they have little ambition and that notwithstanding their racial pride they have little or no confidence in themselves. In the things that really count from the point of view of the Department and the Church, they are struggling against an inferiority complex. This is my personal opinion. Whether right or wrong, I have acted according to this opinion which for me is a certainty and I think I can say that I have obtained results. I have told the children that they can succeed as well as any other children if they only make up their minds to do so and in the few times they appeared in public they fully well proved my contention. On one occasion Mr. T.O. Hill was as well pleased with the performance of the children that he publicly promised, when in Ottawa, to speak of it to the Hon. Mr. Crearar, Minister of Mines & Resources in charge of Indian Affairs. Although the children have done well on every occasion when they appeared before the public they have not really been given a chance to do their best as we have no facilities to train them. Did we have a hall here which the children could use for recreation and in which they could be trained for public performances, to which the public could be invited and in which the children would feel at home, I am sure that we could prove to the public of, at least, this part of the country that the sacrifices that are being made and that the money that is being spent by the Department is not being wasted.

In one of the circulars sent out by Mr. R.A. Hoey, Superintendent of Welfare and Training, he asked for suggestions regarding the manner in which the methods employed could be improved. (of Ottawa: 503-658, May 15, 1937). At that time I made no suggestions as I did not know what the Department would be willing to do. Now, I would like to make this suggestion:
Kindly ask the Department to allow me to put up an Auditorium. I shall be glad if it is put up without extra cost to the Department. I would like you, Mr. Ferguson, to cooperate with me in this matter as you have cooperated with me in the past. I would ask you to supervise this whole undertaking, to see that no money be spent that would endanger the good financial standing which this school has and which is granted to this school by all business men who have dealings with us. I would ask that you see that the building is put up according to the requirements of the Department. As I have been successful in financing the School in the past I am sure that I can accept this extra financial burden without in any way imposing on the children that is by taking from them what is their due in regard to food or clothing. Could the Department see their way to give a more generous grant to the technical school in the way of material and also could they give a contribution towards putting in a new technical class room in a semi-basement under the auditorium? I would be very grateful.

However, I would like you to obtain permission from the Department according to the following specifications. (More or less.)

A frame building 62 by 104 feet at the rear of the school placed close to the boiler with an entrance convenient for both boys and girls.

The height from floor to ceiling 26 ft.
Basket court 46 by 76 ft.
Stage and Dressing Rooms 62 by 14 ft.
Cloak Rooms and Main Entrance 62 by 14 ft.

There would be a Projection Room above the Cloak Rooms for the Moving Picture Machine. There could be a gallery above the Cloak Rooms for seats as well as a seating space of eight feet on each side of the hall. Were the building put up close to the school it could be heated at very little extra cost by having the heating system connected up with the heating instalment of the school.

I have given this matter very careful thought during the past two years and I consulted men of experience who are interested, and I was assured that the cost would not be over $4,000 for the building I had in mind. Were I not sure that I could complete the building I would be willing to be careful and wait till finances would permit to complete the work.

Eventually the building could be brick veneered to correspond with the general outlines of the school building or if the Department agreed it could be finished in stucco.

Were it possible to get this permission very soon, I would be very thankful as I could start the work at once.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith a letter from the Rev. Father Kennedy, C.M.I., Principal of Kamloops Residential School, in which, among other matters, he requests that he be granted permission to erect a suitable auditorium in connection with the school, the cost of construction to be paid for from school funds.

In the past few years the Rev. Principal has certainly brought the children of the school before the public eye in the way of physical training, band playing and drill work, and there is certainly much credit coming to him. The present quarters for this class of training at the school is limited, and he is unable to do justice in his efforts in this aspect. If the Department fails to take cognizance of training, which I think we should do after seeing the splendid progress in this connection at the school, the Rev. Father should certainly have adequate quarters, and in consideration of the proposal that the auditorium will be built without direct cost to the Department, I favour the ideal, and the proposition should be encouraged as much as possible.

One point that enters into the construction of this building as planned is that it is of wooden structure. The proposal is to build it at the rear of the boiler room. This will bring it in between the boys' wing and the Chapel. The question is, how much of a fire hazard this wooden structure would be to the rest of the building. The present wings on both sides, and the boiler house, the nearest parts of the house to the proposed structure are of brick construction, and possibly with the fire protective equipment we have at the school they might withstand serious damage should the proposed building burn up. This is a point that can be decided on by the Department engineers and architects.

The Rev. Father mentions in his letter the possibility of a contribution from the Department towards putting in a technical classroom in the semi-basement under the proposed building. I agree with this as a very good suggestion if the building is gone ahead with. The present

D.M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 8, VANCOUVER, B.C.
quarters of the technical class are inadequate. It is an old, stove-heated, frame building set away some considerable distance from the main buildings. It is too small for the number of pupils who should be in the class at the same time. A new class-room of sufficient size, properly equipped would be of much benefit to the pupil in the teaching of this class of work, which is of so much importance to the progress of the young men after leaving the school, and I would state that this point is worthy of much consideration by the Department.

In regard to the heating of this proposed building, the present boilers at the school are about double the capacity requirement for the heating of the school, and sufficient to heat the new building, and would therefore not tax the present equipment to any extent.

My suggestion in the matter is that if the fire hazard angle does not enter into the proposition to any great degree, we have the Rev. Father prepare a plan of the building proposed.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I wish to thank you most sincerely for your kind letter of the 12th (File 154-0-5.)

I would have written sooner to thank you for the information you gave me that the Department has no objection to my erecting a new auditorium the cost of which will be met from school funds but I waited to be able to send you details regarding the building I wish to put up. I have been unable to get all the details yet. I do not, however, wish to delay any longer in expressing my gratitude to you for this special favour on behalf of the children. They are most enthusiastic.

As soon as I received your letter, I called up a man who was recommended to me as being one of the best contractors in Kamloops. He is now working on the third plan. His first plans were far too elaborate. I find that the cost of a semi-basement would be approximately $2000.00. This extra cost cannot be met out of school funds and I would not feel justified in even suggesting that the Department contribute this amount especially as there is so much other important work to be done such as a new barn, the replacement of the cold storage system and general repair work around the school for the upkeep of the buildings.

I am certain that we can put up a very creditable building with the funds we have. We might save money by hiring a few men and having our boys help but I am afraid that there might be an accident and some of the boys might be hurt and then what we save might might be only at the expense of the solidity of the building. I prefer to give the contract to a reliable man who will assume full responsibility and take every precaution.

When I receive the plans and have had time to study them I shall write again and give you estimates on cost of material which the Department might see fit to contribute for completing the building which work will be done by the boys of the technical school. At the same time I shall have an estimate of cost of paint for the outbuildings and varnish for some of the floors especially for the girls recreation floor. I do not think the cost would be very great and it is very important that the work be done as soon as possible. All this work could be done by the boys and would be a good training for them instead of making little boxes for exhibitions. I am very grateful to you for having suggested in your letter that I do this.
I had not intended writing at such a great length at least this time but I feel I should not close without saying a few words about the school. I am sure you will feel pleased to know that I am confident that this is the best year we have had in the school since my coming here. There is a wonderful spirit among the children. We have had no trouble with them. Their health has been good. Of course with the number of children we have there are bound to be exceptions to all this but they have been few and far between.

Thanking you once more for your kindness, I remain

Yours truly,

Thos. M. Kennedy, O.M.I.
Principal.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: Kamloops School Sewage Disposal

During the construction of the addition and improvements to the septic tank for Kamloops School, I found that at a depth of about 7 feet the soil was much more suitable for the absorption of septic tank effluent than at a depth of 3½ to 4 feet.

The original underground disposal bed was at the shallower depth and it had been planned to enlarge and renew the underground disposal system at about the same average depth. I would suggest that when and if the underground disposal system for septic tank effluent is adopted that the beds be constructed at about 7 feet in depth. I made several tests and found good clean gravel to a depth of 14 feet. As to what greater depth the gravel reached I could not readily determine.

This gravel stratum outcrops on the bank of the South Thompson river but with the disposal beds at a minimum distance of 150 yards or more from the river filtering should be complete. By increasing the trench width and the use of several rows of large tile in one trench, the capacity of the disposal bed area may be kept at the necessary capacity and the cost of installation considerably reduced, probably as much as 25% or 30% from the estimate given in my report of July, 1937, approximately $3750.

Before undertaking the construction of underground disposal beds it would be desirable to observe the results from the present method of effluent disposal, that is surface irrigation of the garden area. The system has only been in operation for about two months and in approximately one month the school population will be considerably reduced until about September 1st. An inspection will be made about the end of September or early in October to see what the results have been both in the operation of the septic tank system and in the disposal of the tank effluent.

(SGD) W.G. Warren.
Vancouver, B.C.,
June 2, 1938.

Dear Sir: Re: Kamloops School Sewage Disposal System.

Certain improvements were made to the sewage disposal plant at the Kamloops Indian Residential School in the past fiscal year and consisted in an addition to the septic tank settling chamber cage as shown in plan accompanying Mr. Warren's report of August 20, 1937, the construction of a sludge pipeline to the site of a proposed garden drying pond, a change in the location of the effluent pipeline and its extension to the garden. This latter is additional to the plan of disposal contained in Mr. Warren's report above referred to and may be considered a temporary measure in substitution of the underground effluent disposal recommended.

The usefulness of this effluent extension to the garden will almost entirely depend on how effectively the garden irrigator will distribute the effluent over the area of the garden below the ditch. It may be that this temporary measure will prove to be satisfactory and no further underground disposal beds required.

The cost of the work done as above referred to, was $2153.70. The sludge drying basin remains to be completed at an estimated cost of $130. I would recommend that provision be made for the construction of this basin within the next year.

We propose to make an inspection of the plant sometime during the present summer to see that it is operating satisfactorily, following which full instructions on the care and operation of the plant concerned will be prepared for the guidance of the school officials.

In connection with this matter I am enclosing, for your reference, a memorandum by Mr. Whitehouse dated June 1st, wherein reference is made to the soil conditions at the school and the possibility that some change may be made in the original proposals re underground beds should this be found necessary.

There is attached hereto a plan of the sewage disposal system for Kamloops Indian Residential School dated May 18, 1938, showing the details of the existing plant.

Dear Sir:

KAMLOOPS INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Kamloops, B.C., July 5, 1938.

Mr. W.J. Ferguson,
Indian Agent,
Kamloops, B.C.

Dear Mr. Ferguson:

When Mr. Hoey, Superintendent of Welfare and Training was here at the School, I spoke to him about getting help from the Department regarding the completing of our new auditorium. He asked me to send in my requisition by writing.

Mr. H.J. Davies, the contractor who put up the main construction gave me a price of $1235.00 to complete the exterior of the building. The Kamloops Plumbing and Heating Co. contracted to put in a satisfactory heating system for $1400. The cost of lumber for completing the interior is $1000.00. This work could be done by the boys in the technical school, and thus save the cost of labour.

In order to complete the building before the cold weather sets in I would ask if it would not be possible for the Department to make a grant of $1000.00. The cost so far has been $3300.00. Did I receive this grant, it would then be more easy for me to get permission from the Church Authorities to spend the balance from school funds in completing the building.

Whether or not it is possible to obtain this grant I would ask for the following consideration from the Department:

During the quarter ending Dec. 1937, we had 4-16 children over the quota. In March quarter 11-66 and during the June quarter 9-64. These children were accepted owing to home conditions being poor and on request of the agents. These children over the quota at $25.00 per quarter per child would mean $1015.00. Could the Department not see their way to granting us this amount or part thereof which could be spent on the Auditorium.

I am sending in a requisition for building material for the Auditorium. This could be given as a grant as material for the technical School, and would all be used up during the year by the pupils and thus enable us to keep this large class busy without the necessity of the school paying out of its grant what had to be paid in the past to keep the technical school open during the year.

Mr. H.J. Davies, gave me a tender of $2200.00 to build a new technical school in connection with the auditorium, of 30 by 50 feet at the same time making provision for four garages. Were this built by the boys of the school, I feel that there would be quite a saving. Were the Department able to give me a grant towards this, with permission to use this grant at the present time on the auditorium, the boys of the technical school could then gradually build the technical school out of school funds and the yearly grant for technical work granted by the Department.
I would also like to get a grant to buy paint for the painting of the outbuildings. This would protect the buildings and would give a very attractive appearance to the layout we now have here. We would need:

To stain the roofs of 13,600 sq.ft. 90 gals.
To paint silo 1,700 " " 8 gals
To paint walls 17,500 " " 45 gals
For trimmings 9 gals.

I am most anxious, as you know, to have the auditorium completed as soon as possible. It will be a very attractive building and complete the appearance of the school itself while being of the greatest help to the children. Anything you can do to obtain assistance will be greatly appreciated by

Yours sincerely,

Thos. M. Kennedy, Per E.M.B.
Principal.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith two letters from the Reverend Principal of Kamloops Residential School, concerning assistance from the Department in connection with the new auditorium, and other matters at the school.

The school request is quite large and I am not prepared to make a recommendation until I have the views of the Department in the matter.

Besides the improvement requested in the enclosed letters there is the question of more stable accommodation for the dairy cattle at the school, and also the erection of a new 16'x24' dairy.

In regard to this new barn, the proposition now is to remodel the floor plan of 38 feet of the north end of the present barn. This would call for the tearing out of the calf and bull pens and the horse stalls, which would be replaced with cow stalls to the number of 20, ten on each side, and with the present 22 stalls, this would give them accommodation for 42 cows, and they would all be in the one building.

To take care of the horses, calves, bulls and sick stock, it is proposed to build a new barn with room for two bull pens, 2 calf pens, 1 maternity pen and 1 pen for miscellaneous stock, and an isolation room 15'x17' for sick stock. This room would be partitioned off from the rest of the barn with a solid wall, with an entrance from outside. The length over all of this barn would be 60', with a width of 24'. The equipment from the old barn, bull pens, calf pen, stalls, etc., could be installed in the new barn, but for the 20 new stalls in the old barn equipment would have to be purchased for these.

I am giving you this rough outline so that you may know what is required at the school when considering the enclosed requests of the Rev. Principal.

In regard to this stable accommodation, I would recommend that this proposal be given consideration, and as much of the work carried out this year as there are funds available for this purpose.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.
The Secretary

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith a requisition for $365.00, for the purpose of the removal of the old floor, and installation of a new floor in the girls' recreation room in the east wing of Kamloops Residential School.

The old floor in this room is badly worn and slivered, and without doubt, should be repaired.

I had Mr. Davies, a local contractor, look over the floor and he has tendered the following price.

Repair with patches and sand whole floor......................$135.00

Remove and lay new floor, 2321 sq. ft. with No. I. Edge-grain Coast Flooring.....................$365.00

The old floor is an edge grain fir floor, and to replace it will take about 3000 feet F.B.M. of floor. The cost of this purchased here from local dealers is $57.00 per F.B.M., or $171.00 for the whole floor, so apparently Mr. Davies has allowed himself $194.00 for the labour, nails, etc.

In my opinion I think his price is high, and I would suggest, so that the work can be done during the holidays, that I be authorized to have the floor installed at a cost not to exceed the amount of my requisition, for $365.00, and upon receipt of this authority I will have the following local contractors tender on the job: John Hodgson & Son, H.J. Davies and F.D. Woodward and D. Salvas, and award the work to the lowest tender.

These names all appear on the approved list which I have in the office here.

Yours faithfully,

(W.G. Ferguson)
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 3rd and 8th inst. in connection with repairs to the Kamloops Indian Residential School, I am enclosing herewith a newly prepared requisition for the material required by the School with the articles properly described as requested.

In regards to the prices on this requisition, they are supplied by Mr. H.J. Davies, contractor, and from inquiries about town from other dealers and contractors, these prices are as low as can be obtained here locally. To expedite the matter, I would recommend that the purchase be made from him.

The cost of the new floor in the Girls' Recreation room, unless some unforeseen cost springs up, will amount to:

| Material | $171.00 |
|----------|---------|
| Labor    | $143.00 |
| Total    | $314.00 |

Mr. F.D. Woodward of this city submitted the lowest tender for the job and he will be doing the work.

In connection with this new floor, it will be very necessary that it be oiled and varnished before the pupils are allowed to use it. In view of this, I am enclosing a requisition in the amount of $60.00 for this, and would ask that I be authorized to proceed with the work without delay.

I have your letter of the 11th inst., and have noted that it will be impossible to incur an expenditure of $626.00 in connection with the painting of several rooms at the school. I might add that the $60.00 for the painting of the new floor was included in this expenditure.

In regards to the fire fighting equipment I have to report that after a survey of this equipment, I found that most of it was in poor condition. The Department may expect quite a heavy expenditure to put things in a save condition. A requisition in this respect will follow next week.

Yours faithfully,

(W.J. Ferguson)
Indian Agent.

Amount of tender ........................................... 928.35

H. J. Davies, Contractor - on preferred list.
No lumber yard. Verbal tender of August 26th ......... 968.35

Carswell Lumber Co. - on preferred list.
Refused to tender on account of financial difficulties ----

The other names on preferred list are Gordon Grant who has no lumber yard and is working full time as trainman for railway. The firm of Kennedy & Woodward is non-existent. The Pondosa Pine Lumber Co. have mill at Westwold, but have no local office and also refused to tender on previous orders.

You will note that all the new written tenders are much lower than Mr. H. J. Davies' verbal tender. After Mr. Davies on the 26th ultimo gave me his prices, I called all the other firms by telephone who have tendered as per this letter and they were all higher in price than he was. Now they have somewhat reduced their prices.

At the present time and during the past week Mr. Davies has been out of town and I have not been able to get a new tender from him. However, he is expected back next week and as soon as he is, I will get a new tender from him if he cares to. I will telegraph the amount to the Department and hence avoid delay.

With these new purchasing regulations, there is some confusion. One time I will send in wholesale prices. This will be referred back for local tenders. These are sent in and in the end the purchase is made in Vancouver or somewhere else.

Memorandum:

Mr. R.A.Hoey,

With reference to your requisition of August 31st, for lumber, etc., required for the Kamloops Indian Residential School, if you will refer to this you will note that the Indian Agent recommended the purchase of materials from H. J. Davies, Contractor, whose prices amounted to $961.70. The Agent further stated that he had made enquiries from other dealers and contractors and that the prices quoted by Davies were as low as could be obtained in Kamloops. We requested you to forward the names of other parties asked to quote and to let us have the original tenders. From the Agent's letter dated the 17th instant it now appears that he had not secured tenders until requested to do so at the later date.

The procedure has been quite irregular. As you will note, the first quotation secured from Mr. Davies was $961.70. The tender reported in the Agent's letter of the 17th instant, from the same man, amounts to $968.35. Again, in the Agent's wire of the 23rd instant, this tender is reported as $910.85. In view of these irregularities it has been decided to call for new tenders from Head Office.

The Indian Agent, W.J.Ferguson, complains that the new regulations have caused him some confusion. It does not appear to me that the Purchasing Regulations should be difficult to understand if trouble were taken to read them carefully.

[Signature]
Departmental Purchasing Agent.
Memorandum:

Mr. C.W. Jackson.

On the 31st August there was submitted to your office by the Indian Affairs a requisition for lumber required for repairs to the Kamloops Indian Residential School (copy enclosed). On this requisition appears the following note:

"The Indian Agent secured the above prices from H.J. Davies, Contractor, Kamloops, B.C. He further states that he made enquiries from other dealers and contractors and that the prices quoted above are as low as can be obtained in Kamloops. The Indian Agent states that the material is needed immediately."

The principle of the purchase was approved by you and passed on to me on September 2nd. Upon receipt of this I enquired of the Indian Affairs what other firms and contractors in Kamloops had been asked to quote and what prices had been submitted. This information was not available in the Indian Affairs Branch and evidently they wired to Mr. Ferguson, Indian Agent, on the 10th, to which he replied by letter on September 17th (copy enclosed). With this letter there were also quotations as follows:

Kamloops Lumber Co., Ltd., $920.85
Inland Building Supplies, Ltd., 898.70
F.D. Woodward, 928.35

On September 23rd I received a copy of a wire from Mr. Ferguson, stating:

"Re building material for school, reference my letter 17th, Davies' tender $910.85."
You will note that the requisition of August 31st gave the quotation of H.J.Davies as $961.70, while the Indian Agent's letter of September 17th gave Mr. Davies' tender price as $968.35. Three different quotations have been offered by Mr.Davies and as yet we have not received any tender from him. Of course, this information may be on record in the Agent's office.

In view of the irregularity in dealing with this tender it was decided that we would call for new tenders. These were invited on the 27th ultimo and are due on October 10th.

From the evidence on file it would appear that tenders had not been invited until after Mr.Ferguson was in receipt of the department's wire of the 10th ultimo; also, that quotations were invited by Mr.Ferguson from two firms not on the preferred list, viz:-

Inland Building Supplies,Ltd.;
Kamloops Lumber Co., Ltd.

[Signature]
Departmental Purchasing Agent.

October 5, 1938.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of the 17th ultimo, marked for the attention of Mr. Hoey, has been forwarded to me for consideration.

I have read the file thoroughly and note all the correspondence which has taken place regarding the purchase of approximately $900.00 worth of lumber for the Kamloops Indian Residential School. I also noted that there were only eight different items on this requisition. If this requisition had been sent in the proper manner by you in the first place, there would not have been any further correspondence in this connection—it would have saved several letters and two or three telegrams.

You have had previous instructions to obtain tenders from those on the approved list, and I might call your attention to the fact that getting prices over the telephone is not a tender. If you had taken the trouble to go to those on the approved list in Kamloops and asked them for a tender in writing and signed by them, and then submitted them with your requisition, the matter would have been dealt with immediately. Instead of that, you go to Mr. H. J. Davis and get a verbal tender from him which was not acceptable by the Purchasing Agent. I note that by taking the steps Mr. Bailey did, the price quoted by Mr. Davis has been reduced from $968.35 to $910.85. Apparently Mr. Davies made still another quotation as in one instance I note he has quoted $961.70.

In view of all these irregularities, it has been decided.....

W. J. Ferguson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
KAMLOOPS, B.C.
decided to call for a new tender from Head Office.

The last three paragraphs of your letter, above referred to, are uncalled for. You will readily understand that the Government of Canada reserves the right to place their business where they may see fit no matter what the opinion of an Indian Agent might be. You have received definite instructions regarding purchases and I fail to see why further instructions should be necessary or would facilitate matters in any way. Personally, I think that the whole matter can be traced back to your office—in your unwillingness to cooperate with the new purchasing regulations.

In due course, I shall expect to receive a reply to this letter.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

General Superintendent
of Agencies.

Memorandum:

Mr. R.A.Hoey.

With reference to your requisition of August 31st, for a quantity of lumber required for the Kamloops Indian Residential School (copy of requisition enclosed), you will note that this requisition stated:

"The Indian Agent secured the above prices from Mr. H.J.Davies, Contractor, Kamloops, B.C. He further states that he made enquiries from other dealers and contractors, and that the prices noted above are as low as can be obtained in Kamloops. The Indian Agent states that the material is needed immediately."

Upon receipt of this requisition I wrote you on September 9th as follows:

"Confirming telephone request of even date to Mr.Phelan, with reference to building material requisitioned for repairs to Kamloops Indian Residential School, your file 154-0-5, will you please arrange to advise me as to what firms and contractors in Kamloops, B.C., were asked to quote by the Indian Agent, and what were the prices they quoted.

"Upon receipt of this information I will arrange to secure delivery at earliest possible date.

"We should have originals of tenders."

Evidently, in turn, you wrote to Mr.Ferguson, Indian Agent at Kamloops, who then secured new tenders (copies enclosed), forwarding the same under cover of his memorandum of September 17th. You will note that of these tenders forwarded by Mr.Ferguson on September 17th two of the firms,
viz: Inland Building Supplies, Ltd., and Kamloops Lumber Company, Ltd., are not on the preferred list. Why did Mr. Ferguson invite these firms to tender? Further, from Mr. Ferguson's memorandum I infer that formal tenders had not been secured by him prior to submitting his requisition of August 31st.

I therefore reported the circumstances to Mr. Jackson and received verbal instructions that, because of irregularities in calling for tenders, it would be necessary to issue a new call. Accordingly, this call was issued on September 27th to the following firms:

R. Carswell & Co., Kamloops, B.C.
Pondosa Pine Lumber Co., "
F. D. Woodward, "
H. J. Davies, "

The tenders were due on October 10th, but only one was received, viz: that of F.D.Woodward (copy enclosed), $943.80, while his earlier tender was $920.80, an increase of $23.00. It is difficult to understand why this tender should have been increased, or to understand the various prices of Mr. H. J. Davies, as reported by Mr. Ferguson.

The above circumstances were reported to Mr. Jackson in detail on October 4th. (Copy of memorandum enclosed.)

The whole transaction has been very unsatisfactory, and I would be very much pleased if you would forward a copy of this correspondence to Major MacKay, at Vancouver, as, possibly, he will be able to secure some satisfactory explanation of the various tenders. If he considers it necessary to call for new tenders we would be obliged if he would do so, and make his submission to Ottawa, together with his recommendation.

Departmental Purchasing Agent.

Memorandum:

Mr. C.W. Jackson,

On the 31st August there was submitted to your office by the Indian Affairs a requisition for lumber required for repairs to the Kamloops Indian Residential School (copy enclosed). On this requisition appears the following note:-

"The Indian Agent secured the above prices from H.J. Davies, Contractor, Kamloops, B.C. He further states that he made enquiries from other dealers and contractors and that the prices quoted above are as low as can be obtained in Kamloops. The Indian Agent states that the material is needed immediately."

The principle of the purchase was approved by you and passed on to me on September 2nd. Upon receipt of this I enquired of the Indian Affairs what other firms and contractors in Kamloops had been asked to quote and what prices had been submitted. This information was not available in the Indian Affairs Branch and evidently they wired to Mr. Ferguson, Indian Agent, on the 10th, to which he replied by letter on September 17th (copy enclosed). With this letter there were also quotations as follows:-

Kamloops Lumber Co., Ltd., $920.85
Inland Building Supplies, Ltd., $928.70
F.D. Woodward, $928.35

On September 23rd I received a copy of a wire from Mr. Ferguson, stating:-

"Re building material for school reference my letter 17th, Davies' tender $910.85."
You will note that the requisition of August 31st gave the quotation of H.J.Davies as $961.70, while the Indian Agent's letter of September 17th gave Mr. Davies' tender price as $968.35. Three different quotations have been offered by Mr. Davies and as yet we have not received any tender from him. Of course, this information may be on record in the Agent's office.

In view of the irregularity in dealing with this tender it was decided that we would call for new tenders. These were invited on the 27th ultimo and are due on October 10th.

From the evidence on file it would appear that tenders had not been invited until after Mr. Ferguson was in receipt of the department's wire of the 10th ultimo; also, that quotations were invited by Mr. Ferguson from two firms not on the preferred list, viz:-

Inland Building Supplies, Ltd.;
Kamloops Lumber Co., Ltd.

My explanation for this extra expenditure is that after the old floor was torn up it was found that the old paper could not be used again. The school was about to open after the summer holidays and with the laundry situated directly beneath this floor, rather than let the floor be laid without some damp-proof insulation, I ordered the extra tar paper for the floor. The floor was laid and completed with oil and varnish for the use of the children by September 15th.

SIR:-

During the course of my recent inspection of the Kamloops Indian Residential School, my attention was drawn to a small out-building, which is being used as a milk-house. In a previous report, I discussed in detail the prevalence of Bang's disease in the herd of cattle supplying milk for the members of the staff and student body of the School.

Enclosed, herewith, you will find a letter from the Departmental Medical Officer at Kamloops, in connection with both subjects.

I am strongly of the opinion that a milk pasteurizing plant should be installed at this School, and also that a new and more modern milk-house should be erected at the earliest possible moment. The shack at present used for the purpose of handling and cooling the milk is most unsuitable and unsanitary.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith a requisition for $291.00 to cover the reconstruction of twelve poles of Transmission line at Kamloops Residential School here.

This line supplies the current which operates the pump used in connection with the irrigation of the agricultural land at the School and is a branch line from the School to the pump. The old line at best was only a makeshift.

The school will require the use of this pump for irrigation purposes by May 1st next, so there should be no delay in having this expenditure authorized.

Dear Major MacKay:

As requested I have read Departmental letter 154-0-5 from Mr R.A.Hoey, dealing with the proposed new barn at the Kamloops Indian Residential School.

With regard to the second paragraph of the above letter, I may say that a sum of $2,500.00 would be, as suggested by Mr Hoey, entirely inadequate to cover the erection of a suitable barn and pay for the material.

I may say that I should be in favour of the erection of a suitable barn by the school authorities on the understanding that its cost not to exceed $5,000.00 be reimbursed by the Department as suggested by Mr. Hoey during the current 1939-40 and 1940-41 fiscal years.

The work would be too heavy for the Annual Training Class at the school, and should in my opinion be carried out by a contractor, approved by the Department, and not by day labour under a foreman.

It is my opinion that a shake roof would be far better than a metal one. I doubt that the accommodation provided in the barn constructed at Sault Ste. Marie, is just what would be required at Kamloops, and I should favour a general design and plan more in keeping with B.C. practice. I doubt that horse stalls would be necessary, but believe that increased space would be needed for calves.

Possibly with the high winds occurring from time to time a lower type of barn would be more suitable and somewhat less expensive. The plans might I believe be drawn by the contractor wishing to erect the building and be subject, together with specifications, to the approval of the Department.

A new Principal will, I understand, be nominated to take charge of the Kamloops Indian Residential School in the very near future.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
Dear Sir:

Re File 154-0-5.

I have to refer to Mr. Hoey's letter of March 23 in the matter of the erection of the new barn at the Kamloops Indian Residential School.

With regard to the third paragraph of the above letter I would approve of the proposal made to finance the construction. This proposal was discussed with Reverend Father Scannell, Provincial of the Oblate Order, during his recent visit to this city and Rev. Father O'Grady, when they called at this office. Father Scannell agreed with the suggested arrangements and did not anticipate there would be any difficulty in having the school provide the additional $2500, which amount would be repaid to the school from the funds provided in the 1940-41 estimates.

The subject has been reviewed at length with Inspector Barry, a copy of whose letter following his consideration of the proposal is attached for your information. I am inclined to agree with the Inspector that it would be best to have the barn built by the school authorities on the understanding that the total cost would not exceed $5000 and that construction be carried out by contract approved by the Department.

I should say that a lower type of barn, with shingle or shake roof, would be best in the Kamloops area because of the high winds which frequently occur there. Nevertheless, it would be as well to send the plan of the Sault Ste. Marie barn along for guidance in drawing up plans for a building that would meet requirements at the Kamloops Indian Residential School. Now that Rev. Father O'Grady has been appointed to the Principalship of the Kamloops School and is to some extent already familiar with the proposal, arrangements could be made by him to have plans of a suitable barn prepared and submit same for examination and consideration of the Department. I should appreciate further instructions in this matter.

Dear Sir:

Your report for the month of May has recently been brought to my attention and it is noted that you refer to the destruction by fire of the hog houses and pens at the Kamloops Indian Residential School.

I have reviewed our files but I cannot find any report that was submitted by you regarding this fire. I feel it is unnecessary for me to state that in the event of fire or any serious happening at any residential school the Indian agent is expected to report fully to the Department immediately following such occurrence. It would therefore be appreciated if you would report fully regarding this fire, stating its cause and any other information that you may have concerning it.

As you have been previously informed, the only amount available in the current year's estimates is $2,500 for the erection of a new barn. Arrangements have already been completed for the construction of a barn costing $5,000.
