Dear Mr. Ferguson:

On May 21, 1939 the Pig Pen on the school property was completely destroyed by fire. It is a building 60'x14' of one storey frame construction. It is situated 850' from the Main Bldg., 75' from the Barn, 60' from the Chicken House.

In the extreme East end of the Pig Pen a Brick and cement Fire box was lighted daily to cook pig feed. It was from this part of the building that the fire was first sighted.

On the morning of May 21st, the fire was lighted at 6 A.M. as usual and since it was Sunday when Mass is held at 7 A.M. the Farm Manager looked in at the fire just before coming over to the Chapel, which was about 6:55 A.M. All was well then. When the sister in charge of the kitchen went down to prepare breakfast at 7:30 A.M. she saw smoke and reported immediately. The Engineer and Farm Manager both rushed to investigate. Fire was coming through the roof just over the fire box in the pig pen.

A length of hose was run from the fire hydrant in front of the barn but since the point of contact was 300' from this hydrant, it was necessary to carry all the hose from the four hydrants around the Main Bldg. and join them all together. This required at least ten minutes and by this time the Pig Pen was completely destroyed. Further it is known that the pressure obtainable from this hydrant at the barn is but 60 lbs. since it is cut in between the Main Reservoir and the Main Pump.

However there was sufficient water to check any further conflagration.

Yours sincerely,

F.O'Grady O.M.I.

Dear Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith requisition covering a proposed expenditure of $828.67 for material to construct new pig pens at Kamloops Indian Residential School to replace the old hog houses and pens destroyed by fire in May last.

It is understood from Rev. F. O'Grady, O.M.I., Principal of the School, that while in Vancouver recently he had an interview with Mr. Philip Phelan who intimated that it may be possible to obtain funds this year for this purpose.

Dear Sir:

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 26th inst., regarding a revised list of articles required for fire protection at Kamloops Indian Residential School, I am enclosing the revised list as requested.

The delay in complying with your request since my telegram of the 26th inst., was due to the sudden death of a local Priest, Father Moriarty, O.M.I., which upset the routine work of the School for a few days.

You will note that to my previous estimate I have added recharges for the old extinguishers in the amount of $46.00. It is over a year since they were attended to, and I understand refills should be installed without delay.

I have also put a note on the estimate regarding some re-arrangement whereby the present water system would afford water for fire protection for the new barn. In this connection, I would suggest that the Water Power Branch have Mr. W.C. MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Wardle.

Re: Sewage Disposal System, Kamloops Indian Residential School.

You will recall that your memorandum of the 11th of May last advised that the Indian Affairs Branch had $100 available for the construction of a sludge drying basin for the above sewage disposal system.

We are now in receipt of a report from Mr. Webb to the effect that this work has been completed, but as this drying basin was to facilitate the clearing of the settling chambers, it has not been put in operation as the necessity of cleaning the chambers has not as yet been evident.

The drying basin consists of a shallow pit 35' by 60' and approximately 3' deep with a roadway approach. This is connected to the settling chamber by an 8" pipeline. To facilitate the distribution of the sludge in the drying basin, a wooden flume attached to the end of the pipeline with suitable apertures was provided the full length of the basin (60'). The basin was enclosed by barbed wire fencing to prevent encroachment of animals.

Mr. Webb reports that on Mr. Warren's last visit to this school late in October, he saw nothing to indicate that the septic tanks were not functioning satisfactorily. The effluent was satisfactory and no solids were passing out of the tanks.

Respectfully submitted,

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,

Dear Sir:

Your File 154-0-5.

I have to refer to your letters of May 4th and October 24th, 1939, with reference to the new barn at the Kamloops Indian Residential School.

The barn has been completed and, from reports received, is exceptionally well-built. The materials used were all carefully examined by the foreman to ensure that both the quality and quantity ordered were supplied. The plan adopted is particularly suitable for the requirements of the School and the design found to be the best in a wind-swept area such as Kamloops. The ground floor division has been painted with white enamel, which is now used almost entirely in large up-to-date dairy barns, permitting of regular washing, and doing away with the necessity of the constant use of lime solution for walls and ceiling. Two prints of the barn are forwarded, which give some indication of the size and design of the building.

The Department agreed to spend $5,000.00 for a new barn - 50% of which was to be paid from the 1939-40 funds, and the School to undertake the payment of the balance, which would be refunded from the 1940-41 appropriation. Vouchers totalling $2,305.07 have already gone forward to the Department and they, in all probability, have been paid, leaving an amount of $2,694.93 due to the School.

It will be observed that the total of the Vouchers enclosed is $2,990.05 but, of this amount the Department will be required to refund, according to arrangements, $2,694.93; the difference of $295.12 representing the amount in excess of the $5,000, which the Department undertook to pay, could very well be met by the School.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

AGENT'S REPORT ON KAMLOOPS AGENCY FOR MARCH 1940.

Kamloops Residential School

Principal complains that the main double cooking range has burnt out and a replacement will be required. Local tinsmith who examined the range claims that it would cost over $200.00 to repair and reline, and then the repairs might not prove satisfactory, so it will be necessary to purchase a new range for the school at a cost of about $400.00.

W. J. Ferguson.
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
May 11, 1940.

Dear Sir:

It has just been brought to the attention of this Branch that in your report for the month of March you referred to the cooking range at the Kamloops Indian Residential School. For your future guidance I would point out that it is undesirable to include such items in your monthly report. They should be the subject of a special letter.

It is noted that you estimate the cost of a new range at $400.00. Please let me have detailed information regarding the type of range required and, if possible, the catalogue number. At the same time you should state if you consider any allowance could be obtained for the old range.

It should be distinctly understood, however, by the Principal that in the event of the Department purchasing the range there will be no further funds available for repairs and improvements at the Kamloops School during the current fiscal year. Our appropriation for the current fiscal year has been drastically reduced and as a consequence when we pay the balance owing in connection with the construction of the barn there will be only sufficient left to purchase the new range.

Consequently when replying to this letter you should state definitely if the Principal understands the situation as outlined above.

Yours truly,

Mr. W. J. Ferguson,
Indian Agent,
Kamloops, B. C.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa,
June 5, 1940.

EXD.

Dear Sir:

In your letter of May 5, 1939, you forwarded a copy of a letter which you had received from Rev. F. O'Grady, Principal of the Kamloops Indian Residential School, in which he stated that he understood definitely that the total amount the Department would allow for a new barn was $5000.00 of which amount $2500.00 would be paid in the fiscal year 1939-40 and the balance provided in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1940-41.

In connection with the barn vouchers to a total amount of $3133.74 were submitted and paid during the fiscal year 1939-40.

I am now in receipt of your voucher No. 4A dated April 20, 1940, requesting a payment of $2990.05. This amount, added to what has already been paid, makes the total cost of this barn approximately $6100.00 which is considerably more than the amount authorized. Before deciding what balance can be allowed I felt it was advisable to ascertain from you why the cost of this barn has so far exceeded the amount originally agreed upon.

Yours truly,

Major D. M. MacKay,

Dear Sir-

Attention Mr. Hoey.

With reference to your letter of the 11th inst., I am enclosing herewith requisition for a Malahat Heavy Duty Steel Range with three ovens, at a cost of $375.00 F.O.B. Kamloops, for Kamloops Indian Residential School. Tenders from McLean, McFeely, Prior, Ltd., and Gordon & Belyea, both of Vancouver, B.C., are also enclosed, along with an illustration of the required range, but showing only two ovens.

This will replace the burnt out Malahat Range at the school, which has had continuous use since 1926, which gives fourteen years service, which is fair, considering the heavy strain of use required from this equipment at the school. The old range has given good service and I would favour replacement being made with the same make of range.

I had Giddens & Son here, local tinsmiths, examine the old range for repairs and they reported that the cost would be excessive, and after being repaired it would still be an old stove.

I might mention that Commissioner Major D.M. MacKay, this Spring, had a second hand three oven range shipped to the School, but the Reverend Principal claims it is too narrow, and the ovens are small. I examined this range today. It is 28 inches wide across the top. The length is alright and the condition is fair, but the Reverend Principal is right in his claim that it is too narrow. The School uses most of the cooking in 10 or 12 gallon aluminum pots and they cannot be passed by one another when on top of the range. They were cooking lunch at the School when I was over and the top was too crowded for satisfactory cooking. Most of the pots and pans were overhanging the top. The ovens were also overcrowded.

The Malahat Range has a width of 36 inches, and an extra width of 8 inches over the three oven range at present in use, and this extra width makes it more convenient for the cooking and handling of utensils in use.

With the range shipped the School by the Commissioner, and if a new one is supplied in accordance with the enclosed requisition, this will make three old ranges at the School for disposal—a two-oven Steamboat range, the old Malahat 3 oven range and the one from the Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.
The old 3-oven Malahat Range is badly burned out in the firebox and around the oven, and is of no further use to the School as a range, but possibly some of the top plates and other parts could be used at some future time in repairs to the new range if the same type, a Malahat is supplied. These parts could be stored by the School, and the rest of the body of the stove dumped, or if a buyer can be found, disposed of as junk.

The Steamboat Range, 2-oven range could be repaired so as to be of use in some camp, logging, etc., and I have advised local stove dealers that it will likely be for sale through the Salvage Branch.

The Commissioner's three oven stove is in fair shape and could also be disposed of to some camp outfit when a new range is supplied.

In the purchase of this new range from a wholesale house, or the manufacturer, I do not think that they would consider any allowance on any of these old ranges, and before a local retail dealer would touch any of these old ranges he would have to have a sale already arranged.

On the requisition you will note that I have included a brass hotwater coil for the range at a cost of $27.15. I understand that ranges are supplied without coils, so that in making the purchase a coil, either brass or iron should be included. The cost of the iron one is $11.90. The School has requested a brass coil, but I will leave this for the Department to decide.

As advised, I have pointed out to the Reverend Principal that in the event of the Department purchasing this range, there will be no further funds available for repairs and improvements at the School during the current fiscal year. He distinctly understands the situation in making his request for the new range.

A copy of this letter is being forwarded to the Commissioner, Major D.M. MacKay.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I should like to acknowledge, with sincere thanks, your air mail letter of May 20th, which I received the day before our Golden Jubilee celebration. I appreciated it more than words can tell. Your unfailing interest in our work of the Residential Schools has always been a source of great encouragement to us. I was very glad to thank the Department publicly on the occasion of the Jubilee for the great work it has done in forwarding the cause of Indian education at this Institution.

The Jubilee celebration was all that we could have wished for. We had a large gathering of Indian and white people and the former were very orderly indeed. The weather was exceptionally fine for the outdoor ceremonies. All were amazed at the ability of the children during the concert and the Indian parents were very proud of them. Under separate cover I am sending you copies of the "Kamloops Sentinel" the editor of which attended the concert and made his own report.

There are several matters of business that come to mind especially at this time of the year when the estimates are going through Parliament and I hope you will not mind my mentioning them in this letter. I understand the difficult position in which the Department finds itself this year because of the war and the stringent measures it must take to reduce expenses. I have already received the circular of Mr. McGill announcing a reduction in the per capita grant to $2.24, which means that this School will receive $3759.72 less each year. The transportation allowance has been cut in half and Mr. Hoey stated in a letter to Mr. Ferguson that after paying the balance due on the barn and purchasing a new kitchen range the Department would probably not be able to do any more for this School this year.

Notwithstanding the necessary reductions to be made I feel that the School should not remain at a standstill; there are some things needed very urgently. During the past year I
have gone to considerable pains and expense to keep the buildings in a state of good repair. I have painted the boys' recreation, shoe and wash rooms, sanded the floors and painted the offices in the administration section, extended and purchased paint for the new piggery, installed a new fruit cooker to handle half of a ton of fruit in 30 minutes, put out a new orchard and insulated and lined the auditorium with hemlock flooring. These are some of the main improvements which have been done out of the School grant. But there are others which are very necessary and which I feel I cannot finance. We should have fire protection for the new barn and piggery to the amount of $582.66 and a new frigidaire costing $750.00.

There is another improvement needed very badly at this School and which has been requested for several years but which the Department has not been able to grant and it is a new technical shop and dairy. The present technical shop is altogether too small and unsuitable, has no equipment in the way of power tools and machinery, and soon will need a new floor. The dairy is only a small outbuilding and very unsanitary.

Although the Department has been very good to us in the past I would not presume on its generosity to grant us the two buildings in question this year. But I have a proposition to offer. I am prepared to construct a new technical shop and dairy this year and equip both, provided the Department would re-imburse us next year in the same manner as it is doing this year for the new barn. The total cost would not exceed $2500.00. I discussed the matter with Very Rev. Father Scannell on his visit here and he sanctioned it. I should like to be free in the purchase of materials as I know where I can purchase lumber at a greatly reduced price, which will be necessary in order to construct the buildings at the above cost, labor included. I will be responsible for good workmanship and can assure the Department that the buildings will be well in keeping with the other fine buildings at this Institution.

I would appreciate an early decision of the Department in this matter as I would like to prepare the materials for the Manual Training class when School re-opens. The boys did splendid work on the new piggery and I feel they will do even better work on their new technical shop.

With very kind regards,

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I should like to obtain the permission of the Department to retain only one pupil in School this year who has reached the age limit for discharge—No. O-557 Julia Bob of the Fountain Reserve. The reason is that she was admitted in 1936 and, therefore, has had only four years in School. She is very anxious to return for one more year to learn all she can. She profits very well by her time in School and I would recommend her being allowed to return for another year.

With reference to the estimates for 1941-1942 I should like to remark that the items listed are absolutely necessary. I discussed each one in detail with Commissioner Major Mackay and Indian Agent Ferguson and both agreed all were essential. Many other repairs, which are urgent but not so important, were eliminated from the list as it was thought the Department would be short of funds this year. I am, however, under separate cover, enclosing a proposed layout of the School grounds, which need levelling very badly. It is a work which is as important as the erection of a building. As you know the grounds immediately surrounding the School are very uneven, very dusty and unsuitable for a play field. Because of the intense heat and lack of moisture in this area nothing will grow without irrigation. But it is impossible to irrigate the grounds properly as they are not level. I had a survey taken to find out how much earth had to be moved to bring the grounds to a proper level. There are 18815 cu. yds. to be moved a distance of approximately 450 ft. The estimated cost, because of the distance, is 20¢ per cu. yd., which would make a total amount of $3763.00. I should be very glad if the Department could help us as the need for a proper playground has always been felt at this School. After the grounds have been levelled an irrigation line and sprinkling system should be installed to the amount of $700.00. And there is the interior redecorating of the main building estimated at $1437.25 which has been eliminated from the estimates this year.

In the estimates submitted through the Indian Office last month we are asking the Department to consider favorably the erection of a technical building to cost $2000.00 and a dairy costing $500.00. As a special request I should like to obtain authority for these two items this month, if possible. We need the buildings very urgently and this is the best time of the year for their construction. Work could begin immediately.
and the two buildings would be completed before winter. The present dairy in particular is very unsanitary and is a danger to the spread of germs especially throughout the winter months when it is more difficult to keep it clean. And the technical building is in a poor state of repair, is much too small as it also includes a shoe repairing shop, and is very cold in winter.

I feel at times that the Department might consider the above requests exorbitant coming at a time when funds are so badly needed for other purposes but I do hope it will accede to the most important ones. I am keenly interested in the progress of this the Department's largest Residential School, which has been so well built up and taken care of in the past and I will be very grateful for any favors that might be forthcoming.

Yours very sincerely,

F. O'Grady O.M.I.
Principal.

Dear Mr. Ferguson:

Although estimates for the most important improvements and repairs needed at this School during the coming year have already been forwarded to your Office there are others, which are very necessary and which also I should like you to submit to the Department.

The need for a proper play ground has always been felt at this Institution. The grounds immediately surrounding the School are very dusty and uneven and altogether unsuitable for the recreation needs of the children. They should be properly levelled and irrigated and some kind of grass sown to keep down the dust. According to a survey there are 18815 cu. yds. of clay to be moved approximately 450 ft. The cost, because of the distance, is estimated at 20¢ per cu. yd., making a total of $3765.00. After the grounds have been levelled 900 ft. of flume should be installed for irrigation. The cost is 50¢ per ft. making a total of $450.00. And a sprinkling system, estimated at $250.00, is needed in front of the School.

For several years estimates for the interior re-decorating of the main School building have been submitted to the amount of $1437.25 but so far none of this has been granted. Some parts of the building are very badly in need of repair and I would ask that this amount be allotted for that purpose this year.

I would kindly ask you to forward these requests to the Department at your earliest convenience.

Yours very truly,

F. O'Grady O.M.I.
Principal.

Dear Sir:

Please find enclosed herewith a supplementary estimate for the year 1941-42, in connection with the Kamloops Indian Residential School, in the amount of $5500.00. I am also enclosing a letter from the Rev. Principal, Father O'Grady, C.M.I., in which the request in this regard is made.

You will recall that during your visit here in August last, we discussed the estimates for the next fiscal year with the Rev. Principal, and arrived at the decision that certain items only should be included, and in order of importance. It was on the basis of this discussion that I prepared the 1941-42 estimates for the School last August, feeling at the time that the School was sufficiently provided for. In this regard, also, at the time no mention was made by the Rev. Principal of the Department's being expected to pay anything towards the costs of the levelling of the recreation grounds. As you are aware, the School has already gone ahead with this work on their own. While this work was discussed by the Principal and myself at different times, the work was in no way authorized by this office.

Recreation Grounds: As already mentioned, the School has gone ahead with this work and up to date have moved some 2000 cubic yards of dirt and gravel. In connection with this levelling programme, under a survey of the work carried out by the Provincial Public Works for the School, the amount of gravel and dirt to be moved amounts to a total of 16,815 cubic yards. As 2000 cubic yards have been moved by the School it leaves as per this estimate, 16,815 cubic yards.

While this work when completed will greatly improve the grounds at the school in every way, I am of the opinion that the programme is too extensive at this time when funds should be conserved. It is possible, though that the work could be modified and nearly equal results obtained, and before the Department makes any expenditure in this connection I would suggest that the Water Bureau engineers be requested to make a survey and a report. In the meantime, if at all possible at this late date, provision could be made in the estimates for an expenditure of $1500.00 to cover the moving of the gravel and dirt and the required irrigation works.

D.M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
P.O. Box 70, VANCOUVER, B.C.
Dear Sir:

I beg to forward herewith supplementary estimates received from Mr. Indian Agent Ferguson covering improvements to the recreation grounds and repairs to buildings of the Kamloops Indian Residential School, together with a covering letter from Rev. Father O'Grady.

With reference to the former item, extensive changes to the grounds surrounding the school were commenced this year by the Rev. Principal. During a short visit to the school in August, the proposed scheme was explained to me and I looked over the work done up to that time. I advised Father O'Grady that in my opinion it was work on which engineering advice and supervision were required and that in any case it was extremely doubtful if the Department could assist in any such scheme under the conditions facing the country.

The project involves the removal of considerable quantities of earth and gravel, road work, extensive levelling operations, flume construction and the installation of a sprinkling system. My own opinion is that changes of an important character should not be undertaken at any of our schools without Departmental authority, and I should like to suggest that instructions be issued accordingly. In this particular case, the whole scheme should have been investigated and reported on by engineers of the Dominion Water and Power Bureau before any work was undertaken.

Regarding item 2, an amount of $1437 was included in the 1940-41 estimates to cover the redecoration of the interior of the building, and if nothing can be done this fiscal year in this connection, provision should be made, if possible, to take care of some of the work in 1941-42.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Because of the increase in the price of lump coal I am finding the fuel costs, this year, excessive. I should, therefore, like to obtain permission from the Department to install mechanical stokers in the heating and laundry boilers, kitchen range and domestic hot water heater.

These stokers would installed at no cost to the Department; payment for them would be made mostly out of the savings of fuel. Apart from lower fuel costs a uniform temperature could be maintained throughout the School building, especially in the class rooms, which would be a great benefit to the children in the winter months.

I should appreciate an early reply from the Department as the price of stokers may be advancing very soon.

Yours very sincerely,

F. O'Grady O.M.I.
Principal.
Dear Mr. Phelan:

Along with the enclosed official letter asking the permission of the Department to install stokers I am writing these few lines to explain the situation more fully. The cost of lump coal is $11.06 F.O.B. Kamloops in car load lots and we burn nearly a ton a day by hand firing. Stoker coal is about $3.00 a ton cheaper and we would burn less of it. Our fuel costs would be reduced about 30%. I gave the matter very careful consideration and figured over a period of about two years and a half we could pay for the stokers mostly out of the savings in fuel. The stokers could, therefore, be installed without any cost to the Department. With this plan in mind I placed the order for the stokers but after doing so it occurred to me that I should formally ask permission from the Department to install them even at our own expense. I was told that Father Kennedy had obtained the permission several years ago and I thought it would be on file but I cannot find it. The stokers are not installed as yet but delivery will be made in a few days. If I could, therefore, obtain the permission from the Department next week I would be very grateful.

I had been thinking about writing you for some time about the estimates for next year but I knew you would do all you could to obtain for us what we need most. I am very thankful for what you obtained for us this year and for having the dairy authorized out of the current year's appropriation; we are proceeding with it now as the frost is pretty well out of the ground. For this coming year I am hoping you will be able to have the new technical building authorized. I understand funds may be very limited but we really need a new building to give the boys proper manual training. Anything that you can do to obtain the building for us this year will be very greatly appreciated. --- As soon as the estimates have been passed I would be glad to know what amount has been allotted to us this year---.

If you should happen to be coming West this summer be sure to come this way and spend a few days with us. If you enjoy fishing there are great opportunities here to have a pleasant holiday; yourself and Mrs. Phelan could have a fine time.

With kindest regards and best wishes,

Sincerely,

F. O'Grady

Kamloops, B.C., March 7th, 1941.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

An urgent repair problem has arisen in connection with the irrigation pipe line, which we have dug up recently and found to be beyond repair. The matter was brought to the attention of Mr. Indian Agent Ferguson, who obtained quotations on similar pipe from firms in Vancouver. The amount required is 512 ft. and the price per foot is $1.10 making a total of $563.20. Major McKay, the Indian Commissioner for B.C., on a recent visit, took note of the matter. I understand he will bring it to the attention of the Department in Ottawa within a few days. Should the Department find it impossible to meet this expenditure at this late date in the fiscal year I will be forced to make payment from the School funds as the pipe is absolutely necessary for irrigation, which will commence within a month. In that case I trust the Department will be able to re-imburse the School from the appropriation of the coming fiscal year.

With reference to the construction of a proposed technical School, for which estimates have already been submitted, should the Department, because of other needed repairs at this Institution, be able to appropriate only half of the amount required i.e. $1000 I would be willing to supply materials and labor to the amount of $1000, thus completing the structure, provided the Department could re-imburse us from the appropriation of the fiscal year 1942-1943.

I should like to be informed, at your very earliest convenience, what amount in the estimates we have been allowed for the fiscal year beginning April 1st. next. I can secure labor in April but beyond that time it may be scarce and materials are steadily rising in price.

Thanking you for your assistance in the past I remain,

Yours very sincerely,

F. O'Grady O.M.I.
Principal.
Ottawa,
March 20, 1941.

AIR MAIL

Dear Father O'Grady:

With reference to your letter of the 7th instant Indian Commissioner MacKay's office is being authorized to purchase the irrigation pipe required at the Kamloops Indian Residential School. It is noted that the total cost of this pipe will be $343.20.

With reference to your previous request for construction of a new technical school I regret that in view of present conditions it was not found possible to include this item in our appropriation for the coming fiscal year. $125.00 for painting, $700.00 for retubing boilers and $750.00 for a refrigerator plant is the total amount that will be available for repairs and improvements and new equipment at the Kamloops Residential School during the fiscal year 1941-42. This amount may seem small but you can realize the very great difficulties under which we are working at present.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Kamloops, B.C., March 22nd, 1941.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I have today received your letter of the 20th instant and wish to thank you sincerely for the appropriation to the amount of $345.20 allowed by the Department for the purchase of the irrigation pipe and also for the grants of $125.00 for painting, $700.00 for retubing boilers and $750.00 for a refrigerator plant. I can assure you these grants are very much appreciated.

Whilst I was disappointed that the Department was forced to omit the construction of a new technical school from the list of items in the appropriation for the coming fiscal year I can quite readily understand the omission due to present war conditions. However I am hoping that we will be able to do something ourselves towards the construction of the building. During the past year I was able to purchase a quantity of good lumber at a very reduced price from a mill that went bankrupt. I should like to obtain the permission of the Department to proceed with the construction of the technical school, using this lumber and completing the frame-work and exterior of the building and leaving the finishing of the interior for next year. Probably at that time the Department would be able to supply us with the balance of the materials needed. If the main part of the building were thus constructed it could be used and would give ample room for the proper conducting of the manual training classes.

I should like also to obtain permission from the Department to construct a small frame house for the use of our farm instructor who married recently and is obliged to reside in the city of Kamloops. The distance of the School from the city makes it difficult for him to carry on his duties which continue from early morning until late in the evening.

The implement shed is in a very poor state of repair and is in danger of being destroyed by the wind. With the Department's permission I would move it to a more convenient

Dear Sir:

Re Kamloops Indian Residential School

I have been advised by Reverend Father O'Grady that it is understood that funds are available to provide a new refrigeration unit for the marginally noted school.

Following receipt of this information, I secured from McLennan, McFeely & Prior Limited costs on a single room unit having a compressor of sufficient capacity to handle a second room when funds could be provided for such an addition. The quotation received from this firm indicates that the costs of a suitable unit, excluding materials and labor for preparing the existing room for refrigeration purposes, would be $720.90. It would appear, therefore, that the total amount required would be approximately $850.

I may say that the refrigeration units installed by this Company in our schools and at the Coqualeetza Indian Hospital have been very satisfactory.

I should appreciate being advised of the Department's decision with respect to the proposed installation.

Dear Sir:

Dear Major MacKay:

Within the last few days several local contractors have made surveys of the location of the proposed refrigeration plant according to plans submitted by the Department. In studying the plans with them I find that, because of a rear entrance to the refrigerator the plant must be located in the centre of the room thus using most of the space which we need for the instruction of the girls in baking. If the plans cannot readily be changed and if the contract for the refrigeration plant is to be given soon I would be willing to accept the responsibility for the alterations mentioned above at no extra cost to the Department.

# Work to be done by James M. Wilson, Kamloops.
Dear Sir:

I have to refer to Departmental letter of January 22nd, 1942 file 154-0-5 and previous correspondence regarding the proposed Refrigeration Unit for the Kamloops Indian Residential School.

In this connection I beg to forward herewith tenders received from five of the seven firms from whom quotations were requested. A summary of the tenders submitted is also enclosed.

You will observe that Hall and Young of Kamloops have submitted two tenders, one for $1799.20 which covers the installation required as per Departmental specifications and the other costing $1665.20 on a somewhat modified plan.

In discussing the proposed installation with the Rev. Principal a few days ago he explained that he was not in favor of the plan submitted by the Surveys and Engineering Branch as it would deprive the school of much needed space and suggested as an alternative that the Refrigeration Room be placed in the corner of the existing space, as indicated on the attached sketch. As far as I can determine I cannot see any objection to the Principal's proposal.

Father O'Grady is of the opinion that the somewhat elaborate alterations suggested by the Engineering Division are not necessary and, after a personal examination of the space, I am inclined to agree with him.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.Ont.
I may say that I explained to the Principal that, in view of the high cost of the installation proposed by the Engineering Division, that it was doubtful if funds could be provided for the purpose this fiscal year. Father O'Grady pointed out, however, that the school will be in urgent need of such service once the warm weather sets in, as the existing ammonia plant has broken down and could not be put in serviceable condition without a large expenditure and, rather than be placed in such a position, he would be prepared to undertake the alterations required and the construction of the Refrigerator Room under the alternative plan if the Department would approve of the purchase of the Frigidaire Unit from Messrs McLennan, McFeely & Prior, Ltd., at $934.00 and allow the sum of $416.00 for the materials required. The expenditure involved under such an arrangement would be $1350.00 as against $1665.20 the lowest tender submitted.

The firm of McLennan, McFeely & Prior Ltd., has carried out a number of similar installations for our Department in recent years all of which have been highly satisfactory. It is considered, therefore, that the Department would be on safe ground in placing the order for the Unit required for the Kamloops school with this firm. The alterations required and the construction of the Refrigerator Room could be carried out by the school if an amount of $416.00 could be provided for the materials.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re: Refrigeration Plant, Indian Residential School, Kamloops.

With further reference to my memorandum of January 3rd last, I am enclosing for your information copy of a memorandum from the Chief Engineer, dated February 26th which is self-explanatory, together with copies of the correspondence, blueprints and sketch, etc., referred to therein and also with a file 154-0-5, Volume 10, and the tenders submitted for this plant.

It would appear that while the plan prepared by our Engineering and Construction Service and submitted with my memorandum of January 3rd, was in accordance with the suggestions which had been advanced and the information furnished, it is now evident from later correspondence that this information regarding the area concerned was not correct in some respects and that consequently that plan would not indicate the best location for the refrigerating plant.

Your attention is particularly drawn to the opinion expressed and the recommendations made in the third paragraph of the third page of Mr. Mills' memorandum in which we concur.

Director.
Ottawa,
March 4, 1942.

Memorandum:

ACTING DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

I desire to refer to our requisition of September 30, 1941, and your memorandum of October 7, 1941, with reference to refrigeration equipment for the Kamloops Indian Residential School. As requested in the last paragraph of your memorandum, the Surveys & Engineering Branch were requested to provide a specification on which tenders could be called. They submitted specifications and blueprint copies of a suggested plan for a refrigeration unit on January 3, 1942, and these were immediately forwarded to Indian Commissioner MacKay together with the names of the firms mentioned in your memorandum of October 7.

Commissioner MacKay replied in a letter dated February 16, 1942, copy of which is enclosed. His letter and the tenders were then forwarded to the Surveys & Engineering Branch and I enclose, for your information, a copy of their reply dated the 2nd instant which reached our office this morning.

As you are aware, the Kamloops Indian Residential School is our largest residential school and, as they have no refrigeration plant, I believe that the installation of one is extremely necessary. You will note that the Director of the Surveys & Engineering Branch recommends acceptance of the suggestion made in paragraph 3 of page 3 of Mr. Mills' memorandum. Funds for the purchase are available in the current year's appropriation and I should appreciate
your giving the matter immediate consideration in order that the necessary authority may be given for the expenditure so that the work may proceed and the account may be paid before the end of the current month.

Director.

Kamloops, B.C., April 22nd, 1942.

Mr. J. D. Caldwell,
Acting Indian Agent,
Kamloops, B.C.

Dear Mr. Caldwell:

In the Estimates for 1942-1943 application was made to the Department, through your office, for a new ironer for the school laundry as follows:

"New double roller ironer for laundry to replace single ironer, serial No.3111, Model M711r, steam pressure 100 lbs, made by the Canadian Laundry Co. Toronto, Ont. The capacity of this old ironer too small for this School and if new one purchased it possibly could be made use of in one of the other schools or hospitals.......$2000.

Should the Department find it impossible, due to war conditions, to purchase a new ironer to the amount of $2000 I feel that a used machine, at much less cost, would satisfy our needs. I recently located a used 48" 4 roll steam laundry ironer at the Main Machinery & Metal Co. 943 Main St., Vancouver, B.C., priced at $300.00. I have had the machine examined and it has been found to be in good condition. Although a wider machine would be more desirable yet having four rolls the ironer should dry the clothes in the one operation whereas with the machine we are using at present we are obliged to pass each article through four times before it becomes thoroughly dry.

As the ironer in question is for immediate sale, I would appreciate the Department considering the purchase of it in the near future.

Yours very truly,

sgd. F. O'Grady, O.M.I.
Principal

DISCUSSION WITH DR. MC QUARRIE - KAMLOOPS SCHOOL

There is a tendency here to have requests made for glasses which in most cases are not necessary. On one occasion a travelling optician examined the children and recommended that twelve children should have glasses. Dr. J.J. Wall later checked these cases and cut it down to two. Dr. McQuarrie states there is no Infirmary at the school and segregation is impossible in the event of an epidemic.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Taylor's letter of the 14th instant forwarding requisition by the Kamloops Indian Residential School to expend $1,134.50 for the installation of a water supply for fire fighting purposes for the protection of the new school barns. At the time this letter was received, the Reverend Principal of the School called at this office and it was pointed out to him that the total amount available for this school for this year would be $1,600.00. Consequently, he expressed the opinion that the cost of the work would either have to be reduced considerably or held over. He made enquiries in Vancouver and found that he could purchase some 4 inch pipe for an amount considerably less than was quoted on in his requisition, copies of these quotations being enclosed herewith together with those accompanying the original requisition.

I have no knowledge of the suitability of the pipe quoted on, and there would be insufficient by 122 feet for the purpose required. It would, therefore, be necessary to purchase additional pipe and it is doubtful whether this would be the same type of pipe, which involves considerable doubt as to the type of fittings required and whether the hydrants would be similar to the pipe.

Under the circumstances, I would suggest that the matter be referred to the Dominion Water and Power Bureau for investigation by their engineer when he is in the locality. We could then arrange to purchase as much material as funds could be provided for during the present year, and carry over any balance until the following fiscal year.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th instant, enclosing request from the Kamloops Residential School to expend an amount of $1184.50 for the installation of a water supply for fire fighting purposes to protect the new school barns.

This request has received very careful consideration and the Department is not completely satisfied that we would be justified in expending such a large amount of money at the present time for the purpose mentioned. Is the fire hazard in regard to these barns so great that such an expenditure is advisable? Is there any definite assurance that even if the installation requested by the Kamloops School were made there would be adequate fire protection for the barns? In addition to carrying out this work it would be necessary to use material that is in great demand for purposes which are probably much more urgent than the one under consideration.

In view of the above the Department is not prepared to proceed further with this matter at the present time. If there are no more pressing demands for repairs or equipment at the Kamloops School than the one above mentioned, the Department does not see any reason for expending the funds provided in the current year's appropriation.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:-

Replying to your letter of the Ist.instr.re a requisition for 200 feet of cotton fire hose for the Kamloops Indian Residential School,I beg to advise as follows:-

This hose was for use in the interior of the main School buildings,and had no relation to the iron pipe for protection of outbuildings.

With Mr.W.C.Warren I inspected the protection facilities for barns and outbuildings,last month,and it was considered that the buildings now without adequate protection could be served by utilising the 200' of hose now housed in 50' lengths in four separate shelters outside the main school building.

I have suggested to the Principal that the boys should be organised for fire fighting purposes,and that in the event of the more distant buildings being fired,the existing hose could be run to the nearest hydrant by the older barn;this would enable a stream of water to be thrown far enough.

In view of this alternative protection,the matter of the iron pipe can be left in abeyance until times are more suitable.Perhaps it will thus be possible to obtain the flush toilets requisitioned for later.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed herewith Requisition dated July 14th, received from Mr. Indian Agent Taylor together with his letter of the same date for 200 feet of 2½" fire hose.

On receipt of this application various hardware stores were requested to furnish tenders and I was advised by each of them that they were unable to quote as it was, at that time, unobtainable.

As I did not hear from him I wrote him again on the 1st instant and enclose herewith his reply of the 2nd, in which he states that the hose is required for the interior of the main school building, whereupon, further inquiries were made and the only firm able to quote on the same is Gordon & Belyea Limited, setting out the total price of the hose at $138.00, less the fittings. As these are unobtainable and it will be necessary for the school to send down the nozzles and couplings on the old hose for attachment to the new hose, if same is authorized, as this requires the use of special machinery, the cost of the fittings will be additional to the price of the hose. I have no information as to the cost of this work but anticipate that it will be a very nominal amount.

It is contemplated that a supply of this new hose will also afford some degree of protection to the outbuildings which has been a matter of discussion in the past summer.

If funds are available I would recommend approval of the application.

Sir: Re: Kamloops Indian School Fire Protection

In connection with your recent request for a report on extension of fire protection service to out buildings at Kamloops Indian School the following is a report in that connection.

FIRE PROTECTION SERVICE

The attached plan shows the layout of Kamloops school and outbuildings, also pipe lines, pump house and fire hydrants. At the time the school was built and fire protection service installed, in 1927, service was adequate, as there were only a few outbuildings in addition to the main school building at that time. Since then a number of outbuildings have been erected at some distance from the installed fire service outlets, the greatest distance from a hydrant being now 700 feet.

Fire protection service consists of five double outlet standard fire hydrants, four of which are housed and provided with 100 feet of rubber lined fire hose and nozzle, the fifth has no housing or equipment.

Water for all services is supplied by an elevated tank under a normal pressure of about 45 pounds. The tank is supplied by pumping from the South Thompson river, pump capacity is 500 gallons per minute against 90 pounds pressure. The pipelines are so valved that in event of a fire the tank pipeline may be closed off, permitting water to be pumped to the fire hydrants close to the main building, thus providing water for fire fighting purposes at the maximum pump pressure of 90 pounds.
NEED FOR EXTENSION OF FIRE SERVICE

There would appear to be some need for making the fire service available to all buildings of any value which may reasonably be served from the existing facilities. Outbuildings are all of frame construction and have an approximate value of $25,000. Some of these, the two barns, are quite large buildings and are about thirty-five to forty feet in height.

SUGGESTED FIRE SERVICE EXTENSION

It is suggested that extension of fire protection to new buildings may be best afforded by providing 200 feet additional hose and moving one hydrant to a position on the pipeline better suited to existing conditions.

With 200 feet new hose in addition to the 400 feet already on hand, sufficient could be assembled for two fire streams to be used on the larger buildings and one stream on more distant small buildings.

By the installation of a gate valve in the main pipeline, full use could be made of the pump to all fire service outlets, resulting in much better fire pressure on long hose lines.
COST

The cost of the suggested additions and alterations is estimated at $419.00. Material required is:

200' mill yard cotton rubber lined 2½" hose with couplings (City of Kamloops Hose thread) $180.00

1 Underwriters' play pipe 14.00
1 8" x 8" x 4" Tee flanged F.& D. 17.50
1 4" blind flange F.& D. 3.00
1 8" std. hub end gate valve with wheel 54.00
1 8" C.I. std. flange to 8" socket 14.00
1 8" std. wrot pipe 3' long flange 1 end 15.00
2 8" full face gaskets 1.20
1 4" " " " .30
16 3/4" x 3 1/4" Mch. bolts 2.40
8 5/8" x 2 3/4" Mch. bolts .80
1 2½" std. hose gate valve 22.50
30# lead and 5 lbs. yarn 3.00
1 valve box (materials only) 6.00

$333.70

LABOUR

Moving hydrant and re-installing valve and valve box installation 60.00
Moving building for hydrant shelter and remodelling. 25.00

$ 85.00

ADDITIONAL WORK

During the course of my visit at Kamloops School, I noted that the roofs of fire hydrant shelters were all in very bad condition, much of the original roofing having disappeared. This should be renewed in order to protect equipment stored in the shelters - cost of this should not exceed $50.00 for a good quality
roof on all four.

It is suggested that the attention of the school authorities should be drawn to the necessity of taking the greatest care possible of fire hose in order to insure its availability in good condition when required for fire protection, also that the use of fire hose for purposes other than for which it is intended should be discouraged.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir: Re Indian Residential School, Kamloops, B.C.

In answer to Mr. D.M. MacKay's letter, dated Oct. 17th, 1942 regarding the Indian Residential School at Kamloops, B.C., I will answer the third paragraph first - standard black pipe and black malleable fittings are all that will be required.

Now in regard to the vertical boiler - up to 1936 the laundry was operated with a vertical tubular boiler No. 43794, rated at 9 H.P. At that time the laundry was enlarged and more machines installed. The old boiler was taken out and the present vertical boiler installed. This boiler is rated at 19 H.P. This gave complete satisfaction for a short time, but when other changes were made, the boiler required forcing. A stoker was installed and the boiler further forced. Naturally when you begin to force a boiler up to and over its capacity it means a greater consumption of coal, particularly in a vertical boiler, where the efficiency of this type of boiler is very low.

In my report to Major D.M. MacKay, dated September 14th, I recommended that the boiler be retubed and am still of the same opinion and the school operate the laundry machinery in accordance with the steam capacity. This arrangement could be carried out during the duration of the present war and I understand that owing to the steel situation it will be impossible to have a boiler manufactured unless it is to be used for essential war purposes.

Again, the steam requirements of this laundry are, according to the Rev. Principal's statements, increasing so rapidly that the boiler capacity now required is nearly four times as much as in 1935.

I would suggest that a proper survey be made of the probable future steam requirements so that when a new boiler is installed, one large enough to take any possible increase in steam load be provided.

Even if the present boiler is discarded I do not know of any school, except possibly Christie, that will require a new boiler as all the other schools have new laundry boilers and they are giving every satisfaction.

I expect to be in Vancouver on Monday, October 26th, on my return from Alert Bay and will meet Major D.M. MacKay and discuss the whole situation with him.

I remain,

Yours respectfully,

T.J. Arnall
S.F.S. Engineer.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ontario.

The Principal of the Kamloops Indian Residential School has taken up with this Office and also with the local Agent, Mr. H. E. Taylor, the question of lowering the intake of the pumping unit in the South Thompson river, in order to increase the supply of water for irrigation for lands of the School.

The records indicate that the well for the pumping unit was built some years ago by Reverend Father McGuire, the Principal of the School at the time. The well was not placed at a sufficient depth to allow pumping throughout the entire irrigation season, with the result that, in years when water was low in the river, the supply available for irrigation was correspondingly decreased.

Just recently Mr. W. C. Warren of the Surveys and Engineering Branch made an inspection of the pumping system and submitted a report dated December 7th, 1942, a copy of which no doubt will have been received by the Department. It will be observed from Mr. Warren's report that, in order to overcome the existing difficulties, it will be necessary to lower the intake culvert two feet and the intake well three feet. An extension of about forty feet of pipeline to the intake culvert would also be necessary. The estimated cost of the improvements required is $785.00.

No provision was made in the current year's Estimates, or those of 1943-44, to provide for the expenditure involved. The amount, however, might be made available from the Irrigation Division of the B. C. Special Vote from balances remaining from projects to be undertaken through the Commissioner's Office, Division 1, provided, of course, it would be in order to use the funds for such purpose. The pupils receive instruction in the proper use of water for irrigation at the School and it is possible that, because of this, the expenditure might properly be made from Vote 79. If any improvements are authorized, they will need to be completed during the low water period in winter.
months. River levels have been lower in recent years and there is no doubt that a crop loss has occurred in some years at the School due to lack of water caused by high intake.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir:

Re: Kamloops Indian School,
Irrigation Pump Intake.

At the request of the Indian Agent I made an inspection of the intake serving the Kamloops Indian School irrigation system on November 21st.

This inspection was made as a result of complaints by the school principal that the pumping plant did not function properly during the first two weeks of May and the last two weeks of September and that similar conditions had occurred during the past three or four years to the detriment of crop production through lack of water for irrigation.

On checking over gauge records at Chase on the South Thompson river and Kamloops on the Thompson river, I find that the river level has been too low to supply the pumping plant up to May 15th and after September 15th in 1942, after August 15th in 1941, after September 1st in 1940 and after September 15th in 1939. Apparently this condition has been a matter of complaint by the school authorities for some years past. Mr. Fredcroft reported under date of March 14, 1931 that there would likely be difficulty in securing water at the intake after September 15th but that he was unable to determine if the additional crop secured would justify the expense of lowering the intake.
Apparently up to the time of Mr. Tredcroft's report low water in the South Thompson river early in the season had not been a matter of complaint.

During this past irrigation season the river level did not rise sufficiently to permit pumping until about May 15th and in consequence of the long dry period preceding irrigation loss of crop was considerable. The school authorities have brought under irrigation about 20 acres of additional land which is very light soil and after the experience of the past year fear that labour expended on this land would be wasted unless they are able to secure water throughout the growing season.

In order to overcome difficulties complained of, it would be necessary to lower the intake culvert 2 feet and the intake well 3 feet. An extension of about 40 feet to the intake culvert would also be necessary.

The attached plan shows a cross section of intake works and suggested reconstruction. My inspection showed that the present culvert is not laid on a uniform grade and that the suction pipe of the pump is about one foot too short to operate satisfactorily under existing conditions, but even if these faults were corrected the intake would still be too high to supply water throughout the irrigation season.

To lower the intake and culvert the recommended amount is estimated to cost $755.00.

There is on hand sufficient pipe to provide a new culvert pipe, the value of which is $190.00, so that the actual cost of the improvement may be estimated at $975.00.
It would be very difficult to estimate the benefit to be derived from the lengthened irrigation season as a result of the intake being changed to a lower elevation, or to assess the crop loss occasioned by lack of water throughout the growing season, and I am unable to make any recommendation in respect to the necessity for the improvement.

If the alteration suggested is to be carried out it should be undertaken during the low water period and completed by the end of March.

Yours truly,

W.C. Warren
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer

I beg to refer to voucher 534/43 in favor of Kamloops Lumber Company Limited for $83.40 for lumber for cattle guard in conjunction with fencing of Adams Lake Reserve.

This voucher was rendered in error and refers to lumber purchased by the Water Power Bureau for work on the intake at the Kamloops Indian Residential School. It was billed to this office by the Kamloops Lumber Company two days after I had been advised by the Public Works that they were billing us for the lumber for the cattle guard. There was nothing on the account to indicate that it was an order from the Water Power Bureau, and as I had ordered no other lumber, I assumed that the amount was for the cattle guard material. The error was only discovered when I received the enclosed amount for $56.04 for lumber for the cattle guard.

I took this matter up today with Mr. W.C. Warren and he advised that he had called two or three times at the Office of the Lumber Company for his account but they were always closed. He pointed out to them that instructions re the rendering of the account were contained in the purchase order he gave them, but apparently they had not complied with them.

It will presumably be necessary for an adjustment to be made from Ottawa in regard to these vouchers.

I received a phone advise from the P.W.D. at Salmon Arm previous to receiving the amount from the Lumber Company, so you will understand that I had every reason to assume that the amount rendered was for our department.

"H.E. Taylor"
Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM TO MR. WEBB:

Re: Kamloops Indian School - Alterations to Irrigation Intake

In connection with the above, the improvements suggested in my report of December 7, 1943 and authorized in Mr. Mills' letter of January 21, 1943 on behalf of the Indian Affairs Branch were undertaken and completed March 31, 1943.

The work consisted of lowering the pump well and intake pipe on the South Thompson River used for irrigation purposes on the school property. It had been found that during low water periods in the fall and occasionally in spring, water was not available for irrigation at the pump intake. The school authorities maintained that the irrigation season was unduly curtailed by lack of water for a part of the growing season and resulted in poor yield and sometimes loss of crop.

The old pipeline consisting of two 16-inch vitrified tile pipes was uncovered and relaid two feet deeper as a single pipe 104 feet long with an extension of 36 feet of 16-inch creosoted wood stave pipe at the river end. A concrete base and head wall was constructed to support the intake end of the pipe and a screen was installed to prevent drift from entering the pipe.

A sheet pile coffer dam installed to facilitate excavation in the river bed was left in place and was backfilled with rock, covering the pipe to a depth of about two feet and for a distance of about 50 feet from the river end towards the well, a riprap of rock was provided outside.
the coffer dam.

The concrete well curbing was lowered about two feet six inches and a concrete bottom installed in the well. The work of lowering the curbing proved to be very hazardous owing to the poor quality of the concrete. This fractured badly and broke off at the bottom during the process of lowering and had to be replaced. Three feet in height was added to the top of the well to compensate for the lowering of the curbing and three feet of ten-inch wrought steel pipe was added to the length of the suction pipe. Pumping had to be maintained throughout the operation owing to excessive seepage.

The cost of the work was $839.24 of which $186.46 was expended for material and $652.78 for labour and supervision.

No difficulty should be encountered in future in securing an adequate irrigation supply. Some difficulty may however, be experienced with ice during very cold winters. The old intake pipeline was just above the ice elevation under normal conditions. It is quite possible that with an extremely low river level some damage may be caused at the outer end of the pipeline.

W.G. Warren
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer

REPORT ON KAMLOOPS INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH SEPTEMBER, 1943.

General;

The Kamloops Indian School was visited frequently, and on one visit the general fire alarm was tested, and the building emptied in an orderly manner, in two minutes. The test was made after lunch, when the smallest pupils were having a rest period in the upper floor dormitories, and had to use the fire escapes. When the alarm sounded, many of the girls were employed canning fruit, and when they formed up in the yard for roll-call check-up, most of them were clutching jars of fruit which they had apparently thought worth "rescuing".

Arrangements are being made to have the Chief of the Kamloops City fire brigade visit the school to assist in forming the boys and staff into an emergency brigade, and to advise re procedure, etc.

H.E. Taylor,

Attention Mr. D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sirs:

We wish to apologize very sincerely for the delay in answering your letter of June 21. In the absence of complete details, your letter was left to the writer's attention, who was out of town and who, eighteen years ago, sold the old pump referred to.

In looking over our old records, we find that this pump was driven by a 1/2 HP vertical motor and that the distance from the base of the motor to the bottom of the vertical pump in the laundry pit was 11'. We also refer to a letter written Father O'Grady in 1942 on the same subject. At that time we quoted $280.00 on a unit but in checking over other details, we find that we would prefer to install two intermediate bearings instead of one, which would bring the price to $295.00, f.o.b. Vancouver, exclusive of sales tax.

We would suggest that the old 1½" pipe, which must be badly corroded by this time, be removed and increased to 2". If this is done, the new pump will give a capacity of 50 to 60 US gallons per minute. The price quoted would include vertical pump, with column and shaft and discharge pipe for 11' setting, motor base plate from which pump would be suspended, 1 HP vertical type 1750 RPM 110/220 volt 60 cycle single phase ball bearing, automatic float switch with float and rod. In other words, the unit would be a duplicate of the old one except in a larger capacity.

We are enclosing leaflet illustrating the type of pump we
would supply except the illustration shows a short setting without intermediate bearings.

We shall be pleased to receive your instructions and delivery would take six to seven weeks from receipt of order.

Very truly yours,

PUMPS & POWER LIMITED.

JL Marshall

Type "A" Centrifugal Pumps

Built in a variety of sizes from 100 to 20,000 gallons per minute. Used especially where a large diameter impeller is necessary. Very suitable for direct connection to driving power slower than electric motors, such as gas engines. See cut.

Type "SD" Centrifugal Pumps

For direct connection to slow speed prime-movers, such as steam or oil engines. We have a variety of patterns for these pumps, both for low or high heads. Much used for condenser circulation, coffer-dam work, etc.
Automatic Electric Sump Pump

This pump is designed to elevate to street sewers the drainage in buildings where basement, boilers, or elevator pit, or toilets, are below sewer level, and for any other service where the liquid to be pumped accumulates in a catch basin, pit, or tank.

The unit consists of a Pumps & Power centrifugal pump, direct connected by a shaft to a vertical ball-bearing motor, which is started and stopped automatically through the rise and fall of a float in the sump. For crude sewage, we provide the inside of the sump shell with special constructed cutting edges to accommodate any tough materials. The whole discharge pipe included is mounted in one piece on a cast iron plate, as shown above. All parts can therefore be lifted out for inspection or repair by simply lifting the pit cover. We also supply cast-iron pit if desired.

This outfit is of simple and rugged construction, fitted with self-lubricating bearings which require no attention. Operation is both quiet and efficient. Floor space small.

We have built these in all sizes for over ten years and have many in successful operation throughout the province.

To the Fire Marshal: Re Inspection, Kamloops Indian Residential School - July 18th:

Accompanied by Rev. Father O'Grady and Staff Sergeant A. Fairbairn I made an inspection of the above-noted school and report as follows:

Construction:
The main building is of brick exterior construction with wood interior. It is three storeys in height over a full sized basement. The other buildings are of wood frame.

Occupancy:
These premises are used as a residential school for Indian children. The upper floor of the main building is given over to dormitories. The next floor is given over to class rooms while the main floor has the executive offices, library, etc. The basement houses the heating plant, the laundry, playrooms, etc.

First Aid Fire Protection:
There are standpipes equipped with 1½" hose as well as fire extinguishers of various types. A supply of rubber gaskets is required for the couplings between the standpipes and hose. I found carbon tetrachloride extinguishers in several parts of the institution. Owing to the toxic properties of these extinguishers I would advise that they be removed and placed where they may be of use in case of electrical fires. I find that the larger sized extinguishers supplied are foam type which are practically unfitted for general fire fighting. They are excellent for oil fires. Five Gallon hand pump cans are far more efficient and their maintenance is negligible.

Routes of Egress:
There are sufficient routes of egress to take care of the children but the indication of the routes is poorly done. There is a direct route from the different rows of beds. These beds must be laid out differently in order to allow a straight passage from the furthest row of beds to the exit doorway. I may be mistaken but I am of the opinion that the bed spaces are overcrowded according to the Health Act. Exit signs pointing the most direct routes to all exits together with standard exit signs and panic bolts on all doors leading to the exits proper should be installed.

Recreation Building:
Construction: This is quite a large wood frame structure as a general recreation hall, gym, auditorium, etc. It will have two extra exit doors.

Heating:
This building is heated by a very nonstandard furnace which is vented by a smoke pipe through a window.

Projection Room: This hall is used as a moving picture room and has a nonstandard projection room in which is installed a 6A 35 m.m. projection machine complete with sound equipment. The room which is way below standard size is very substandard in construction having wooden walls and ceiling. There are no covers and while there are two door openings one is boarded up the other has no door on it. There is not and never has been a licensed projectionist here. Should there ever be such a thing I hate to think what would happen to the projectionist's building. I find that 16 m.m. film is also used he
Manual Arts Work Shop:
This is a large two storey wood frame structure on a full basement.

General:
The housekeeping conditions were very good and with the changes to the exit route indications, the exits and the recreation hall there should be very little to worry about in this school.

Respectfully submitted,

"W.A. Oswald"

Dear Sir:

Re: High pressure Laundry Boilers -
at Indian Residential Schools -
Kamloops and Christie, B. C.

At my last inspection of the boilers at Kamloops School, I found that the overload of this boiler was beginning to show injurious effects in the number of leaking tubes on the top plate.

On October 9th, 1942, I made a report on the condition of the Laundry, which I am now enclosing with this report.

Since making my inspection, you have received a letter from Rev. Father F. O'Grady, Principal of the School, asking for suggestions to overcome the steam shortages.

In addition, you received a letter, dated September 8th, 1945, from Mr. J. Coleman, Asst. Commissioner, stating that Mr. Ashbridge, Indian Agent at Port Alberni, asked for a new laundry boiler for Christie School and quoting price for same.

On working out the steam requirements for the laundry at Kamloops School, I find that it will take a boiler of 26 H.P. When the new mangle, now in the laundry, is installed, the steam requirements will be 34 H.P. In view of the above, I will suggest the following for your consideration:

(1) Install in the laundry, at Kamloops, a 50 H.P. Horizontal Return Tubular boiler, stoker-fired, to carry a steam pressure of 150 lbs.

(2) Install a reducing valve on the steam main and reduce the steam to 90 lbs. at the mangles.

(3) Take the present Vertical boiler, have it retubed and installed at Christie School.

If this is adopted, there will be no further trouble for some years, and it should be done as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

T. J. Arnall,
S.P.P. Engineer.

Dear Sir:

Re Indian Residential School, Kamloops, B.C.

In answer to Mr. D.M. MacKay's letter, dated Oct. 17th, 1942 regarding the Indian Residential School at Kamloops, B.C., I will answer the third paragraph first - standard black pipe and black malleable fittings are all that will be required.

Now in regard to the vertical boiler - up to 1936 the laundry was operated with a vertical tubular boiler No. 43794, rated at 9 H.P. At that time the laundry was enlarged and more machines installed. The old boiler was taken out and the present vertical boiler installed. This boiler is rated at 19 H.P. This gave complete satisfaction for a short time, but when other changes were made, the boiler required forcing. A stoker was installed and the boiler further forced. Naturally when you begin to force a boiler up to and over its capacity it means a greater consumption of coal, particularly in a vertical boiler, where the efficiency of this type of boiler is very low.

In my report to Major D.M. MacKay, dated September 14th, I recommended that the boiler be retubed and am still of the same opinion and the school operate the laundry machinery in accordance with the steam capacity. This arrangement could be carried out during the duration of the present war and I understand that owing to the steel situation it will be impossible to have a boiler manufactured unless it is to be used for essential war purposes.

Again, the steam requirements of this laundry are, according to the Rev. Principal's statements, increasing so rapidly that the boiler capacity now required is nearly four times as much as in 1935.

I would suggest that a proper survey be made of the probable future steam requirements so that when a new boiler is installed, one large enough to take any possible increase in steam load be provided.

Even if the present boiler is discarded I do not know of any school, except possibly Christie, that will require a new boiler as all the other schools have new laundry boilers and they are giving every satisfaction.

I expect to be in Vancouver on Monday, October 26th, on my return from Alert Bay and will meet Major D.M. MacKay and discuss the whole situation with him.

I remain,

Yours respectfully,

T.J. Arnall
S.F.F. Engineer.

Dear Sir:

It is proposed to carry a new 3" steam main from boilers to main building, and before leaving the boiler room, drop the 3" steam line to a point approximately 5 ft. below grade. At that point we drip the steam main and increase the size of steam main to 3-1/2" until we enter the Auditorium, then divide line into one 3# and one 2-1/2" connecting to, two (2) Unit Heaters, and two (2) Radiators in the dressing rooms. All steam pipes to be covered with 4 ply air cell pipe covering neatly pasted on. Valve steam main at the boiler.

All drips and return lines to be connected to the present pump in boiler room.

Return lines in Auditorium to be covered with 3 ply air cell pipe covering.

Lay a 2" plank box 10' x 12" inside measurements from Coal Hopper to Auditorium graded from 5 ft. to 3 ft. to drain condensation back to trap. Cover roof of box with roofing felt before back filling. The return line not to be covered in the box or the boiler room.

Referring to your letter of the 8th inst., requesting information regarding what compliance has been made with the recommendations of the Deputy Fire Marshall following his inspection of the Kamloops Indian Residential School, I would advise as follows:

1. Beds in dormitories have been re-arranged to allow a straight passage from the furthest row of beds to the exit doorway.

2. Exit signs have been installed in dormitories.

3. Panic bolts supplied have been installed.

4. Extra two exit doors have not been installed in the recreational building. There are, at present, in addition to the main entrance, four fire exit doors with red lights. The school principal thinks that the Deputy Fire Marshall may have thought that there were only two fire exit doors, because, when he inspected this building, he did not go into the dressing rooms, from which two of the fire exit doors are located. He viewed the interior of the building from the main entrance, from which only two of the fire exit doors are discernible. No suggestion was received as to just where the additional exits should be placed. The building was erected by a local contractor in accordance with regulations, and the School Principal requests further enlightenment in regard to the extra two exits required.

5. The use of the 35 mm. movie projector has been discontinued. A 16 mm. portable sound projector is now used, and the projection room, which was quite disapproved by the Deputy Fire Marshall, is no longer in use.

6. The standpipes will be flushed out in the near future, and this will be done twice yearly as requested.

Proposed Heating Installation for Indian School Auditorium

Dear Sir:

Revised Estimate

It is proposed to carry a new 3" steam main from boilers to main building and before leaving the boiler room, drop the 3" steam line to a point approximately 5 ft. below grade. At that point we drip the steam main and increase the size of steam main to 3-1/2" until we enter the auditorium, then divide line into one 3" and one 2-1/2" connecting to 2 unit heaters, and 2 radiators in the dressing rooms. All steam pipes to be covered with 4 ply air cell pipe covering neatly pasted on. Valve steam main at the boiler.

All drips and return lines to be connected to the present pump in boiler room. Return lines in auditorium to be covered with 3 ply air cell pipe covering.

Lay a 2" plank box 10" x 12" inside measurements from coal hopper to auditorium graded from 5 ft. to 3 ft. to drain condensation back to trap. Cover roof of box with roofing felt before back filling. The return line not to be covered in the box or the boiler room.

This price includes 2 - #35 Unifin one-speed unit heaters. 2 - 75 ft. radiators in the two dressing rooms, and install a new radiator of 75 ft. at the rear of stage. All necessary traps and valves. Our price for this job complete is SIXTEEN HUNDRED AND SEVENTY SEVEN DOLLARS AND FIFTY CENTS. ($1,677.50).

If #583 two-speed Modine Unit Heaters are used add TEN DOLLARS each $10.00.
