Dear Mr. Neary:

I received the copy of the letter you addressed to Mr. D. MacRitchie, Chief Priority Officer of the War Assets Corporation in Montreal in connection with the purchase of a Caterpillar D6 from the Military Training Centre at Vernon, B.C. I wish to thank you for your efforts towards obtaining this machine for our needs.

As far as I know the machine in question has not yet been declared surplus. I learned recently that all such equipment of the Armed Forces, being Crown property, is turned over, when not needed, to the Crown Assets Allocation. If the latter have no use for it it is then turned over to the War Assets Corporation for sale to the general public.

Since the demand for heavy equipment is so great we may have difficulty in getting this machine from the War Assets Corporation if it is declared surplus to them. As I see it now the best procedure would be to apply to the Crown Assets Allocation to have the machine allocated to us on whatever basis they wish. Since we are under the Department of Mines & Resources they might allocate the machine to the Department for our use. However, if it has to be declared to the War Assets Corporation to be sold it should be earmarked for us. - The Army Headquarters who own the machine and the Crown Assets Allocation each must have offices in Ottawa.

Thanking you in advance for what attention you may give to this matter I am,

Yours sincerely,

F. O'Grady O.M.I.
Principal.

Re: Improvements at Kamloops Indian Res. School, B.C.
Attention: Mr. P. Phelan.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

The above school is possibly the largest in the Indian Department system of schools. It is, generally speaking, in good condition in spite of the fact that very little has been set aside for the last ten or twelve years, for general repairs and upkeep. The following demands are now made by the principal and I hope that sufficient money will be provided in the coming estimates, for each of them:

(1) The school has an authorized pupilage of 285 but it has had at least 305 present on its roll and the principal now demands an increase of 20 pupils because with the increase cost of living, it is becoming impossible for him to keep this supernumerary number without compensation.

(2) Only $1500.00 has been provided for general repairs and upkeep for this very large building and this sum, you will admit, is not sufficient. The principal is, therefore, asking that this be increased to $3000.00 per year. At the present time, all outside buildings have to be painted and the interior of the school should also receive a great deal of attention. It is impossible to do so with the amount of $1500.00 which has been provided in the past.

(3) Father O'Grady, the principal, who has had great deal of experience in the supervising of Indian Reserves, has come to the conclusion that for his district, the establishment of a Mounted Police Post is essential and he now asks the Department to study this project.

(over......)
and, if possible, provide the funds necessary for this purpose, out of the present year's estimates. The Indians have a salutary fear of the Mounted Police and a great deal of drinking, if not all of it, would completely disappear from the Reserve under the protection of this Post. Most of the immorality and lewd conduct of young people would cease, if the constant vigilance of the Mounted Police was present. The same would hold in the case of free unions. At the present time, the Indians have much less Police protection than the White people and they are abusing their liberty with results that are becoming every day, more costly to the Department of Indian Affairs.

(4) The school has established a small saw-mill to provide lumber for its own needs and those of the Indians desiring to build a home for themselves, particularly for such former pupils who are getting married and who wish to establish their homes on the Reserves. The cost of this saw-mill has been around $3,000.00 and so far, only $600.00 has been received from the Department towards it. Father O'Grady is of the opinion that a larger amount should be contributed by the Department, as this mill will supply the needs of the Indians, which is the normal duty of the Department to provide for.

(5) In the Kamloops Territory, irrigation is the only means of growing crops of grain and hay. This holds for the Whites as well as for the Indians. At the present time, the Indians of the Kamloops Territory have almost no irrigation facilities. If they had, they would probably cease being just labourers and would establish homes on their own lands. Would it be possible for the Department of Indian Affairs to have a survey made to find out what the cost of an irrigation project would be? A sum of money for this purpose should be provided in this year's estimates and if the scheme proved feasible, funds for this purpose could be included in next year's budget.

(6) The last request of Father O'Grady is for a High School. He claims that Kamloops is sufficiently central for this purpose and he also states that his own school would provide, on the present basis of 8th Grade graduates, about 20 pupils per year. As Williams Lake, Lejac, Mission City and Sechelt Schools could also send their 8th Grade pupils to Kamloops, without very great expense, the pupilage of this High School could easily reach from 110 to 130 pupils. This number would provide four classes of about 30 pupils each.

Of course, a High School would mean the building of a complete unit and would be fairly costly, but I think it is a practical solution of the High School problem, as far as our B.C. Indians are concerned and one which should receive the immediate attention of the Department.

Hoping that the above will be given your serious consideration,

I remain, dear Mr. Phelan,

Very truly yours,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.
Ottawa, 14 September 1946.

Dear Mr. Neary:

I wish to thank you for your letter of September 10th, attached to which was a copy of a letter you received from Mr. M.L. Fitzgerald, of the War Assets Corporation in Vancouver in connection with the purchase by us of a Caterpillar D6 from the Military Camp at Vernon, B.C.

Previous to our correspondence on this matter I discussed the purchase of this tractor with Mr. Fitzgerald. He stated that the Corporation had nothing to do with the machine since it was not yet declared surplus; that this equipment, being Crown property belonged to the Crown Assets Allocation, who, if they had no use for it, would turn it over to the War Assets Corporation for sale. Mr. Fitzgerald also stated that he was not sure whether we could be given a No. 1 priority and the first chance to purchase the tractor. The latter statement is confirmed in his letter to you of Aug. 26th, when he says that the sale will be subject to earlier dated priority. All this is subject, of course, to the machine being turned over to the War Assets Corporation for sale.

It is because of the uncertainty of being able to obtain the machine from the War Assets Corporation when they get possession of it that I suggested in my letter of September 3rd, that the Crown Assets Allocation be contacted to have the machine transferred to us on whatever basis they wish i.e., loan or otherwise. It is because I want to be assured of getting the tractor that I suggest the latter move. If Mr. MacRitchie can assure us of getting the machine it would not be necessary to approach the Crown Assets Allocation.

I wish to thank you for your efforts on our behalf; they are certainly most appreciated.

Dear Major MacKay:

Following our telephone conversation of today I am enclosing the particulars of the tractor located at Edmonton, Alta. and for sale by the War Assets Corporation of Calgary, Alta.

This tractor, if purchased by the Department, would fill a great need here at the School and could be used for the extension and improvement of the irrigation systems on the adjoining Reserves.

Yours very truly,

F. O'Grady O.M.I.
Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

The Department is aware of the recent representations made by Rev. Father O'Grady for the supply of a tractor for use at the Kamloops Indian Residential School.

I think it is agreed that a real need exists for this type of equipment not alone at residential schools such as Kamloops, but at many of the larger Reserves as well. I may say that I have held the opinion for some time that heavy tractors should be supplied to a number of our agricultural Agencies for clearing and improving land suitable for cultivation, and indulged the hope that our needs, at least to some extent, would be met from the large number turned in as surplus by various Government departments once the war ended. The War Assets organization was not in the picture at the time otherwise it is doubtful if such hopes would have been entertained as we have not been successful in getting much in the way of any type of equipment from this source irrespective of the pressing character of the need. So it would appear that if we are going to get anywhere in supplying such equipment to our Agencies it will be necessary for the Department to resort to purchase.

Father O'Grady has been in touch with the War Assets Corporation, Calgary, who have advised that they have a diesel tractor at warehouse No. 30, 123A Street and 127th Avenue, Edmonton, at the price of $7,856.00, "as is and where is." A copy of the correspondence regarding the unit in question, as received from Father O'Grady, is enclosed herewith. This type of machine is regarded as being eminently suitable for our purposes in this province and it is felt that if the necessary funds can be secured the War Assets should be approached with a view to its purchase.

It is fully expected that there will be a substantial balance, possibly $5,000 to $6,000, of the B.C. Special Vote - Irrigation, that we will be unable to spend this year due largely
to lack of necessary materials and labour. In addition to this it is anticipated that there will be a substantial balance available from the Housing Vote to this province unless the supply of materials between now and the end of the current fiscal year greatly improves. Would it be possible to arrange with the War Assets for the purchase of this tractor, payment to be made in April from such balances as remain? The tractor would, of course, be the property of the Department and available for use on Reserves as required. It would, however, be advisable to have the tractor housed at the Kamloops Indian Residential School where it would be available to the school for use on the understanding that the school in return would be responsible for its proper care and maintenance, which certainly should be properly provided for in the case of a unit of such value. If it is possible to secure the machine on the basis suggested I would be prepared to recommend that the balances of the B.C. Special Vote unspent at the end of the current fiscal year be used to meet the cost.

It would be appreciated if the Department could give early consideration to this matter as it is understood that War Assets, Calgary, are about to offer the equipment for sale to the public early next week.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Reference - your 4-11-4 of November 2.

Your letter has received careful consideration but we regret that we are unable to permit the purchase of this machine.

All purchases in excess of $5,000.00 have to be authorized by the Governor-in-Council. Before an Order-in-Council can be obtained, the Chief Treasury Officer has to certify that funds are available. Regarding your suggestion for using balances available at the end of the fiscal year in your various special votes, he would be unable to do this due to the fact that he would have no assurance that any stated amount would be left over for the purpose of purchasing this machine.

It is felt that this tractor would be heavier than would be required for the purposes described in your letter, unless of course the land to be cleared was very heavily wooded. The biggest expense in maintaining such a machine would be the payment of the driver, who would naturally have to be fully qualified in order to keep the machine in proper running order.

We do concur in the need for a machine for the purposes you mention in your letter but feel that the price of $7,836.00 for a used machine is much too great. As you are

........ aware
aware, the funds in the B.C. Special Vote - Irrigation - must be spent for irrigation purposes only. As for the Housing Vote, it is expected that the project being undertaken at the Port Hardy Military Camp will take most of these funds that are available. It is hoped that a cheaper machine can be located for your needs in the near future.

TRACTOR FOR KAMLOOPS INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Reference - your letter 4-11-1 of December 5 -

The proposal outlined in your letter has been given careful consideration. The problem is that the Department is willing to purchase a tractor for use at the Kamloops School and for use on irrigation projects and road building in the Kamloops Agency, but the purchase of this particular machine is felt to present certain difficulties.

At the present time the largest machine in use on similar projects is a D-4. One of these is in use in Nova Scotia and has been found to be as heavy as required for all purposes. We also have one in use at Norway House, Manitoba, which is proving to be very satisfactory.

The D-8 machine is so heavy that a special carrier vehicle is required to move it from one place to another. If you intend using it on irrigation projects and for road building, then it will be necessary to use provincial highways for transporting it. The laws of the province prohibit a tractor being driven on provincial roads. Therefore you would require a tractor transporter.

On the other hand a D-4 machine can be loaded into a two or three ton truck and moved from one project to another quite easily.

The second disadvantage of using a D-8 machine is that considerably more maintenance is required to keep it operating.
operating efficiently. This means the employment of a highly skilled driver.

Would you please bring these two points to the attention of the Reverend Father O'Grady, as it is quite possible that he does not realize the large size of the D-8 machine and its very heavy costs of operation.

Dear Dr. Scott;

With reference to the Farm Loan Act passed by the Federal House, by means of which several of the Provinces will be enabled to finance agricultural long-term loans, I had an interview today with Hon. J.E. Brownlee, Premier of Alberta, on the subject of my prospective employment in this work.

Mr. Brownlee expressed the opinion that it will be next fall, at the earliest, before this Act can be brought into operation in Alberta, owing to the delay in getting all the details worked out at Ottawa. He expects there will have to be another conference between the Provincial and Federal governments, which can only take place after the conclusion of the present session, by which time the Ministers will want a little rest and recreation after their arduous duties. Then, he says, holiday time will be here, and it will be difficult to speed things up at that time of year.

You were kind enough, Dr. Scott, to give me a very good reference, which I am sure will prove of great value in connection with my application, and for which I tender my sincerest thanks.

In the meantime I wish to place my services at the disposal of the Indian Department, either in British Columbia or elsewhere, provided there is any vacancy which I might fill. When in Victoria a few weeks ago I was told that the Department contemplate erecting a new Indian school at Alert Bay; and that there may be other building work in the Province too. If so, and if the Department has not already appointed an Inspector to supervise the work, I should be pleased to serve in that capacity, at Alert Bay or elsewhere.

The Department already has full knowledge of my capabilities, having served as Inspector of Construction almost continuously for nearly five years in Alberta; in addition to which I was at the head of the Island Building Company, Ltd., which Co. erected the Kuper Island School in 1915.

I cannot afford to wait indefinitely on the Alberta Farm Loan appointment, and am ready to go to work again for the Indian Department, under whom I had the honour of serving before.
I may say I am familiar with conditions at the Pacific Coast, having operated there as building contractor over a number of years. Also, I believe my appointment as building inspector would meet with the approval of Commissioner Ditchburn, with whom I had pleasant relations during the construction of the Kuper Island school.

I am leaving for Vancouver on the 27th, and may be reached at the address indicated at the head of this letter.

Hoping to be favoured with an early reply, and assuring you of my best efforts in the event of my engagement,

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Dr. Duncan C. Scott.
Deputy Superintendent General.
Department of Indian Affairs.
OTTAWA.

Dear Dr. Scott:

Many thanks for your letter of the 29th ultimo advising me that the Department has called for tenders for the erection of a unit for the Kamloops Indian Residential School, and that when the Civil Service Commission's advertisement for an Inspector of Construction issues I shall receive a copy.

It is my intention to make application for the position of Inspector in the prescribed way as soon as I receive the promised copy of the advertisement, but in the meantime can this letter not be treated tentatively as an application? The Department has full knowledge of me already, and my previous application, when formerly engaged, will be on the Department's file. However, I shall be pleased to make any further application which may be required.

In the event of my appointment I should like to be notified as promptly as possible so that I may be on the job at the commencement of operations, and to acquaint myself with all the local conditions bearing on the work. I am expecting to go on a short trip up the Coast next week, but shall arrange for telegrams to be repeated to me, and shall return promptly whenever advised that my services are required by the Department.

I should just like to add that if I receive this appointment no effort on my part will be lacking to merit such expression of the Department's continued confidence.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Oct. 3, 1948.

S. K. Bruce, Esq., Acting Indian Agent, Kamloops, B.C.

With reference to your letter of September 28th and Father O'Grady's letter in connection with the employment of skilled labour in the construction of a root cellar at Kamloops Residential School, a review of our files indicate an order was placed for materials for this building by the Department, reference P.O. 25707 of July, 1944, and consequently it is not understood what the Reverend Principal has in mind in suggesting that funds set aside for material could be used for labour.

Funds provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs and equipment at this school amount to only $1750 and as an expenditure of $2700 has already been incurred for the new boiler, plus installation costs, in addition to various other expenditures it is doubtful if the Department will be in a position to make further funds available for the purpose requested. If, however, you can secure from the Principal an estimate of the labour costs I am prepared to refer the matter to the Department.

For D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Mr. Bruce:

It would be appreciated if the major portion of the funds allotted for improvements to the School during the current year could be used to engage skilled labour. We are about to construct a root cellar 125 ft. long and 30 ft. wide with 9 ft. cement walls. Although the older boys could learn a certain amount from assisting in the construction of this building it is felt that the work is of too laborious a nature for them. It would be much more preferable to engage only adult and it would be appreciated, therefore, if the funds set aside for materials could be used for labor as we have all the materials on hand necessary for this building.

Yours very truly,

I am forwarding herewith a copy of a letter from the Blain Boiler Works Ltd., Vancouver, B.C., who are installing the new boiler at the Kamloops Indian Residential School, advising that the existing stoker is not of sufficient capacity to take care of the new boiler and in its present state will not operate to any advantage. A letter from Rev. Father O'Grady regarding the matter, together with a quotation from H. Giddens and Sons, Kamloops, B.C., on a new stoker are also enclosed.

This matter was discussed with the Principal at the school on the 20th instant and it was felt that the Department should be advised immediately of the situation so that a decision could be made regarding replacement of the existing stoker and action taken, if possible, before the close of the current fiscal year. Rev. Father O'Grady expects to be in Ottawa within the next few days and will no doubt call on the Department regarding this and other matters relating to the school.

It will be observed that H. Giddens and Sons, although estimating the value of the present stoker at between $500 and $400 do not make a definite offer to accept this unit as a trade-in on the new stoker but suggest that it be left at the school and they will endeavour to dispose of it for us. I am unable to recommend approval of such an arrangement. The firm supplying the new stoker should be prepared to allow a fair price for the old stoker on a trade-in basis.

The feeding and burning capacity of the unit quoted on by Giddens and Sons is slightly less than that recommended by Mr. Arnall, S.P.P. Engineer, Department of Public Works, but it is considered to be sufficient for our purposes. A
copy of the specification for a new stoker, forwarded by Mr. C. F. Dawson, District Resident Architect, Department of Public Works, on February 8th, 1946, is enclosed for your information.

I appreciate the Department's difficulty in dealing with a matter involving a fairly large expenditure so close to the end of the current fiscal year but it is being placed before you in case funds are available from which you would wish immediate purchase made.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

In reply to your letter of the 14th of last month I would advise that payment could be made on the second in connection with the installation of the Iron Fireman Stoker by H. Gidden's Sons of Kamloops, B.C. With regard to the first, however, payment should be withheld until the Blain Boiler Works Ltd. of Vancouver B.C. satisfactorily complete the installation. Apparently this firm sub-let the contract and we had to go the expense of approximately $200.00 to remove the old boiler, take out a wall, reset and extend the new floor and build a new cement wall. The installation took so long we were kept nine weeks of the School year without laundry facilities. The people who installed the boiler used from 800 to 1000 of our old common brick instead of obtaining new fire brick. Furthermore they did not cement the bricks of the fire box. They will have to be removed and put in properly.

I would advise that until the above and other adjustments are made that payment be withheld on the installation of the boiler.

Yours very truly,

F. O'Grady O.M.I.

Inspector's Report - Kamloops Residential School

Inspector Davey's report upon his recent visit to the above school has been received and carefully noted.

We have included in our 1948-49 estimates a sum for the construction of a four-classroom block at this residential school. While our estimates have not yet been finalized, it is to be hoped that this item can be left in for action next year. While the educational recommendations of the Parliamentary Committee have not yet been made, it is evident that they favour the sending of Indian high school students to provincial schools. This policy is already in effect in many residential schools across Canada. As Inspector Davey points out, there are five schools in British Columbia now sending high school pupils to nearby provincial high schools.

When Father O'Grady visited here last summer, he informed the Department that the Kamloops High School was already overcrowded and that there was little possibility of having Indian children admitted. It is suggested, therefore, that the Kamloops School Board be approached and some agreement reached as to the possibility of having these children attend the local high school for their senior work.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Kamloops, B.C., January 26th, 1948.

Mr. Phillip Phelan,
Chief Training Division,
Department of Mines Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

When I was in Ottawa I mentioned that last year we were obliged to construct a root cellar, machine shed and grain storage building from materials we could gather together due to the fact that funds were not available from the Department. The root cellar, formerly used, collapsed from rotting of timbers underneath the ground and we had no place to store vegetables. We likewise had no place in which to store all the machinery used at the school; hence the necessity of the machine shed. A grain storage building was also a necessity because of the fact that we now have to purchase grain, when available, in fairly large quantities.

Attached herewith is a list of the materials and the amounts expended. The buildings are all of new construction and it would be greatly appreciated if the Department could re-imburse the School for the expense incurred in the erection of these buildings which were necessary.

Yours sincerely,

F. O'Grady O.M.I.,
Principal.
February 13, 1948.

Dear Father O'Grady:

We are in receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo with reference to the root cellar, machine shed and grain storage building which you constructed during the past summer.

At the present time I regret that it is not possible to favourably consider paying the amount requested as our funds are so limited. However, we will review our appropriation about March 15th with a view to determining what amount, if any, we can allow.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Rev. F. O'Grady, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Kamloops Indian Res. School,
Kamloops, B.C.

AIR MAIL

Ottawa, March 25, 1948.

Dear Father O'Grady:

On the occasion of your recent visit to the Department you stated that considerable interior painting could be done by the school management of the Kamloops School.

We find that we have some funds left in the current year's appropriation and consequently we are advising Indian Commissioner Arneil by air mail that we are prepared to allow an amount of $400 for the purchase of paint.

Please advise Mr. Arneil immediately regarding the colours of paint that you desire. He will arrange purchase so that the account will be dated not later than March 31st.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

AIR MAIL

Mr. W.S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

In a letter dated October 22nd, 1947, Reverend Father O'Grady, principal of the Kamloops Residential School requested authority to expend an amount of slightly over $1,500.00 for material and labour in erecting a machine shop. At that time he was advised that owing to heavy commitments upon our appropriation it was not possible to give favourable consideration to his request.

This morning we received a telegram from him urging us to give approval of the expenditure required for the machine shop.

For your personal information the following amounts have been provided in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1948-49 for Kamloops Residential School:

Steam Press for Laundry and New Toilets - - - - $1,700.
Repairs to Roof - - - $ 900.
Levelling Playgrounds - - $2,400.

$4,000.

The amount of $4,000.00 mentioned above is apportionately larger than the amount provided at any other Indian Residential School in Canada during the current fiscal year and it should be kept in mind.
by all parties concerned that the amount of $4,000.00 for repairs and improvements and purchase of new equipment at the Kamloops School during the fiscal year 1948-49 cannot be exceeded.

These figures are not being supplied to Father O'Grady at the present time and should be treated confidentially as far as you are concerned.

We realize that the Kamloops School is being well operated under Father O'Grady but at the same time we believe that the whole situation at Kamloops should be very carefully reviewed with a view to determining if additional new buildings are absolutely essential or if the accommodation in the present buildings could be rearranged to provide for the services that are necessary.

In a large measure the success of an Indian Residential School depends upon the qualities of the principal. We do not question Father O'Grady's ability but we wonder if in the event of his being transferred to some other field of activity, another principal would be able to properly handle the very extensive set-up that now exists at Kamloops and which should provide all the facilities that can reasonably be expected.

We would like you to give this matter your very serious consideration and let us have your views before we decide in exactly what manner the amount provided in the current year's appropriation should be expended.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

In a recent interview with the Principal, the Rev. Father O'Grady of Kamloops Indian Residential School, he intimated that the end of the fiscal year 1947-48 left his school financially with a debit balance of approximately $10,000 which he states can be attributed largely to the purchase of a bulldozer and the erection of three permanent buildings - root cellar, machine shed and grain storage building. These buildings were referred to in my report on this school dated March 10th, 1948.

Attached you will find a statement in triplicate covering the cost of lumber, nails and paint used in the erection of these buildings, which amount to $2,947.81. I might point out that the Department contributed to the extent of $826.50 to the cost of materials for the construction of the grain storage shed but it is not clear whether the materials purchased by the Department are included in the list submitted by the Reverend Principal. The low cost of lumber is due to its being produced in the school sawmill.

The Principal feels that some consideration might be given by the Department to help defray the cost of materials used in these permanent buildings as they were essential to the operation of the school and will remain satisfactory for many years to come, and thus help reduce the large debit bank balance. At his request I am forwarding these statements for your consideration and whatever action you may deem necessary.

Personal and Confidential

Hon. J. A. Glenn,
Minister of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Hon. and Dear Mr. Glenn:

Although I have never met you, I feel I know you from reading about you so I am taking the liberty of writing this personal and confidential letter regarding the "The Four Room School" that is going to be built at the Indian School at Kamloops. I understand that the present Principal, Rev. F. O'Grady, O.M.I., when in Ottawa last Feb., was told to get everything ready for the erection of this building as soon as he returned home.

I also understand that he did so, that is he went to work and cut the timber and the special rafters etc. and arranged with a contractor to put up the building. The rafters are special because of their length.

How when I was over at Kamloops a few days ago, I happened to meet Father O'Grady in a store and when I asked him how things were at the school, he replied not very good and this led to a few more questions and finally, he related the whole story about the new building and what he had done and then said he recently had a letter telling him that the construction of this building would likely be let by calling tenders, that the Department, that is your Department, felt it should be constructed by others not connected with the Church. I then suggested that he should write you direct and that he would obtain more satisfactory information from you than from anyone else. He said he did not feel like doing that and I then said I would. Hence this letter.

First of all let me say, I take a great interest in this school, it is the largest Indian School in Canada, I think,
but of course you would know about this, but I feel it is one of the best administered institutions in Canada and the present Principal is easily the most capable Principal the school has ever had. He has made many improvements there and has also constructed quite a number of buildings that has not cost the Government a cent, such as an Auditorium, 115 x 70. A technical school 100 x 24 both these buildings are a credit to the School and could not be built today for less than forty thousand.

Now he has arranged with Mr. Robert Swan a well known and reliable contractor to erect this new building and I understand that this man will have his brother, the man who built the big dairy barn at the school working with him. Let me add that Mr. Robert Swan is an experienced contractor and has built many buildings in B.C. For example the Gymnasium at the University and has been employed by the Dept. of Education as a Building Construction Instructor. He has also constructed many other large buildings, but the point I want to stress is that he is not only a capable contractor but a reliable one as well.

I am sure that if this were not so, your new Commissioner, Mr. W. S. Arnell would not recommend him or the arrangement and I am also sure his predecessor Major J. M. MacKay would also make the same recommendations.

Now Mr. Glenn, knowing this and knowing the conditions that exist, political as well as economic and I think I know for I have been here for thirty eight years and have been a member of the B.C. Legislature for the last twenty years, I strongly recommend that the present Principal, namely Father O'Grady, be instructed to go ahead with the arrangements he has already started and erect this new school, and I am certain if this is done there will be no regrets.

In making this recommendation to you, I assure you I do so from no selfish reason or motive but solely and only in the best interest of all parties concerned and this Sir includes Your Department.

Yours sincerely,

(Signed) J. J. Gillis

May 29, 1948.

Hon. J.A. Glenn,
Minister of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Hon and Dear Mr. Glen:

Although I have never met you, I feel I know you from reading about you so I am taking the liberty of writing this personal and confidential letter regarding the "The Four Room School" that is going to be built at the Indian School at Kamloops. I understand that the present Principal, Rev. F. O'Grady, O.M.I., when in Ottawa last Feb. was told to get everything ready for the erection of this building as soon as he returned home.

I also understand that he did so, that is he went to work and cut the timber and the special rafters etc and arranged with a contractor to put up the building. The rafters are special because of their length.

Now when I was over at Kamloops a few days ago, I happened to meet Father O'Grady in a store and when I asked him how things were at the school, he replied not very good and this led to a few more questions and finally, he related the whole story about the new building and what he had done and then said he recently had a letter telling him that the construction of this building would likely be let by calling tenders, that the Department, that is your Department, felt it should be constructed by others not connected with the Church. I then suggested that he should write you direct and that he would obtain more satisfactory information from you than from any one else. He said he did not feel like doing that and I then said I would. Hence this letter.

First of all let me say, I take a great interest in this School, it is the largest Indian School in Canada, I think, but of course you would know about this, but I feel it is one of the best administered institutions in
Canada and the present Principal is easily the most capable Principal the school has ever had. He has made many improvements there and has also constructed quite a number of buildings that has not cost the Government a cent, such as an Auditorium, 115 x 70. A technical school 100 x 24 both these buildings are a credit to the School and could not be built today for less than forty thousand.

Now he has arranged with Mr. Robert Swan a well known and reliable contractor to erect this new building and I understand that this man will have his brother, the man who built the big dairy barn at the school working with him. Let me add that Mr. Robert Swan is an experienced Contractor and has built many buildings in B.C. For example the Gymnasium at the University and has been employed by the Dept. of Education as a Building Construction Instructor. He has also constructed many other large buildings, but the point I want to stress is that he is not only a capable contractor but a reliable one as well.

I am sure that if this were not so, your new Commissioner, Mr. W.S. Arneil would not recommend him or the arrangement and I am also sure his predecessor Major J.M. MacKay would also make the same recommendations.

Now Mr. Glenn, knowing this and knowing the conditions that exist, political as well as economic and I think I know for I have been here for thirty eight years and have been a member of the B.C. Legislature for the last twenty years, I strongly recommend that the present Principal, namely Father O'Grady, be instructed to go ahead with the arrangements he has already started and erect this new school, and I am certain if this is done there will be no regrets.

In making this recommendation to you, I assure you I do so from no selfish reason or motive but solely and only in the best interest of all parties concerned and this Sir includes Your Department.

Yours sincerely,

(Signed) J.J. Gillis.

ELECTRICAL SPECIFICATION
for
STANDARD FOUR CLASSROOM SCHOOL
FOR PROJECT NO. 864
Index No. 865

1. All clauses of the General and Labour Conditions shall apply to and govern this trade.

2. Scope of Work

The Contractor shall supply all materials required and shall install, in a thorough and workmanlike manner, a system of electric wiring as shown on accompanying electrical plan Sheet No. E1, Index No. 865.

Provide all conduit, wire, cable, fittings, panels, switches, lighting fixtures, wiring devices and all appurtenances necessary for a complete and approved system ready for operation.

3. Rules and Regulations

All work shall be carried out in accordance with the rules and regulations as set forth in the Canadian Electrical Code together with such additional regulations of the local Inspection Authorities as may be applicable. Before final payment on contract is authorized, a certificate of inspection and approval of work from the Inspection Department of the local authorities shall be submitted to the Chief Engineer. The Contractor shall file all necessary plans with the local authorities and pay all fees and take out all permits in connection therewith.

4. Plans

Electrical plan Sheet No. E1, Index No. 865, issued with these specifications, will show outlets, wire, cable and conduit sizes and other necessary details. However, outlet locations and the routing of cable and conduits shall be carefully checked, before installation, with the Engineer.
Switch outlets shall be on latch side of doors and shall be ganged where they occur together. All lettering appearing on the plan shall be considered as part of the specifications.

In all cases of discrepancies between the plans and specifications, or in cases where interpretation of the plans and/or specifications is in any way in doubt, the Contractor shall refer the matter to the Engineer. If the Contractor proceeds with the construction without getting the proper interpretation of the plans and/or specifications from the Engineer, it will be at his own risk, and he may be required to remove work which is not in accordance with the design, and will replace it. The number of conductors necessary to provide specified circuits are shown on the plan, but it shall be the responsibility of the Contractor to complete all circuits and connections irrespective of any omissions which may occur on plan detail.

5. Visit the Site

The Contractor must visit the site and see the conditions under which the work is to be done and all electrical work shall be planned and done in close cooperation with the workmen performing work of the other trades.

6. Material and Workmanship

All materials and workmanship shall be the best of their respective kinds. All pipes and fittings shall be galvanized. Lighting panels shall be galvanized and finished in black baked-on enamel. Materials shall be new and as detailed on plan and/or as herein specified. Substitutions will be permitted only by written approval of the Chief Engineer. Stabs and joists must not be notched or otherwise cut except by drilled holes centred in wood members.
7. Service

Electric service to the building will be single phase, 115/230 Volts, 3 wire, and will be run to the building from overhead secondary mains by the Power Company. Provide service standpipe and equipment as detailed on plan to receive and distribute electrical energy. Leave thirty (30) inch length of service conductors outside of service entrance head for connection by Power Company to service secondary drops from Power Company pole. Lighting panel and service switch shall be provided complete with fuses.

Mount service switch and meter, as noted on plan, and provide connections between meter and main switch. Meter will be provided by Power Company.

Ground neutral and service equipment to fulfill code requirements.

8. Wiring

Except as noted on plan and/or as herein specified the wiring shall be done in 600 volt maximum rubber insulated braid covered wire enclosed in rigid galvanized conduit concealed in ceiling, wall and floor construction. Wiring shown in basement floor slab shall be lead covered cable enclosed in rigid galvanized steel conduit of size noted on plan. Feeder from service switch to lighting panel shall be run exposed.

Terminate feeder from Heating Control Panel to hot water tank in ceiling outlet box and extend to 2 KW. and 1 KW. electric heaters and their controls using asbestos covered conductors.

All wiring shall be done according to Canadian Electrical Code regulations governing this type of installation.
9. **Painting and Labelling**

All exposed piping and fittings shall be painted two coats approved first quality paint. Inside of panels shall be touched up after installation to remove marks. Panels shall be fitted with combination lock and catch and shall be provided with index cards indicating circuit service.

10. **Electric Fixtures and Lamps**

Supply and install as specified on plan an electric luminaire on each lighting outlet complete with lamps of specified wattage. All incandescent lamps shall be inside frosted 1000 hour 115 volt Mazda quality and fluorescent lamps shall be 40 watt 2500 hour life, white (3500°K), Mazda quality.

11. **Connect up Equipment**

Heating and ventilating equipment will be provided complete with all electrical motors, heaters and required controls by others. Wiring for controls and equipment is shown on electrical plan for equipment to be provided; however, all wiring for equipment and controls supplied on the job shall be checked and all necessary changes shall be made to meet requirements to the approval of the Engineer.

The locations of all equipment shall be checked with workmen of other trades before running conduit and setting outlets.

The following equipment will be provided complete with all necessary automatic controls by others. Provide all wiring and make all electrical connections.

(a) Circulating pump on forced hot water heating system.
(b) 2 KW. and 1KW. 220 volt electric domestic hot water heaters.
(c) Exhaust fan.
(d) Draft and check regulator for combustion control.
12. Record Plans

During the progress of the work the Contractor shall keep a record of all changes to the original plans and shall forward to the Chief Engineer, upon completion, a blue print showing all changes clearly marked in red. A blue print for this purpose will be provided upon request.

13. Cutting

All cutting of finishing woodwork and ceiling and wall finishes for the installation of lighting fixture outlets and other wiring devices shall be carried out by workmen skilled in this work.

14. Guarantee

The Contractor will be called upon to guarantee his work for a period of one year after date of acceptance. He shall make good or replace any defect arising in his work during that period at his own expense as soon as practicable after being notified in writing that such defect exists.
PLUMBING AND DRAINAGE

1. SCOPE OF WORK

This specification and the accompanying plans are intended to provide for a complete plumbing and drainage installation and fire protection service in the School Building and the Contractor shall furnish all material and labour of every description required therefor for its proper completion.

2. VISIT THE SITE

The Contractor shall visit the site and see the conditions under which the work will be done and govern himself accordingly.

3. RULES AND REGULATIONS

All work shall be done in accordance with rules, regulations and recommendations as may be laid down by local or other authorities controlling such work. The contractor shall file all necessary plans with such authorities and pay all necessary fees for permits, etc., as may be required.

4. MATERIALS AND WORKMANSHIP

All materials shall be new and the best of their respective kinds.

All work shall be executed in a neat and workmanlike manner by workmen skilled in this trade, and special attention shall be given exposed work so that it be neatly erected with pipes plumb and true.

5. EXCAVATING AND BACKFILLING

Contractor shall do all necessary excavating and backfill after same incident to the installation of his work. Backfilling will be done in shallow layers and be thoroughly puddled and tamped.

6. ROUGHING IN

Furnish and install complete lines of drains, vents, wastes, etc., of required sizes. All fixtures shall be back vented as noted on drawings or as may be required.

Install water lines and make all necessary connections to fixtures. Each plumbing fixture shall have air chambers installed on both hot and cold water lines, such air chambers being not less than 12" long. All branch lines shall be separately valved.

7. DRAINAGE UNDERFLOOR

All soil and drain pipe below the basement floor shall be extra heavy cast iron with bell and spigot ends. The inside of such pipe shall be clean and free from rust and shall be thoroughly oiled inside and out to give a protective coating.
8. EXPOSED DRAINS

All soil and drain pipe above the basement floor shall be medium weight cast iron with bell and spigot ends, and shall be clean and free from rust and shall be thoroughly oiled inside and out.

9. JOINTS

All joints in cast iron pipe shall be made with oakum and molten lead and thoroughly caulked.

All joints in waste or vent piping shall be made with long sweep recessed cast iron drain fittings.

Where screwed joints are used for soil or waste pipe, they shall have a smooth continuous interior surface.

Joints to fixtures shall be made with proper gaskets and ferrules as required.

Water closets shall be connected to soil drains by means of brass or cast iron floor flange not less than 3/16 inch thick with caulked joints to cast iron soil drain and with approved packing ring.

10. GRADING OF PIPES

Waste and soil piping shall be graded in the direction of flow with a pitch of not less than 1/4 inch to the foot unless otherwise noted on plan or specified.

All horizontal branches of vent piping shall be graded with the same pitch as above toward the fixtures.

All horizontal branches of hot and cold water piping shall be so graded that they may be completely drained through drip connections installed at necessary points.

11. CLEANOUTS

Provide and set fittings in all drain and soil pipes for cleanouts at all points where obstruction might occur and at the ends of all long horizontal pipes and all points required by-laws, or as directed or shown on drawings. Also install Barrett cleanouts at foot of all stacks.

Cleanouts shall be full size for pipes up to 4" diameter and not less than 4" for larger pipes. In horizontal runs they shall be closed gas-tight with heavy brass ferrules caulked in and capped with screw cap, and where on drains underground shall finish flush with floor.

12. WATER PIPING

Cold water piping included in this contract shall begin at a point 3'-0" outside of the building, or otherwise as noted on plans.

All domestic hot and cold water piping in this building shall be galvanized steel standard weight, put together with galvanized screwed malleable iron fittings. No cold water piping shall be laid in any floor slab. Water service pipes within the basement shall be covered as hereafter described, and exposed to view on external walls and below ceilings.
13. **FIRE PROTECTION SERVICE**

Provide and install where indicated on plan F cold water branches from main to hose rack connections. Each of these branches shall be valved close to hose rack. Provide suitable couplings to connect hose to stand pipe.

Supply and mount on suitable brackets approved type hose racks including 50'-0" of unlined linen hose with suitable nozzle, for inside service. One rack assembly to be located in each of the following rooms, where shown on plan. Manual Training Room, Cooking and Sewing Room (in Basement) and Hall on First Floor. Mount racks 7'-0" up from floor. See drawings for further details.

14. **HANGERS**

Standing runs of cast iron pipe shall be securely fixed in position by means of strong iron supports placed immediately below the hubs.

Horizontal runs of cast iron pipe shall be supported by means of band iron hanger rings and 3/8 inch rod supports from the ceiling.

Vertical runs of water pipe shall be supported by means of iron supports same as for cast iron pipes.

Horizontal runs of water piping shall be supported at 8'-0" intervals with rod and ring hangers. No grabbler bar hangers allowed.

15. **VALVES**

Valves generally shall be gate valves unless otherwise mentioned 2" and under shall be all brass. Over 2" shall be iron body valves with bronze trimmings.

16. **FLASHING**

Where vent stacks project through the roof they shall be suitably cap flashed with 5 lb. lead to make a satisfactory and watertight job.

17. **TESTING**

Water Piping: Contractor will test all water piping before covering, using cold water at 100 lb. pressure.

Drains and vent system shall be tested for leakage by being filled with water to roof level.

Underfloor drains shall be tested for grade using a standard billiard ball.

On completion of the work the sanitary system shall be submitted to a smoke test.

18. **SLEEVES AND ESCUTCHEONS**

Where exposed pipes pass through floors, partitions or ceilings in finished rooms, they shall be provided with galvanized iron sleeves 1/2 inch larger than the pipe and cast iron or chrome plated pressed steel escutcheons either of the one piece or split ring type.
19. PLUMBING FIXTURES

The Contractor shall furnish and install with all necessary fittings and connections to water supply and drainage system, plumbing fixtures in accordance with plumbing fixture specifications.

20. DOMESTIC HOT WATER STORAGE TANK AND HEATERS

The Contractor shall provide and install on suitable stand, a galvanized steel storage tank of the capacity noted on plumbing plan, built for 100 pounds working pressure. He shall make all necessary water connections generally as shown on plan, including all valves, unions, etc.

The Contractor shall also provide and install in positions approximately as shown on detail 2 immersion type electric water heaters of the capacities noted, complete with aqua-statics suitable for this service.

21. COVERING

All exposed cold water piping, unless otherwise noted, shall be covered 1" thick with anti-sweat wool felt sectional covering consisting of two 1/2 inch layers, each of which shall have been so fabricated by its manufacturer as to have a double thickness of asphalt paper both inside and out, stapled in place and jacketed with factory cotton pasted on. Risers in partitions will not be covered unless noted on plan.

All hot water supply and recirculating pipes, unless otherwise noted, shall be covered with 1 inch thick 4-ply asbestos air cell sectional pipe covering carefully butted and fitted around hangers, etc., and jacketed with factory cotton pasted on.

Elbows, tees, valves, etc., shall be covered with asbestos cement and covered with cotton as specified for pipes.

Hot water storage tank shall be covered with 1 inch thick 4-ply asbestos airsell blocks, wired in place, and plastered 1 inch thick with long fibre asbestos cement applied in two coats, the last coat to be tempered with 10 per cent Portland cement and trowelled to a smooth finish. Paint two coats with waterproof paint of an approved colour.

22. HOSE BIBBS

Provide and install in Boiler Room where shown on plumbing plan, one 1/2 inch angle pattern hose valve with renewable seat and tee handle.

23. FLOOR DRAINS

Provide floor drain in Boiler Room where shown. It shall be cast iron with anti-tilting flat round grate with integral receptor.
PLUMBING FIXTURES

1. GENERAL

The Contractor shall furnish and install ready for use the following plumbing fixtures, the locations of which, as hereafter numbered, are indicated by the corresponding numbers on plans. All exposed work, brackets, etc., not plated shall be enamelled two coats with white enamel. Plated work shall be of best quality chromium plate or brass, unless otherwise noted; if chromium plating cannot be obtained nickel plating will be acceptable, but the Contractor shall definitely state the plating included when submitting his tender.

2. MANUFACTURERS' PLATE NUMBERS AND ILLUSTRATIONS

The Contractor shall submit in triplicate to the Chief Engineer, Engineering and Construction Division, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ontario, for approval, a list of the Plumbing Fixtures and Fittings with Manufacturers' Plate Numbers and Illustrations that he proposes to supply. Fixtures and Fittings shall be as specified consistent with such restrictions as may apply; for any such not obtainable the Contractor shall submit obtainable and acceptable alternatives subject to the final approval of the Department.

3. CLOSET COMBINATION: 1 required.

Vitreous china reverse trap elongated rim bowl with cast iron floor flange asbestos gasket and china bolt caps.

Vitreous china low down closet tank with silent ball cock and 3/8 inch chrome plated angle supply with rough plated brass stop and wall flange.

Black Bonalite open front seat cover with plated bar hinge.

4. LAVATORY: 1 required.

20" x 18" Vitreous china wall lavatory with 6" high integral back, rectangular basin, and anti-splash lip on concealed wall hanger.

Fit with heavy duty plated brass hot and cold indexed self-closing faucets, chain stay, 3/8" x 6" plated supply uprights with reducers, 3/8" rough plated brass angle stops and plated wall flanges, 1-1/4" cast-brass adjustable "P" trap to wall with backing gland, screwed female outlet and plated wall flange 1-1/4" plated and polished P.O. plug with rubber stopper, and plated brass chain with spot welded ring on stopper.

5. KITCHEN SINK: 4 required.

18" x 30" x 8" deep Vitreous china flat rim sink with integral overflow and drainboard. Fit with plated swinging spout, connected to 1/2" plated hot and cold supplies with 1/2" rough plated angle stops, with wall flanges. Provide grease trap equal in manufacture to the "Fleming" no. F-2015 having a grease capacity of 15 lbs. and 75 gal. water per hour with 1-1/2" inlet and outlet as supplied by the Acme Co. of Canada, Ltd.
HOT WATER HEATING

1. SCOPE OF WORK

This specification and the accompanying plans are intended to provide for a closed system of forced hot water heating complete in every respect, for the Day School. The Contractor shall take all measurements at the building, set out all work, and be responsible for the accuracy of same. He shall provide all labour, transportation material and plant, and give his personal and constant attention to the work and be responsible for any damage done.

2. VISIT THE SITE

The Contractor shall visit the site and see the conditions under which the work will be done.

3. MATERIALS AND WORKMANSHIP

All materials shall be new and the best of their respective kinds, sound and free from defects.

Workmanship shall be of the best, and all work shall be done in a neat manner with due attention being given to the grading of pipes and making connections. All connections shall be made so as to permit free and unobstructed flow at all times, and adequate provision shall be made for expansion. All pipes shall be carefully reamed after cutting and the Contractor will be held strictly responsible for any failures due to neglecting this phase of the work.

4. RADIATION

Furnish and install where shown on plans, cast iron free standing radiators of a design equal to "Corto" as made by Dominion Radiator Co., Ltd., or the "Copley" as made by Gurney Foundry Co., Ltd. These radiators shall be suitable for hot water heating and shall be of sizes as noted on plans.

5. RADIATOR VALVES

Furnish and install on flow end of all radiators, brass globe valves with solid wheel handles, of approved manufacture.

6. VALVES GENERALLY

All valves, except for radiators, shall be gate valves, 2" and under, all brass; over 2" iron body bronze fitted of a type and make satisfactory to the Chief Engineer, Engineering and Construction Division, or his representative.

7. AUTOMATIC AIR VENTS

Furnish and install where indicated on plans and where elsewhere deemed necessary, automatic air vents equal to Bell and Gossett type as made by S.A. Armstrong, Co., of Canada Ltd., Toronto, Ontario. Air Vents shall have heavy cast iron bodies seamless copper floats and needle type discharge valve.
Vents shall be of sufficient capacity to positively and quickly relieve the air from all parts of the system; vent outlets shall be carried to convenient drains or where directed.

8. PIPING

All flow and return piping shall be standard black steel pipe put together with cast iron screwed fittings and with unions, screwed or flanged, where required. All piping throughout the work must be carefully reamed before assembly, and pipe compound shall be applied to pipe threads only.

Piping shall be run substantially as shown on plans so that there will be a free and easy circulation to each radiator. All flow connections to radiators above the mains shall be taken off top of main at 45 degrees. All flow connections to radiators below the mains shall be taken off bottom of main at 45 degrees. All return connections shall be connected into side of return main. Provide and install drain-offs on all connections to radiators below the mains and at all other low points, so that the system can be completely drained, providing all necessary valves.

Where risers occur, they shall be concealed in partitions or furred in as indicated on plans.

9. GRADING OF PIPING

Flow and return mains shall be graded \( \frac{1}{2} \)" in 10'-0" unless otherwise noted. Laterals to radiators and risers shall be graded \( \frac{1}{2} \)" inch per foot back to mains.

10. HANGERS

Pipe suspended from ceiling shall be supported by ring hangers with \( \frac{1}{2} \)" inch diameter rods spaced not more than 8'-0" apart.

Pipe carried on wall shall be supported by bracket type hangers securely fastened to wall. Careful attention shall be given in locating these brackets, in respect to the grade of the pipe. Brackets to be spaced not more than 8'-0" apart.

No grabbler bar hangers will be accepted for any part of the work.

11. SLEEVES AND ESCUTCHEONS

Pipes passing through walls or floors shall have galvanized flanged floor sleeves \( \frac{1}{2} \)" inch larger than the pipe installed during the construction of the building.

A cast iron or chrome plated pressed steel escutcheon of the one piece or split ring type shall be provided and installed where any pipe enters or emerges from a ceiling, floor or wall.

12. COVERING

All flow and return mains, except where otherwise noted on plan, shall be covered with 4 ply 1 inch thick asbestos air cell sectional pipe covering, carefully butted and fitted around hangers where such occur, and finished with factory cotton pasted on. Elbows, tees, valves, etc., shall be covered with long fibre asbestos cement, and wrapped with cotton as specified for pipes. Flanges and unions shall not be covered.
Boiler shall be covered with 1 inch thick 4 ply asbestos air cell blocks wired in place, and plastered 1 inch thick with long fibre asbestos cement, applied in two coats; the last coat to be tempered with 10 per cent Portland cement and trowelled to a smooth finish. Paint two coats with waterproof paint of an approved colour.

13. BOILER

Furnish and install where shown on plans, one boiler having capacities as noted on drawing. Boiler shall be cast iron square sectional hot water type and equal to the Viking as made by the Warden-King Co., of Canada Ltd., and shall be suitable for burning coal, hand fired.

The boiler shall be fitted with thermometer, pressure gauge, direct-acting aqua-stat and reverse-acting aqua-stat, located as shown on detail. Provide draft and check regulator and mount on basement ceiling above boiler. This unit to be complete with linkage, operating mechanism and all miscellaneous auxiliaries as hereinafter specified.

Provide valved drain-out connection from boiler, also pressure regulating and pressure relief valves on cold water supply to boiler generally as shown, and extend flow and return connections therefrom to the heating systems all as outlined on plans. The Contractor shall provide one complete set of firing tools including 16" scoop shovel.

14. CUSHION TANK

Provide and install close to basement ceiling over boiler one cushion tank of a size as noted on drawings, and built to Inter-provincial Regulations governing pressure vessels. Tank to be equipped with gauge glass, combination air charger and tank drainer, and supported from ceiling by 2 heavy strap iron hangers.

15. SMOKE BREECHING

Furnish and erect smoke pipe from boiler of a size and gauge noted on plan, complete with connection to boiler. Provide and install one close fitting, manually operated damper in horizontal run in smoke pipe.

16. CIRCULATING PUMP

Provide and install near boiler, where shown on plan, circulating pump of a size and capacity as noted on drawing. Pump shall be equal to those made by Minneapolis-Honeywell or Bell and Gossett type as made by the S.A. Armstrong Co., of Canada Ltd., Toronto, and shall have horizontal type direct connected motor of size and electrical characteristics noted on drawing. Provide a valved by-pass with reducers, as shown on drawing.

17. CONTROL EQUIPMENT

This Contractor shall provide and mount where shown in Class room approximately 5'-0" above floor, one heavy duty line voltage mercury switch type thermostat equal to Minneapolis-Honeywell No.442A series 40, arranged to start circulating pump when room temperature falls. Provide and install on boiler one immersion type reverse-acting aqua-stat equal to M-H No.444BE series 40 which shall be wired into thermostat-pump circuit so as to override room thermostat and start pump when boiler water temperature reaches 180 degrees F.
Contractor shall also provide and install on boiler where shown one direct-acting immersion type aqua-stat equal to M-H. No. L448 series 40. Provide and locate on basement ceiling above boiler one 2 position spring return type damper and check regulator complete with all operating mechanism including linkage, pulleys, brackets, etc. This unit shall be equal to Minneapolis-Honeywell M405A series 40. The purpose of the direct acting aqua-stat and the draft and check regulator is to provide a means of combustion control. This Contractor shall, as mentioned previously, install these items. See Electrical Specification for wiring instructions.
VENTILATION

BOILER ROOM, SCHOOL BUILDING.

18. FAN AND MOTOR

Provide and install on steel brackets where shown in the boiler room, one centrifugal type exhaust fan, direct connected to 1/6 H.P. 1/110/60 A.C. standard motor. The fan shall have a capacity to deliver 433 cfm. against 1/4" static pressure. Fan inlet shall be left open.

Provide manual motor starting switch with thermal overload protection and mount same 5'-0" above floor on wall under motor.

19. AUTOMATIC SHUTTERS AND DUCT WORK

Provide and install where shown on plan 10" x 10" standard automatic discharge louvres. Also provide and install 10" x 8" galvanized iron duct between fan and discharge louvres. Duct shall be made of 28 V.S. gauge and shall have cross broken panels to give rigidity. Longitudinal joints shall be lock seamed. Dear Mr. Bethune:

I received your letter in answer to mine to the Minister yesterday and want to thank you for your reply, however, although no fault of yours, I am far from satisfied with the information received and would like to have a direct reply to my letter from the Minister as soon as he returns to the office and finds it convenient to do so.

I saw in some of the daily newspapers that Honourable Mr. Glenn had retired on account of bad health. I was very sorry to hear that and I hope a well earned rest will bring him back to his usual good health.

In case Mr. Glenn does not return to the Office, I would be very grateful to you if you would hand my letter to the new Minister. I have not seen many of the newspapers of late due to the floods and did not hear of anyone appointed in his place.

I was pleased to hear that the new school block was going to be constructed, but I am not at all satisfied at the set up. Your letter states that it is to be built by day labour, employing Mr. Robert Swan as foreman-carpenter, all very well. Then you state that the Departmental Purchasing Agent will purchase the materials.

This means of course that the Department has a list of what I shall call "approved dealers" and that this purchasing agent whoever he is will have to deal and buy through them.
I say this because it is the usual way the department has acted for some time and it is anything but an economic or satisfactory way. Personally although a strong Liberal in politics, I am very much opposed to such a method of buying and acting.

In the present case, the foreman would have to hire his help in much the same way, he would have to consult some local person before he hired anyone and would not be free to hire or discharge as he sees fit and as he should. That is the way it works. If he needed anything, any special material, he would have to wait until the Purchasing Agent secured same from one of the boys and in the meantime the work would of course slow down. Many other things enter into this system that I need not mention.

As far as buying rough or prepared lumber from the mill at the school operated by the Principal, Father O'Grady, I am not a bit worried because he can sell his lumber, rough and prepared at ease, but I am worried at the latest change as stated in your letter.

Why in the name of common sense, yes and in the name of all that is fair and economical should not this building be constructed as originally planned.

The forty thousand dollars has been appropriated, that means the department feels it will cost that much and Father O'Grady, the principal of the school is prepared to construct this block for that amount. He may lose or gain a little, personally knowing him as I do, I believe he will have a little left over but I am not sure of that, but admit he has, it will not be used for him, or anyone else, but the school. That is if he has any left over it will be used for needed improvements at the school. If there is any doubt about that, then let us forget about the whole thing.

I tried to speak to Father O'Grady this morning on the long distance telephone but could not locate him. I was going to ask him what he intended doing, but if he wanted my advice about it, I would advise him to have nothing whatever to do with this block unless
the contract was given to him and allow him to hire anyone he liked and fire anyone who did not give satisfaction and to buy wherever he felt he could get the best and quickest action.

I do know that he accepted the word of those in authority in the department at Ottawa when he was told to return to B.C. and make preparations to construct this block. He intended starting building on the first of May so that he would have the use of this block for the first of Sept., and he even made arrangement about engaging four extra teachers but of course the building will not be ready by then under the proposed setup. I am very sorry to make this letter so long but I wanted the department to know that in taking up this matter, I am only trying to protect them from any future criticism which I am sure will occur if the construction of this building follows the latest method as you suggest in your letter.

Yours sincerely,

J. J. Gillis, M.D.

Dear Father O'Grady:

I sincerely regret the misunderstanding which has arisen with regard to the construction of the classroom block at the Kamloops Residential School.

During the past year it has become increasingly difficult to get authority for the granting of contracts which do not conform with the Public Works Act.

As you probably know, this Act requires that all contracts in excess of $5,000.00 be advertised for and the contract awarded on the basis of the tenders thus received. This is a very slow process and during the war, it was possible because of the emergency, to award contracts directly. As I pointed out previously, this procedure has become increasingly difficult and in fact almost impossible.

Therefore, in view of the need for your classroom block being completed as soon as possible, it would be preferable to build it on a day labour basis. We have received the details of Mr. Swan's qualifications and are quite prepared to pay him on a day labour basis. We are also prepared to purchase from your mill as much of the rough lumber as possible and also the beams which you have cut.

Dear Doctor Gillis:

I have for acknowledgment your two letters of June 16 and June 21 with regard to the construction of a new classroom block at the Kamloops Indian Residential School.

When Father O'Grady visited the Department last summer, the matter of a new classroom block at his school was discussed with him. In order that he might be aware of the type of building proposed, he was provided with a set of blueprints of the building. A meeting was also arranged with the engineers of our Lands and Development Services Branch so that they could get as much information as possible from him with regard to the electrical and heating specifications required for the new building.

During the winter these specifications were prepared and were recently mailed to our Indian Commissioner for British Columbia.

On April 8, 1948, the following telegram was received from Father O'Grady:

"Would appreciate being advised if classroom block for Kamloops Indian School is approved and if we may proceed with its construction."

He was sent the following telegram in answer:

"Do not proceed with erection of classroom block until you receive specific instructions from Indian Commissioner Armill."
On April 17, the Reverend Father O'Grady submitted a tender for $40,000.00 for the construction of this building to our Indian Commissioner for British Columbia. At that time the electrical and heating specifications had not been finished. Therefore Father O'Grady did not have the complete drawings, specifications and other information upon which to properly base his tender.

Our Indian Commissioner for British Columbia was of course aware of the Public Works Act which requires that all construction work in excess of $5,000.00 be advertised for and tenders received in the usual manner. He was also advised that the matter would have to be discussed with officials of the Lands and Development Services Branch before a decision could be reached.

It was realized that if tenders were called for, there would very likely be some considerable delay before the actual construction work was started. These tenders could not be called for until the electrical and plumbing specifications referred to above, were ready. These drawings and specifications were only finished recently and were mailed to our Indian Commissioner for British Columbia on June 11.

Therefore, in deciding to hire Mr. Swan and to erect the building on a day labour basis, the department was attempting to expedite the building of the classroom block by hiring a man whom Reverend Father O'Grady had recommended so highly. In fact, we had hoped to complete the building in time for school opening in September. We instructed Indian Commissioner Arnell that we desired to purchase from Father O'Grady the timbers and other forms which he had prepared.

We have sent letters by airmail to both Reverend Father O'Grady and to our Indian Commissioner for B.C., as it is understood that they have had several discussions concerning the erection of this classroom block. I will write you again as soon as I hear from them.

Yours faithfully,

J. J. Gillis, Esq., M.D., M.L.A.,
Merritt, British Columbia.

I desire to refer to my letter of June 29th and previous correspondence in connection with the erection of a class room block at the Kamloops Indian Residential School.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Re: Erection of Class room Block at the Kamloops Residential School - our requisition of September 14th, 1948.

As requested by telephone, I attach copy of letter which was signed by the Minister in connection with the erection of the above mentioned building.

Please note the under-lined portion on page two of the attached letter.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Enclosure.

PP/MGD
Further to my letter of September 7th, we have not made as much progress in connection with the above-mentioned building as we had hoped, due partly to delay in securing sufficient details with regard to material requirements, but even so, the delays experienced so far will not likely have any effect on the progress made in the actual erection of the building for the reason that the earliest delivery possible on the required steel beams is six weeks.

A quotation from Dominion Bridge Co. Ltd. on the steel required at a cost of $1380.00 f.o.b. Vancouver, is enclosed and I would ask that the order be placed with them at the earliest possible date as delivery is quoted as six weeks from receipt of the Order. I may say I have discussed this matter with Father O'Grady recently and he is not greatly concerned with the delay in the delivery of the steel for the reason that this will only temporarily halt the construction of the building, and the most important thing which is being proceeded with at the moment, is to have the cement completed before cold weather sets in.

For your information, I would advise:

1. Plans and specifications were submitted to Sigurdson Millwork Co. Ltd., Vancouver, who have prepared a bill of material and tendered on supply of same. Their tender is not typed and in places it is almost illegible to a layman, consequently, I have asked them to submit another tender in duplicate which will be forwarded in a day or so to enable the Purchasing...
Agent to place the order.

2. Reinforcing wire and reinforcing rods were ordered from Evans, Coleman and Evans and have been delivered to the site.

3. 14 kegs of nails were ordered from Gordon and Belyea Ltd. and part of this order has been delivered to the site. We have yet to order 5 more kegs of nails but as the nail factory in Vancouver is closed down, these are not immediately available.

4. With my letter of September 7th, I enclosed lists of materials required, one of which listed the material to be shipped from Vancouver including lumber for ceiling joists and rafters, insulation, asbestos shingles, etc. We have called for tenders on the supply of this material but as there is some confliction between this list and the list quoted on by Sigurdson Millwork, some revision will be necessary before the tenders can be forwarded to you in proper form for submission to the Purchasing Agent.

5. Superintendent Bruce was asked to submit specifications on the wiring, plumbing and heating to Kamloops contractors and I understand from Father O'Grady that we may expect to receive tenders on these installations within a few days.

6. Father O'Grady has suggested, and I concur, that it would be desirable to finish the exterior walls of the building with Insul-brick Siding rather than asbestos shingles. Mr. Swan is preparing an estimate for the quantity of siding required and tenders will be called for on this item.

It will be apparent from the above that the matter of the construction of this classroom block is in hand and the most important thing at the moment is the placing of the order for the steel beams.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Mr. Bruce:

Re: Heating Classroom Block

The Classroom Block, which is being constructed in connection with this School, calls for its own heating system being installed on the basement floor. This would be ideal were the building constructed as a unit apart from any other School but where it is attached to a Residential School it would be much more economical and practical to have the heating boiler installed in the boiler room of the main building where there is ample space and large storage facilities for coal. It would require, of course, a coal stoker.

Besides decreased operating costs and added facilities for firing the distinct advantage of having the heating boiler installed in the main building is that space for two more classrooms would be gained on the basement floor of the classroom block. The basement floor would be divided into four rooms of exactly the same size as the four classrooms above and wooden beams with truss rods could then be used instead of the steel beams which may be more difficult to obtain now because of recent curtailments on the import of steel. Quite a considerable saving could be effected in using wooden instead of steel beams.

I would appreciate your asking the Department for a decision in this matter as soon as possible.

Yours sincerely,

I feel that both these suggestions should be reviewed by the engineers who designed the building and that we should be guided by their recommendation. An early decision would be desirable however inasmuch the order has been placed for the steel beams.
