Colonel Neary:

Kamloops Indian Residential School:

On the Remembrance Day holiday I accompanied Mr. Supt. Bruce to this school, the largest concentration of Indian pupils:

Laundry:
The installation includes an assembly line of washers, extractors and driers aligned: W E D D W E W
Heat is provided by a 52 H.P. boiler which furnishes steam to the washers instead of hot water. Two steam pressers are also in use. The whole effect is to reduce the institutional washing to a chore that is disposed of quickly instead of consuming the disproportionate time spent on it in other schools. Facilities exist for the teaching of washing and ironing on a home scale.

Kitchen: Here, too, the space and equipment are in better ratio than in schools with a hundred fewer pupils. The dishwashing apparatus and procedure is almost, but not quite, up to the standard aimed at in the 1950 Ontario requirements.

Dining Room: The original large hall has been divided into two parts, as this is said to make supervision easier. The tableware and cutlery are adequate in quantity and of superior quality.

Dormitories: Some congestion is presently being experienced but will be relieved when the additional building now under construction is ready some months hence.

Washrooms: Not inspected. The boys' are in process of improvement.

Classrooms: The schedule and size of classes will appear from the age-grade tables which have been forwarded. My attention was invited to the high school classroom, equipped with excellent desks made on the premises. The teacher emphasised the urgent need of further equipment for the teaching of science. If the pupils are not to attend Kamloops High School, there will have to be more materials and apparatus in their own school.

New Building: This is still at the basement level, and its final form is in question. The principal stressed the advantages of several variations from the original design. These are:
Locate the heating unit in the main building and use for other purposes the considerable space saved. He states that competent advisers may visit his home.
Provide toilets for the children so that they will not have to visit the main building.
Do away with the rear entrance, using the space saved for staff quarters, and substitute entrance-exits for the children at the ends of the building, opening into the cloakrooms.
Eliminate the electrically-heated water-tank and pipe hot water from the main building.
Lighting fixtures to be of the fluorescent type.
I suggested that since so many radical changes are involved that he should submit to you as soon as possible well-annotated sketches.

C.A.F. Clark

Ottawa, December 18, 1948.

Re: Classroom Block - Kamloops Indian Residential School, B.C.

With reference to Major MacKay's memorandum of November 25th bearing your notation of the 27th ultimo together with attached quotations in connection with the above, you are advised as follows.

We are unable to comment on the tenders received for the heating system as it is evident that the prices include for additional work not called for in the specification or shown on the plan. This has been brought to the attention of the Indian Affairs Branch verbally, and they are to advise us as to the extent of the extra work involved, at which time it may be possible for us to offer intelligent comment.

Tenders with reference to the plumbing were received from Carr and Son and H. Giddens and Sons, both of Kamloops, B.C. Carr and Son quotation of $3,960.00 appears excessive for the work outlined on the plan and specification.

Giddens and Sons' quotation of $1,035.00 is given "as per plan". They also quote an alternative figure of $1,635.00 based on piping the domestic hot and cold water from the boiler room of the Residential School to an arrangement not shown on the plan.

If the plumbing is to be installed in accordance with our plan and specification, it is suggested that the Indian Affairs Branch would be well advised to accept the tender of $1,035.00 submitted by Giddens and Sons, which seems to us to be fair and reasonable.

No mention is made in either tender of a septic tank. It is pointed out that our plan is an adaption of a standard arrangement and shows septic tank details for use in areas where a tank is necessary. The plan shows the main house drain and incoming water line capped just outside the building wall for extension by others. It is assumed that the Indian Affairs Branch will arrange to have these lines extended and connected to sources on the property outside the terms of the contract.

The following tenders on electrical work were received:

H. Giddens and Sons, Kamloops, B.C. ............ $1,762.00
C.L. Wain and Son, Kamloops, B.C. .............. $1,641.25
Fernie Bros., Kamloops, B.C. ................... $2,700.00
Pinn Electric Co., Kamloops, B.C. ............. $1,656.00

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
H. Giddens quoted, in addition to the above prices, for electrical work if certain proposed heating changes are made to the school making eight (8) full classrooms. We have no information concerning such a proposal, and we will comment only on the above prices which are based on our plans and specifications Index No. 863 for the above.

If the Indian Affairs Branch decide on the proposals referred to, which would affect the number of classrooms, our plans would require revisions, and all firms quoting should be requested to retender on the electrical work. We would then be in a position to comment on the quotations submitted based on our revised plans.

The lowest tender received for doing the electrical work was submitted by C.L. Wain and Son in the amount of $1,641.25. This price, in our opinion, is reasonable, and it would appear satisfactory if the Indian Affairs Branch accept the tender of this firm.

We are enclosing herewith, for transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch, tenders referred to this Division by Acting Director Major MacKay for comment.

Chief Engineer.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

You will recall that Father O'Grady during his recent visit, discussed mainly the building of the classroom block. Could you please advise whether he ever mentioned to you the building of a greenhouse.

It was not mentioned to me but in conversation with Mr. Phelan a passing remark was made. Both Mr. Phelan and I feel that no encouragement should be given to Father O'Grady to press such a project at the present time. We feel that he has ample buildings to care for and maintain at the present time without adding still another.

We have had considerable grief in the past with the operation of greenhouses at residential schools and they have not always been very successful. One exception is, of course, the St. George's Residential School at Lytton, British Columbia.

I would like to discuss the matter of the buildings at the Kamloops Residential School with you when an opportunity presents itself.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Re: Kamloops Residential School
Sports Equipment

Enclosed is a requisition from the Principal of the above mentioned school for sports equipment. Tenders have been received from three firms and the total cost of the items requested is approximately $400.00. In view of this large amount and the Department's policy of not supplying hardball equipment it is recommended that the items 3 dozen baseball bats and 4 dozen baseballs be deleted. This would result in a reduction of approximately $145.00. It is also felt that the number of softball bats could be reduced to one dozen.

The total cost of the equipment after the above deletions will be approximately $235.00 and it is recommended that this amount be authorized.

The present enrolment at the above school is approximately 335.

Dear Sirs:

We take pleasure in submitting our estimate on supplying hot water heating system as per plans for the sum of Six thousand, eight hundred and ten dollars ($6,810.00).

To remove the boiler from the new school and install in the boiler room at the Residential school we would carry a 2 1/2" hot water main and return from the old boiler room to the new building. Install two 2 1/2" circulating pumps with valves and by-passes. One pump would be operated at one time, the other pump would be a stand by pump in case of a break down. Increasing the boiler size by one section for domestic hot water supply and installing one indirect hot water heater, 400 gal. per hour. This hot water boiler would operate automatically summer and winter and supply hot water to the Residential school and to the new classrooms. We would cover the return mains with four ply asbestos covering, install mains in cedar box between new building and old building. We would install a 100 lb. Iron Fireman coal stoker fully automatic. We would also recommend that the chimney which is to be built in the new school be built in the corner of the old boiler house so that the new boiler would have a separate chimney. If these heating proposals are accepted there would be an extra cost on the heating plant of Four thousand, one hundred and forty-seven dollars ($4,147.00) making a total of the heating Ten thousand, nine hundred and fifty seven dollars ($10,957.00).

We would install plumbing as per plan for One thousand, thirty-five dollars ($1,035.00). If the proposed alterations are made to the boiler house we will pipe the hot and cold water from the old building to the new school building carrying our hot and cold water pipes in the same ditch as the steam mains.
We would also install a circulating pump in the old boiler house and supply constant hot water to the new building. This will increase the plumbing cost by Six hundred dollars ($600.00) making the total plumbing One thousand, six hundred and thirty-five dollars ($1,635.00).

Our price for wiring the new school as per plans would be One thousand, seven hundred and sixty-two dollars ($1,762.00). If the proposed heating changes are made to the school making eight full classrooms. Our price would be with forty-eight fluorescent fixtures 4 tube, 50 watt complete with installation and fixtures for Three thousand, five hundred and fifty-one dollars ($3,551.00). Subsequent to the receipt of your memorandum, Indian Commissioner Arneil and Reverend Father O'Grady, Principal of the Kamloops School, were in Ottawa and conferred with our officials. Both the gentlemen just mentioned expressed the definite opinion that the heating system should be installed in the main building, that lavatory facilities should be provided in the classroom block, and fluorescent light fixtures should be installed in the classroom. As a result of this discussion, Indian Commissioner Arneil was instructed to obtain new tenders, and I enclose these numbered from 8 to 14 inclusive.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Dudley,

In our Appropriation for the fiscal year 1937-38, the following items were included for the Kamloops Indian Residential School:

Installation septic tank - $2,000.

Miscellaneous repairs - 200.

You will note, on this file, a copy of a recent letter from Dr. P. S. Tennant, Medical Officer, Kamloops, B. C.

The reports received from the Indian Agent and the Medical Officer during the past two or three years indicate that the present sewage disposal system at the Kamloops Residential School is not sufficiently large to do the work required.

I feel that it is most important that something should be done to improve the sewage disposal system at this school and I recommend that the necessary action be taken in this regard at the earliest possible date.

In addition to the current file, I am sending you the previous file with a letter turned out showing that the sewage disposal system has been unsatisfactory for some time.

Chief, Training Division.

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, May 2, 1949.

Re: Classroom Block,
Kamloops Indian Residential School,
Kamloops, British Columbia.

With reference to Major Mackay's memorandum of April 11th bearing your marginal notation of the 13th instant, together with attached tenders numbered 1 to 14 inclusive in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

Principal Father O'Grady visited Ottawa last December and conferred with officers of this Division with regard to numerous changes to the layout of the classroom block. Such changes, if carried out, would affect the mechanical, electrical and structural layout. The Indian Affairs Branch when verbally informed, stated that they would advise this Division officially if the changes requested by the Principal, received their approval.

We received no advice that the alterations have been approved. The subsequent tenders numbered 8 to 14 inclusive with reference to the heating, plumbing and electrical work, are based on the proposed alterations, and since we have no record as to the extent of the alterations involved, it is not possible to offer worthwhile comment on either the heating or the electrical prices.

Following a recent discussion with Indian Affairs officials, Col. Neary requested that we comment on the plumbing tenders at this time and that the heating and electrical comment be deferred until such time as definite information with regard to the changes, could be obtained.

It is expected that an officer from this Division will be making an inspection trip in the near future, and that at such time he can call at Kamloops and obtain the data required.

In the meantime, the two tenders covering the plumbing, are based on the proposed changes and are listed below:

Giddens and Sons...........$3,525.00
Carr and Son................$5,316.00

Both the above tenders are based on supplying the extra fixtures required by the proposed changes. In our opinion the tender of Giddens and Sons covers the plumbing requirements and is the most favourable. It is suggested that the Indian Affairs Branch would be well advised to accept this tender.

We are returning herewith the tenders accompanying Major Mackay's memorandum.

You will be further advised regarding the heating and electrical tenders when we are in a position to comment with authority.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Arrangements have been completed to have Mr. A.H. Hargreaves, the heating engineer of the Lands & Development Services Branch at Ottawa, visit certain schools in British Columbia. He will arrive in your province either the last week in May or the first week in June. As soon as we know the definite date, you will be advised. His itinerary is as follows:

1. Kamloops - As stated above, we will advise you as soon as we know when he reaches the Kamloops School, and the Department would appreciate it if you would meet him there in order that the changes, if any, in the heating and plumbing may be discussed with him by Father O'Grady and yourself.

2. William's Lake and Lejac - We would like to have arrangements made to have Mr. Hargreaves driven from Kamloops to the Cariboo Residential School at William's Lake, and also from William's Lake to Lejac. Possibly, one of the officials at Kamloops could take him to William's Lake and it could be arranged to have him met there and taken to Lejac. However, I have no doubt that you will make the best arrangements possible under the circumstances.

3. Vancouver - Following his inspection of the Lejac Residential School, Mr. Hargreaves will travel from Prince George to Vancouver by Canadian Pacific Airways. On reaching Vancouver he will visit the Sechelt School and the Alert Bay School.
4. Following his visit to the two schools just mentioned, he will proceed by air to Edmonton and then home.

Owing to the rush of work in Head Office of the Lands & Development Services Branch at the present time, Mr. Hargreaves' services can only be spared for a limited time. However, we hope that his trip will result in our obtaining definite information regarding the procedure that should be followed in connection with repairs and improvements at the schools mentioned. We cannot guarantee to provide this year all that Mr. Hargreaves might recommend, but you can be assured that we will give his recommendations careful and immediate consideration.

May 30, 1949  
Williams Lake, B.C.

Re: Kamloops Indian Residential School

Further to my night letter of the 29th you are advised as follows:

I arrived in Kamloops at 12:45 p.m. from Calgary by train on Sunday the 29th and registered at the Plaza Hotel. Mr. Arneil met me the following morning and we visited the Residential School, meeting Father O'Grady, the Principal.

After clarifying the changes to the original design of the classroom block and recording them for the use of our Electrical Engineer, I measured the distance between the new block and the residential building and back to the boiler room in order to determine the extent of the revisions to the heating system.

The Classroom block is located 88'-0" from the main building and the total distance from the block to the boiler room is 225'-0". In view of the fact that the pipe sizes for the heating system in the new classroom block had been established, it was necessary to calculate the pump size to meet the conditions brought about by moving the boiler to the boiler room of the main building.

Having done this I requested the Principal to call in the Contractor, whose price was low. Following a general discussion, the Contractor agreed to the few minor changes without increase in price. I learned that Giddens & Sons were considered very reliable in this area.

The Kamloops School is one of the finest institutions of its kind that I have visited. The boilers are loaded to capacity but they are able to carry the load and look to be in good condition. The Principal pointed out to me the domestic hot water equipment. It is comprised of a 250 gallon storage tank with a small jacket heater and is vastly undersized. He stated that he had brought this to the attention of the Indian Affairs Branch but so far nothing had been done.

There are 340 pupils here plus a large staff and this equipment cannot begin to handle the load. Mr. Arneil suggested that prices be obtained on the necessary equipment and forwarded through the Indian Agent to the Indian Affairs Branch for consideration. Accordingly I outlined a brief specification and the Principal was authorized to contact local firms and secure competitive bids.

There is no doubt that this equipment is badly needed. I believe it can be installed for less than $800 dollars. It is likely that the bids will reach Ottawa before I return and it is for that reason I now bring it to your attention.

C. H. Buck, M.R.A.I.C.

Dear Sirs:

Indian Residential School - Kamloops, B.C.

HEATING

We take pleasure in submitting our estimate for supplying hot water heating system as per plan with the exception of removing the boiler from the new school and installing in the old boiler room of the Residential school.

We would carry a 2 1/2" hot water main and return from the old boiler room to the new building. Installing 2 - 2 1/2" circulating pumps with valves and by-passes. Only one pump would operate at a time. The other pump would be a stand-by pump in case of a breakdown. We would increase the boiler size by one section for domestic hot water supply and install an indirect hot water heater. This would take the place of the electric tank which was to be installed in the boiler room of the new school. This boiler would operate automatically summer and winter and supply hot water for the new classrooms.

We would cover the return mains with 4 ply asbestos covering, install mains in cedar box between the new building and the old one. We would install a 100 lbs. Iron Fireman automatic coal stoker. We would also recommend that the chimney which would have been built at the new school be built in the corner of the old boiler house so that the new boiler would have a separate chimney.

If this heating proposal is accepted we would make the complete installation for the sum of Ten Thousand, Nine Hundred and Fifty-Seven Dollars ($10957.00).

Yours very truly,

H. GIDDENS & SONS

The following is a brief review of the circumstances in connection with the new domestic hot water equipment for the above.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR

Kamloops Residential School,
Kamloops, British Columbia.

It was the intention of the Indian Affairs Branch to build a Four Classroom Indian Day School at the above location according to plans and specifications Index No. 836 prepared by this Service. However, before construction was started, it was decided that by heating the Day School from the Residential School the heating plant area could be utilized for instructional purposes.

The Indian Affairs Branch informed us in their memorandum dated the 11th of April, 1949, that changes had been made to our layout and they obtained tenders for the electrical work based on the proposed changes to be made. In our memorandum to Indian Affairs dated the 2nd of May, 1949, we pointed out that since we had no knowledge of the extent of the alterations we were unable to offer worthwhile comment on the tenders forwarded to us. In a discussion with Col. Neary, he requested that our commentary on the electrical work be deferred until such time as we were fully acquainted with the situation.

Our electrical engineer visited Kamloops last November during his western inspection trip and took measurements and prepared a plan of the new layout. There was such a great variation from our original plans that it was considered advisable to prepare a new electrical design and call for competitive tenders on this basis. We have completed our electrical design and have today delivered by hand to Col. Neary six (6) copies of our plans and specifications Index No. 827, which the Indian Affairs Branch will send to the electrical contractors for re-bid.

Our officer inspected the Residential School and out-buildings while he was at the site, and in this connection, we make the following remarks.

(a) Residential School

It is proposed to continue to use several of the existing classrooms in this building as instructional areas when the classroom block is in operation. The lighting in these classrooms is very poor and we consider it necessary to increase the illumination.
(a) Residential School (Cont'd)

The lighting in other areas throughout the school is below minimum requirements, and it is recommended that general improvements in lighting be carried out as required to our specifications. It is also recommended that a minimum number of plug receptacles be provided thus eliminating the hazards existing through the use of long temporarily connected extension cords.

The present distribution system is 2 wire, 115 volts alternating current and we recommend that a 3 wire, 115/230 volt system be provided and that existing open knife type distribution centres be replaced by modern totally enclosed equipment.

(b) Out-buildings

There are a number of buildings located at the site, and it is recommended that alterations in the wiring be made to conform to code regulations and good practice. The electrical installations in several of the more recently constructed buildings is satisfactory and requires no attention.

In summary therefore, we desire from the Indian Affairs Branch:

1. Concurrence in providing a new distribution system and improved lighting and wiring in the Residential School.

2. Concurrence in providing lighting and wiring improvements in the Out-buildings in accordance with Canadian Electrical Code Regulations and good practice.

We estimate that the above mentioned work can be carried out under contract for an amount not exceeding $4,500.00.

Chief,

I have for acknowledgment Mr. Neary's Army Signals message of this date relative to various matters in connection with the Kamloops Indian Residential School and would advise as follows:

(1) Re Tank heater for domestic hot water for classroom block:
It will be recalled that Messrs. Giddens and Company, when tendering on the plumbing contract, quoted on an adequate size tank heater whereas Messrs Carr and Sons in their tender inadvertently quoted on a small size tank heater. Messrs. Carr and Sons' tender was accepted to complete the contract.
As the smaller heater quoted in their tender is quite insufficient for the requirements of the school it is considered necessary to have installed a tank heater of the proper size. A quotation was received from Messrs. Carr and Sons indicating the difference in price, installed, between the small heater already quoted on and the large heater necessary. This amounts to $988. Owing to the above circumstances quotations were not invited nor was it considered feasible to do so having in mind that the contract had already been awarded. It is considered that the price submitted is satisfactory and the purchase is strongly recommended.

(2) Re Purchase of 80 quart food mixer:
It is noted that it is not considered advisable to supply an 80 quart food mixer at the present time. In conversation with Father O'Grady today he advises that the purchase of two 20-quart food mixers would not be sufficient for the school's purpose and would continually require both small mixers operating at one time with obvious inconvenience and additional work.
Father O'Grady asks if authority could be obtained to secure a 60 quart food mixer. The 60-quart food mixer
could be economically used and would be considered sufficient. On receipt of your further comments regarding our procuring a 60-quart size, prices can be obtained. In the meantime no action is being taken to secure the 20-quart food mixer.

(3) Stoker for kitchen range:
Father O'Grady was under the impression that a quotation had been forwarded to Ottawa. Steps are being taken today to have quotations forwarded this evening by airmail so that the matter may receive attention. I am advised by Father O'Grady that Messrs. Giddens and Sons are giving an advantageous price on the stoker for the kitchen range.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dept. Citizenship & Immigration

Dear Colonel Neary:

In connection with the installation of the domestic hot water unit for this School I wish to advise that Mr. Hargreaves of the Department of Lands & Development, on his visit here a year ago, approached H. Giddens Ltd. of Kamloops, who were to get the contract for heating the Classroom Block, and asked them to quote on the domestic hot water unit. H. Giddens Ltd. had already figured, in their price on the heating job, to supply hot water for domestic use by increasing the size of their heating unit. Mr. Hargreaves did not favour that method of heating water and recommended a separate installation. He outlined what was required and asked H. Giddens Ltd. to quote a price on this separate unit. Since a separate unit for domestic hot water was being called for H. Giddens Ltd. would not need now to increase the size of their heating boiler. They suggested to re-quote on their heating contract price at a lower figure. Mr. Hargreaves thought it best for them to leave their heating contract price stand but asked them, in quoting on the domestic hot water unit, to arrive at a figure less the amount they saved in not having to increase the size of their heating boiler. H. Giddens Ltd. did this. The situation changes now with another Contractor coming into the picture. Carr & Son of Kamloops were asked to quote on the domestic hot water unit by the local Superintendent and they, without sufficiently studying what was required, put in a price on a unit far too small at a much less figure, and got the contract. H. Giddens Ltd. were surprised but not disappointed because they effected quite a saving on their heating job.

In the quotation of Carr & Son on the domestic hot water unit it is the size of the heating tank that is far too small. To correct the situation Carr & Son subsequently quoted to install a heating tank to the amount of $988.00. The domestic hot water unit would then be of the same size as quoted on by H. Giddens Ltd. which is the size required.

I hope the above explanation will clarify the situation of the contract mentioned in the preceding paragraphs and that some action can be forthcoming soon to proceed with the installation of the domestic hot water unit which is so urgently needed.

Yours sincerely,

F. O'Grady O.M.I.,

Complying to your request for a statement of the damages to the 50 H.P., 2200 volt motor of the irrigation pump, we advise as follows.

On receiving a phone call that there was trouble in this motor, we went to investigate. On enquiry we were advised the pump was in normal operation and suddenly stopped. Smoke was seen coming from the motor and the starting compensator.

KAMLOOPS INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL,

With reference to your marginal request on Major MacKay's memorandum of the 1st of June in connection with the above, the following comment is provided.

2. Due to circumstances with which we have no connection or control, it would appear that a misunderstanding has arisen with regard to Father O'Grady's request for improvements to the domestic hot water system in the residential school. It is the purpose of this memorandum to review the circumstances known to us and to suggest a recommendation on which the Indian Affairs Branch may base their action.

3. Our Mr. Hargreaves visited this school a year ago in connection with changes to the Four Classroom Block then under construction. At that time Father O'Grady pointed out that the domestic hot water facilities in the residential school were inadequate to meet the requirements for his pupils and staff. Our officer inspected these services and verified the principal's contention. Father O'Grady was advised to submit his request for improvements to the Indian Affairs Branch through the local Indian Superintendent. Since the Superintendent was away on a business trip, Mr. Arnell who was present, suggested that Father O'Grady's request should be submitted to him for transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch.

4. Our officer outlined the requirements and it was agreed that since this work had nothing to do with the contract being carried out at the new Classroom Block, it should be classed as a maintenance item. Therefore, Father O'Grady was advised to obtain prices on the following equipment:

One - 1000 gallon domestic hot water storage tank with suitable steel supports.

One - High-Test cast iron jacket heater built for a working pressure of 75 p.s.i., having a capacity to raise 500 gallons of water per hour through 100 degree temperature rise.

One - pressure relief valve set to release at 60 p.s.i.

One - stoker to fire jacket heater having a capacity to burn coal at a maximum rate of 50 lbs. per hour. All necessary piping, valves and fittings as may be required to complete the installation.

Major MacKay:
For your information.

Director,
9/8/50.

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6450, file 882-5 part 15)
5. Giddens and Sons were the contractors carrying out the plumbing and heating installation in the Classroom Block. They submitted a price for the work, which for reasons unknown to us, was not acted on by the Indian Affairs Branch.

6. After they had completed their contract and moved out, the local Indian Superintendent called for prices and the work was awarded to Carr and Son, whose tender was much lower than that of Giddens and Sons. After the work was awarded to Carr and Son, Father O'Grady discovered that they had tendered on equipment of insufficient capacity and not in accordance with the requirements suggested by our officer.

7. Father O'Grady's letter, a copy of which was attached to Major MacKay's memorandum, does not give sufficient detail for us to furnish complete comment. He states that the "Domestic hot water unit would then be of the same size as quoted on by H. Giddens Limited, which is the size required".

8. In order for us to recommend that the Carr and Son tender be accepted, it will be necessary to have Father O'Grady submit to us an itemized list of the equipment they propose to supply. This list should include the items mentioned in paragraph 4 of this memorandum. We would also be interested to know the contractor's price. Since this work is to be administered by the Indian Affairs Branch, no funds will be transferred to this Service.

Chief.

Sir,

Reverting to the matter of irrigation of the land of the Kamloops Industrial School which we discussed during your visit to the province, I beg to say that no outlay has yet been made in the direction of having an estimate prepared, and it seems that a little has been gained by waiting.

The man I had in view to look it over has been ill and would not have been able to undertake it up to the present; but in discussing the matter with Indian Agent Smith I learned that he was expecting to obtain the services of an engineer from the Department of Interior to go into another matter relating to water for the Indians of the Kamloops Agency, and he would have him take levels at the Industrial School. That engineer has not yet come and the matter remains as it was.

Last week I spent a couple of days in Kamloops attending the Convention of the Western Canada Irrigation Association and met Father La Chesne with whom I had an interview, and he appeared urgent to get matters under way, but he advised me of a new complication in the situation which to my mind would make it prudent to hasten slowly for a bit and allow matters to work themselves out. He is dissatisfied with the location of the C.N.R. right of way through through the Industrial School grounds which was arranged for by my predecessor, Mr. Commiskey, and wanted the question re-opened. Were it not that this matter of C.N.R. right of way is a factor in the irrigation project which
we had in view, I would not care to deal with the matter of re-opening the right of way question which I understand was sufficiently difficult in itself before it was settled; but if the C. N. R. is to be built on its present location it will affect materially the cost and efficiency of a suitable irrigation system for the Industrial School grounds. Father La Chesne gave me a rough sketch of the C. N. R. location through the school grounds and I enclose it herewith. As the buildings stand on an eminence and the railway which will pass in rear of them is on ground that is still higher, it will mean a deep cut there and a moderately high fill all along the flat and river front to the east.

I also discussed the question of irrigation for the Kamloops Industrial School grounds with Mr. Young, Provincial Water Comptroller, and he promised to let some of his engineers look it over without any cost to the Indian Department for such service, and that is another reason why it might be better to let the matter rest for a bit to give the right of way situation time to clear up a little before rushing into any expenditure. Father La Chesne is anxious to get work under way this fall.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Indian Agencies

Dear Sir,

In accordance with your request I have made an examination of the Kamloops Indian Industrial School Farm with the object of ascertaining the feasibility of irrigating a portion of this farm by pumping from the South Thompson River, and beg to submit the following report:

The natural conditions existing are favourable to the irrigation of this land by pumping and with a reasonable annual charge for the necessary power, it should be a satisfactory method of irrigation.

The land included in the present pumping project contains a total possible area of about 100 acres, which can be economically developed, requiring only a short pipe line 380 feet in length to deliver the water to a point where it can be distributed by flumes and ditches to all the fields to be irrigated.

In order to determine the capacity of the pumping plant required, it was of course necessary to secure the best data available as to the duty of water, or the amount necessary per acre in this district, also the number and duration of the applications.

With the natural precipitation during the irrigation season, (which will generally amount to about 5 inches) it is probably safe to state that as an average for the different crops to be grown on this soil, and under this most favourable condition of delivery, (where practically all of the water reaches the land)
two acre-feet per acre would be an ample supply to be pumped during the irrigation season.

It is stated that the irrigation season extends from the first of May to the first of September and that about four applications of water are necessary during this season.

The duration of each service and the depth of water to be put on the land will vary greatly with the class of soil and the different crops, and therefore it is difficult to acquire reliable data regarding this matter, but the maximum requirement at a service should not exceed eight inches in depth.

It will be necessary to provide a pumping plant of a suitable capacity to pump sufficient water during such periods, when the greatest amount is actually needed during working hours, as no natural storage reservoir exists here which could be cheaply developed, to equalize the supply pumped, and by this means permit of a smaller pump being used.

Where one half of the crop is alfalfa and the other half grain or other crops requiring a similar volume of water, and when an economical use of the water is made under a rotation system, experiments in other localities have shown that about 19 per cent of the water should be delivered in the month of May, 26 per cent in June, 33 per cent in July and 20 per cent in August. Applying this data to the 100 acres under contemplation, the maximum pump duty will be 33 per cent of 200 acre-feet, or 66 acre-feet to be pumped in thirty days of twelve working hours each, which amounts to 2.2 cubic feet per second. (It is assumed that in this particular case the pump will be operated only during the daylight hours).

As no doubt there will be a variety of crops grown and the services of water can be regulated so that the different fields receive it alternately in sufficient quantities to suit the different crops, I have concluded that a pump of the above capacity will be ample to irrigate the one hundred acres considered in this
The total lift (including friction head) to the point of delivery or distribution into the main ditches is 50 feet above the average water level of S. Thompson River during the irrigation season (as near as can be ascertained) and the necessary power required to operate the proposed pump would be 25 H.P. on the pump shaft, allowing an efficiency of 50% for the pump.

The transmission line from the Kamloops sub-station to the pump house will have a total length of 1.20 miles of which 0.90 miles of poles are already installed, requiring only the additional cross-arms, pins, insulators and wires.

Power is distributed from the Kamloops sub-station into the main lines at 2200 volts and will be transmitted to the pump-house through No. 6 gauge copper wires at this voltage, where it will then be reduced to 220 volts by two service transformers.

With regard to the cost of power, this is a matter which will have to be arranged with the City of Kamloops, as their present schedule of prices (as published) are prohibitory, but no doubt a special arrangement can be made based upon a reasonable charge per horse power or a lump sum for the season.

As an example of what charges are being made by other power companies for similar work, I may mention the case of the Pitt Meadows Land Company who operate a large pump at Pitt Meadows during about four months each year. The Western Canada Power Company constructed the transmission line and supply the necessary power at one cent per K.W. hour, with a minimum charge of $200.00 for the season.

Probably 25,000 K.W. hours would be the total amount you would require during an irrigation season, so that the annual cost of irrigating the farm at this rate would amount to about $250.00 or about $2.50 per acre, without taking into consideration
the interest on the cost of the plant and assuming that the operating and maintenance are provided by the School.

I may here mention that the area of irrigable land in this project, which we examined in the company of the School Principal and Agent, is smaller than I at first anticipated, but no doubt is a sufficient area to demonstrate the feasibility of pumping.

A very much larger area of level land lying along the North Thompson River in the vicinity of Paul Creek, can no doubt be successfully irrigated by pumping. This large tract of land which is now being served by Paul Creek, would require a separate pumping plant on the N. Thompson River, and may receive your future consideration, after more data has been secured.

With regard to the Western portion of the land under consideration, lying between the 40 foot contour and the low area subject to flooding, there is an area here of about 32 acres of light sandy soil, a large portion of which can probably be considered as irrigable land. Irrigation at the Industrial School. Memorandum

Mr. Scott,

1st. Re Water-supply and Irrigation of Land of Kamloops Industrial School.

-------------------------------

The following notes were taken from the several files relating to the water-supply of the Kamloops Industrial school and the various attempts and suggestions made to date to irrigate the school land for farming purposes.

Up to January 2, 1892, the water-supply for both domestic and irrigation purposes was furnished by a windmill pumping water from the Thompson River into a wooden tank located in the attic of the school building but owing to the inadequate supply of water thus obtained an additional quantity had to be carried to the school by the pupils, a distance of 400 feet, with an elevation of about fifty feet.

On January 2, 1892, Rev. J. A. Bedard of Victoria applied to the Department for an additional irrigation plant, for the Industrial school, consisting of a 12 foot geared aerometer, a pneumatic low pressure pump, air compressor, 50 foot wooden tower, shaft, fittings, a 2000 gallons water tank and the necessary piping to lay a pipe line from the river to the proposed site of the tank, a distance of about 400 feet. The estimated cost of the work was given at $956.00, but upon the recommendation of Mr. A. W. Vowell, Indian Superintendent, who stated that the scheme as thus suggested would not give satisfactory results, the work was not carried out.

On March 17, 1893, Mr. A. W. Vowell reported to the Department that the water-supply for both domestic and irri-
irrigation purposes was almost a failure and that provision would have to be made to improve the situation especially as to the irrigation of the school land and a detailed report was subsequently furnished by Agent J. W. MacKay suggesting that the old wind-mill be repaired so as to provide irrigation for the school garden and lower part of the school reserve and that a new pumping plant be installed which could be operated by hand or belt-driven to furnish the required supply of water to the school building. The estimated cost of this new pumping apparatus including the well, wooden tank and piping amounted to $240.00. No action was taken by the Department in this matter.

On February 7, 1906, the Principal of the school, Rev. M.N. Carion, applied for a grant of $250.00 to install a new wind-mill similar to that already suggested by Rev. J.A. Bedard in 1892 to irrigate a few extra acres of land in the school reserve. Upon the recommendation of both the Indian Superintendent and Agent the amount of $250.00 was paid by the Department for the machinery only, and the labor was furnished by the school authorities.

On March 21, 1912, an architect, Mr. J. Partlett, engaged by the Department to make an inspection of that school reported that the water-supply was exposed to contamination owing to the bad location of the intake pipe and recommended that the pumping of water for domestic purposes from artesian wells. No action has yet been taken with reference to this suggestion.

On January, 28, 1913, Mr. R. Bell, an architect from Vernon B.C., also made an inspection of the school especially of the water-supply. He, in his report, mentioned that the 3 H.P. gasoline engine which had been purchased by the school to operate the pump was worn out and that the whole
plant was far from being satisfactory. He suggested the installation of a new pumping system which would be driven by electricity, the cost of which would only amount to $700.00, in view of the fact that electricity was being brought to the school at that time. The proposal was not carried out owing to lack of funds.

On June 2, 1913, the Principal and the Agent made a strong plea that the 3 H.P. gasoline engine above mentioned be replaced and the request was granted on August 6, 1913. The amount authorized for the change was fixed at $250.00.

On April 13, 1915, an amount of $87.20 was expended in repairing the old wind-mill used for irrigation of farm land.

On July 4, 1917, an amount of $52.50 was also expended in repairing the gasoline engine also used for irrigation purposes.

On March 8, 1917, another request was made by Rev. J. Welch for the installation of a new and complete pumping plant for the irrigation of the school land, but same was not taken into consideration owing to the reduction in the school appropriation.

On April 8, 1917, the Principal, Rev. J.B. Salles, reported that only from five to eight acres of land were being cultivated and that considerable loss was suffered owing to the lack of proper and sufficient irrigation and applied for some help towards improving the present condition.

Finally on February 8, 1918, Agent J. Smith informed the Department that the failure in last year's vegetable and hay crops was due to the insufficient and poor system of irrigation, and stated that 100 acres of good land could be utilized if irrigated and that such improvement would enable
this institution to grow sufficient vegetables and other farm products.

The school reserve has an area of 352 acres of which only 8 acres are being cultivated; this compels the authorities to pay, each year, a considerable sum of money for vegetables and other products which could be obtained from their own farm if some reliable system of irrigation could be provided, such as that described in the following item.

On December 4, 1916, a complete survey was made of the school reserve by a civil engineer of Vancouver, Mr. H. Burwell, with a view to preparing the necessary plans, estimates and reports on the feasibility of irrigating a sufficient portion of the school farm. According to Mr. H. Burwell's notes on the proposed scheme an additional 100 acres could be economically developed along the shore of the South Thompson River. The plant consisted in summary of pumping the water with an electric driven pump a distance of 350 feet to a distributing tank from where it could be carried to the different portions of the fields by means of wooden flumes and ditches.

The cost of the whole installation at that time was estimated at $4,500.00, and its annual maintenance and operation $300.00.

Although several requests were made to this Department by the Principal, the agent, etc., who all agreed on the urgent need of this improvement, the Department decided that the work as proposed could not be taken into consideration at present owing to war conditions.

I may add that upon examination of the proposed plans and estimates, I think that several changes could be made which would reduce both the cost of the installation of the plant and its operation, if the scheme is to be carried out at a later date.

J. D. Chene,
Architect and Engineer.

Design and Estimates for Pumping Plant
For Irrigating Land at Industrial School
Kamloops Indian Reserve.

Previous surveys and investigations have developed the essential facts in connection with the proposed irrigation project. One hundred acres of land are to be irrigated by a pumping plant capable of delivering water at the rate of 1000 G.P.M. into a ditch 50 feet above low water. Electric power can be obtained from the power plant of the city of Kamloops, situated about 6500 feet away and on the opposite side of the river.

In preparing the design submitted, the effort has been to provide, at a reasonable cost, an installation of standard pumping machinery of the required capacity which will operate reliably under the local conditions. In this, we have been guided by the actual performance of a plant of similar capacity which was installed last spring just across the river from the proposed location of the present plant and operated under similar conditions.

In order to have a cheap and simple installation, the pump and motor are to be set above high water, where they can be mounted on an ordinary concrete block foundation, without danger of being injured by the water. With this type of installation, the suction head should be kept as low as possible and in any event should not exceed 25 feet.

Gauge readings have been kept on the Thompson river at Kamloops by the B.C. Hydrometric Survey since the spring of 1911. The highest water for the different years was as follows:

| Year | Gauge Height |
|------|--------------|
| 1911 | 14.8         |
| 1912 | 12.8         |
| 1913 | 14.6         |
| 1914 | 12.0         |
| 1915 | 10.2         |
| 1916 | 13.9         |
| 1917 | 14.4         |
The highest water for the last seven years was 14.8 feet.

The elevation of the pump foundation for the plant on the Vic Ranch on the south side of the river is 16 feet, and of the bottom of the lower chord of the new C.N.Railway bridge is 21 feet. We have decided to adopt 18 feet, which is 3 feet above the highest water for the last 7 years, but below the level of the 1894 flood. If another exceptionally high flood should come some year, the motor can be removed for the few days of extreme high water.

The ordinary height of the water during the irrigation season is from 2 to 12 feet on the gauge, so that the suction lift of the pump will vary from 16 to 6 feet. Very little water would be pumped at the 16 foot lift.

The elevation of the outlet of the discharge pipe is to be 30 feet above the centre of the pump. The total vertical lift, therefore, would be from 36 to 48 feet.

The discharge pipe will be about 350 feet long and most of it will be 8 inch wood stave pipe. The suction pipe will be 25 feet long and will be 8 inch steel pipe. The discharge of the pump at a total head of 50 feet is to be 1000 G.P.M. Under these conditions the friction head would be about 14 feet.

The total head to be pumped against, therefore, will ordinarily be somewhere between 50 and 62 feet, with short periods in which the limits may be passed in either direction.

In such an installation as the one proposed, some method must be provided for priming the pump, since a centrifugal pump will not pump air. The method proposed is to use a foot valve on the lower end of the suction pipe, with a hand force pump to fill the pipe. This is quite a simple and reliable method except that a foot valve may get out of order occasionally and provision must be made for cleaning it.

It is quite an advantage to have some method of preventing sticks and other foreign substances from entering the pump and from interfering with the proper action of the foot valve; but if an ordinary small mesh screen is used on a pipe set directly in the river, it is apt to become clogged with...
weeds, leaves and small sticks. For these reasons it has been decided to dig a well and connect it with the river by a timber pipe about 2 feet square buried in a trench below the lowest water level for the irrigation season. The pump will take water from the well which will be kept at the level of the river by the flow through the timber pipe. A coarse screen of iron rods can be placed over the outer end of the timber pipe, and if necessary a fine screen on the lower end of the suction pipe below the foot valve. Then if anything interferes with the foot valve or fine screen, it is a comparatively simple matter to disconnect the lower part of the pipe and raise it up for examination and cleaning.

The well and trench must be dug and the timbering finished while the water in the river is low, preferably before the middle of April.

The pumping unit proposed consists of a 6 inch Centrifugal pump, capable of delivering 1000 U.S.gallons per minute against a head of 50 feet at 800 R.F.M., direct connected to a 25 H.P. 3 phase, 60 cycle, 220 volt, electric motor. This can be delivered from Vancouver within 3 weeks of the placing of the order.

This plant could supply 65 acre-feet of water in a month of 30 days, working 12 hours a day. This would be sufficient for 100 acres of land in the driest month.

At present prices, 6 inch steel pipe would cost at least $2.00 a foot, so that to provide steel pipe for the whole length of the 350-foot discharge pipe would cost $700.00 plus the freight from Vancouver.

It is proposed to use instead, 350 feet of 6 inch wood stave pipe, wire wound and asphalt coated. This pipe will be safe for pressures up to 75-foot head, and can be purchased at Vancouver for 52 cents a foot. It will not be buried, but will be placed on sills and not allowed to come in contact with the ground.
Under these conditions, it should last at least five years and probably ten years or more. Its first cost just about equals the interest for five years at 5% on the first cost of the steel pipe.

The estimate for the transmission line is based on the assumption that power can be obtained from the end of the transmission line which serves the pumping plant at the Vic ranch on the south side of the Thompson river. This line is about 6000 feet long and cost $1300. to build. It was paid for by the owners of the ranch on the understanding that the city can take it over at cost when there are other plants to be served from it. Until the city does take over this line, some arrangement would have to be made with the owners.

Possibly the city of Kamloops would supply the transformers, which would reduce the necessary expenditure by $500.00

In the whole season, probably 2 acre-feet of water would be required per acre. With an efficiency of 50% in the pump and 95% in the motor, the amount of power required per acre would be about 300 kilowatt hours. The rate quoted by the city
is $0.15 per kilowatt hour, so that the cost for power would be about $4.50 per acre each season.

The cost of power for 100 acres of land on the Vic ranch last season at a somewhat lower head was $300.00 at the same rate for power.

An interest and depreciation charge of 15% on a plant cost of $2,500.00 would be $375.00, or $3.75 an acre if distributed over the whole 100 acres. This would give a total charge of $8.25 per acre, for power, interest and depreciation.

It is assumed that the ordinary attendance and maintenance would be looked after by the Industrial School in connection with the regular irrigation and farming operations. There might also be a rental charge for the use of the section of the transmission line from the power house to the Vic ranch until it is taken over by the city.

Sir:

In my report for the pumping plant for the Kamloops Industrial School dated March 30th., 1918, I based my estimates on the supposition that we would be able to make a reasonable arrangement with Mr. Dawson, the owner of the transmission line to the Vic ranch, which would enable us to transmit the power for the pumping plant over his line from the city power house. On account of the short time allowed, it was necessary to submit our report without waiting to get a definite agreement from Mr. Dawson.

We find now that Mr. Dawson wants to charge a rental of One hundred dollars ($100.00) a year for the privilege of using his line. This rental charge is merely for the use of his transmission line which he will continue to use himself as well, and is quite distinct from the city's charge of $1 per kilowatt hour for power. In spite of the fact that you stated you would not be willing to pay more than $50.00 a year, he refuses to make any reduction in his original figures. The amount he asks seems rather high.

Fortunately, however, there is another way of transmitting the power. The first cost will not be very much more than the original plan, and it will not involve any annual rental. After a careful inspection, we have found that the present two-wire lighting circuit to the Industrial School is in good condition, and that by adding a third wire and building some 1700 feet of
line, we will obtain a system which will be quite capable of transmitting the necessary current. This whole system will belong to the Department and will be almost entirely on the reserve.

The cost of the re-construction and extension work has been estimated very carefully, and it would be about three hundred dollars ($300.00) more than the original plan. This seems quite a reasonable capital expenditure to save an annual charge of $100.00 and if you consent, we will make this change in the transmission line plans. It will increase the total estimated cost for the plant from $2800.00 to $3100.00.

I am sorry that this feature was not referred to more fully in our original report, but at that time we did not realize that Mr. Dawson would insist on such a high rental, and we did not know that the cost of re-constructing the present lighting system to the Industrial School would be so low, since previous estimates by the other engineers were much higher.

I am enclosing a plan of the two transmission systems which will help to explain the general situation.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Division Engineer

J.F. Smith,
Indian Agent,
Kamloops, B.C.
I beg to enclose herewith a report from Mr. Cline, Divisional Engineer of the Hydrographic Department.

In submitting same I beg to say that we failed to make satisfactory arrangements with the proprietor of the farm directly opposite the Industrial School to transmit the current over his wire. On further investigation it was found that by adding another wire to our existing pole line, it would be capable of carrying the necessary current, thus eliminating an annual overhead charge of $100.00. The Engineer has decided to adopt the latter course, and install an independent line, with an extra cost of $300.00.

All the machinery is now on the ground and is being installed.

Special report on work will follow.
